PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TATE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from seven citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of the Parliament of Australia in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully calls for:

The Honourable Minister for Social Security to give assurances to the parents, staff and children of the Educational Programme for Infants and Children, Preston Institute of Technology, Bundoora, in the State of Victoria, otherwise known as EPIC, this being the largest early intervention programme for handicapped children in Australia, that he will continue his financial support for the said programme after June 1981 and that he will continue such support until he has secured alternative financial support for the EPIC programme,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Acting Clerk-A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Patients' Medical Records
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patients' medical records:
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should-
Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to insurance intermediaries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in view of the long established practice that serious breaches by members of Parliament or their staff of codes of conduct in relation to members of Parliament within the precincts of Parliament are sought to be resolved by Parliament rather than by the police, the matter of repeated nuisance and personally abusive telephone calls made to a member of the Senate at his Parliament House office on 8 and 10 April 1981 be referred to the Committee of Privileges.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Due to the congestion which exists at Sydney airport, will the Minister for Transport confer with the major airlines to see whether more flights within Australia could by-pass Sydney? I mention as examples possible direct flights from Brisbane to Canberra and Adelaide and increasing the frequency of current direct flights which by-pass Sydney or obviate the need to fly through Sydney, for example, flights from Melbourne to Brisbane and from Adelaide to Canberra.

—Obviously Senator Colston has not thought through the problems which may occur. Other airports may not be able to provide the same facilities as would be available at Sydney airport to service international aircraft and to allow passengers to disembark in some comfort. Nevertheless, he has asked me to send the question on to my colleague in the other House. I will do so.

—Did the Attorney-General see in the Canberra Times recently a report that a senator had accused a Canberra magistrate of having perverted justice? Has the Attorney-General examined the allegation and taken any action in relation to it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn to the remarks made by Senator Mulvihill in this chamber on 29 April concerning a magistrate to whom Senator Mulvihill referred as Magistrate Nichols. I gather, that in fact, he was referring to Mr W. K. Nicholl, a magistrate in the Australian Capital Territory. There is a special magistrate by the name of Nichols; but the criticism, I gather, referred to Mr Nicholl, who is one of the stipendiary magistrates. Mr Nicholl is a highly respected and competent magistrate. I am not aware of any justification for Senator Mulvihill's allegations that Mr Nicholl is perverting the course of justice in relation to traffic offenders in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Mulvihill's criticism of Mr Nicholl has brought forth very prompt statements on behalf of both legal professional bodies in the Territory. A letter from the Australian Capital Territory Bar Association appeared in the Canberra Times on 6 May and a similar letter from the President of the Law Society of the Australian Capital Territory appeared in the same newspaper on 12 May. I draw the Senate's attention to the defence of Mr Nicholl made in both those letters. I have received a letter from the President of the Law Society in which he has assured me that Mr Nicholl has the confidence of the profession in regard to his personal integrity, honesty and competence.

I refer now to the case upon which the criticism was based. I only wish to add that the penalty that was imposed was in respect of only one of six charges that had been laid. Two other charges were dismissed on the evidence and no evidence was tendered on the three other charges. I have known Mr Nicholl and have heard of his capacity as a magistrate since I have been Attorney-General. I must say that what I know of him and his reputation gives me every confidence in his capacity as a magistrate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether he, effectively, apologised to the Senate during the week before last for what he said was an error by his Department in altering an estimate by the National Energy Advisory Committee. Did the error appear in a printed release tendered by the Minister at a Press conference on 2 February this year? Why did the Minister, or some other person, at the same Press conference also change the estimate of NEAC about the lead time for development of the Rundle project from 8 to 15 years to 8 to 10 years? Was this also an error on the part of his Department or was it an attempt to mislead the Press and the public about the real chances of the Rundle project going ahead?

—I understand that some time ago the Secretary to my Department wrote a letter to the Press explaining the situation. Whether it was published or not I do not know, but I will seek to get the letter and the facts as the Department explains them and as they have occurred. An attachment representing the accurate picture of the NEAC report was wrongly typed in an ordinary typing transformation. It was nothing more than that. I was not aware that that was so. I spoke at the Press conference on the basis that the document represented NEAC's views. I will get the statement made by the Secretary to the Department and let the Senate have it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Was a transcript made of what was said by the Minister at that conference? Does not the transcript use the expression 'eight to 10 years' as being his calculation of a reasonable time in respect of the lead time on Rundle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that any transcript was made. It is possible that one was. I am not aware that my own Department did make a transcript. If it did, I would be happy to let the honourable senator peruse it. If he has a transcript, I would be happy to peruse it so that we can get to the facts.
—That would be an error, too?

—No. I hope that there is not going to be an attempt to continue to exacerbate a situation in which in an earnest desire to do a good job some typing member of my Department made an error. If that is to be a sin, then I am sorry for Senator Button and his own sense of purity.
—Never mind about my sense of purity. If you would just answer the question I would be happy.

—I would be very happy to do so. The answer is that in the course of the Press conference we made it clear that the report was some five or six months old and that estimates that had been made subsequent to that time had suggested that there may have been an improvement in lead time.

ANSWER.PARA: I would need to look at the transcript of that conference, but the fundamental situation was that there was a difference of some significant number of months-four, five or six months-and that my advisers had upgraded their sense of lead times. It was not any attempt on my part to alter the NEAC report. How silly it would be to contemplate that a Minister would be publishing a report and at the same time purporting to alter that report. To say it is to demonstrate the nonsense of the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it correct that the Australian Government and the Indonesian Government have reached an agreement in regard to the 200-mile limit affecting those waters surrounding both Indonesia and Timor? If this is so, can the Government advise details of the boundaries and the significance that this agreement will have in Australia on oil search, particularly in relation to the issue of exploration permits and the fishing industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that agreement has not been reached on the matter that has been raised by Senator Kilgariff. Negotiations are continuing between Australian and Indonesian officials aimed at reaching a comprehensive agreement on delimitation of those maritime areas between Australia and Indonesia not covered by the two seabed agreements concluded in 1971 and 1972.

ANSWER.PARA: A third round of talks between Australian and Indonesian officials was held in Canberra from 4 to 7 November last year. The two delegations continued their discussions on the various areas between the two countries where there are outstanding questions of delimitation of maritime boundaries, including the problem of overlapping fisheries jurisdiction. In particular, these two delegations undertook a further detailed examination of and exchange of views on specific proposals advanced by each side in respect of these areas. It was agreed that both sides would give further consideration to the proposals put forward by each side.

I am informed that the Australian delegation, which included representatives from the Northern Territory and Western Australia, has reported that the talks were useful in clarifying the proposals of both sides, and that a further round of talks will be held at a mutually convenient time in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Since the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which Department has responsibility for the work test for applicants for unemployment benefit-the Department of Social Security or the Commonwealth Employment Service?

—Some detailed work is still being done on this matter between the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. What is clearly determined is that the fortnightly forms which are required to be lodged will be lodged directly with my Department and not with the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. The extent to which there will be any additional function in my Department or to which the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs will be left with responsibility with respect to administration of the work test is still a matter for detailed decision, as I understand it. That answer is accurate as of a few days ago. I have not made any inquiry within the last few days but I will check the position and if that answer needs amplification I will give the additional information to the honourable senator.

—I seek amplification of the answer through a supplementary question. Does the Minister's answer mean that an announcement of considerable change of this magnitude was made without anyone, as of a few days ago, as the Minister put it, knowing who will decide who has left work voluntarily and who will decide who is making sufficient effort to seek work, as the work test requires now?

—I think the important point with respect to the unemployed is that they will be told quite clearly where the appropriate form has to be lodged. Whether there are any decisions with respect to people not accepting employment and so on will be matters which will be subject to notification, probably by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, to my Department.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. I refer to the establishment of the Australian Children's Television Foundation. Does the Minister recall that in February this year the Australian Education Council supported the establishment of the Foundation and appointed a steering committee which included two State Ministers of Education to assist in this establishment? As the establishment of the Foundation followed closely on a recommendation in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on children's television and as the Foundation cannot proceed without Commonwealth support, can the Minister give me an indication of the progress of the Foundation? In view of widespread public support for the Foundation and because of the urgency relating to quality children's television, will the Government take early steps to give encouragement and support to the Foundation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable senator said, the Australian Education Council, at its meeting in February this year, resolved to support the establishment of the Australian Children's Television Foundation. I confirm that the Council has agreed to the setting up of a steering committee convened by the New South Wales Minister for Education and the Victorian Minister of the Arts with a view to creating the Foundation. The Commonwealth has a representative on the steering committee. All States, except Queensland, have nominated members. The form the Foundation might take and the extent of its responsibilities will depend on agreement between the Commonwealth and the States, but it could be expected that the objectives of the Foundation would be consistent with the need expressed by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for an independent authority which would stimulate the production of programs available for children.

ANSWER.PARA: Until the report of the steering committee is available, I am not able to comment further on the ways in which a contribution by the Commonwealth might be made. This will be a matter for consideration by the Government when firm proposals have been formulated for the consideration of Commonwealth and State Ministers. The view was expressed at the February meeting of the Council that no assumptions should be made concerning the Commonwealth's attitude to the appropriate level of funding for the Foundation and as to the Commonwealth's share of participation. I will keep the matter under consideration for Senator Davidson. I know of his interest and leadership in this matter and I know of the work of his Senate Committee.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WOOL TESTING AUTHORITY: PROPOSED SALE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister partially in his capacity as representing the Minister for Primary Industry and also in his capacity as a Cabinet Minister. Is it a fact that the Government's decision to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority has been overwhelmingly rejected by woolgrowers throughout Australia? Has the wool commodity group of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association now added its voice to this widespread rejection of the Government's proposal? What ideological reasons lie behind the Government's dismantling of this profitable public enterprise which has a world-wide reputation, as evidenced by the support accorded it at the recent annual meeting of the International Wool Textile Organisation in New Zealand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some response to the proposal to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority. Some of that response has been in negative terms. I have not made any attempt to find out precisely what the total response has been and therefore I am not in a position to say to the honourable senator that I am aware of the Tasmanian response to which he referred, nor can I say whether the totality of response has been in the terms which he indicated. The honourable senator seeks some guidance as to the ideological reason for selling a profitable enterprise. I would have thought it was quite well known to all honourable senators opposite and certainly well known to the Australian people that this Government is one which believes in private and not public enterprise. We believe if a function can be performed by the private sector it should be performed by it.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose one of the side benefits of the whole exercise has been to disclose the differences between the political parties which are available to the Australian people. While the Opposition is happy to go before the Australian people as a proponent of public enterprise, we are very happy to go before the Australian people as proponents of private enterprise. We make no apology for that. We believe it will be a very important contribution to good government in this country if government concentrates on what only government can do and leaves to private enterprise what private enterprise can do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister a supplementary question. Following the Minister's remarks about side benefits, my question is: What private operators will take advantage of the Government's decision? Have any deals been done to give them the benefit of this dismantling of a profitable public enterprise?

—The honourable senator is one of the few senators whom I would have said would never be snide in this place, and I trust that he was not meaning to be snide in that question. When I talked of side benefits it was quite clear I was talking of the fact that one of the side effects of the decisions which were taken was to heighten the differences between the Opposition and the Government which can be perceived by the public. I think that is a benefit. I think it is a good thing for Australia and that is the only sense in which I used that term. I utterly reject the suggestion which is implicit in the supplementary question.

—My question is directed to Senator Chaney partly in his capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry and partly in his capacity as the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that the Government is considering the introduction of a subsidy similar to the superphosphate bounty for hirsutism? Is it a fact that the amount of the subsidy will be dependent upon the length of the whiskers of the applicant? Finally, will the Minister take it from here?

—I am probably not the wisest senator in this place but I am too smart to try to crack jokes in front of a professional. I know of no proposal to develop a subsidy in that area. From what I have seen of many of the people I work with in the Public Service and the people I see in the community, we are managing to promote that form of private enterprise without government subsidy. I would like to say that if we did introduce a subsidy it would be available only to Australian nationals or permanent residents.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In view of the fact that the razor gang has abolished the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension, a body established in 1978 and announced at the time with great flourish by the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair, I ask the Minister: Why did the present Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, who was a member of the razor gang, agree to the axing of this body which was carrying out very important work in the interests of Australia's primary producers? Finally, what person or body now has responsibility for recommending priorities for rural research?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will seek information from the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, in relation to the final part of the honourable senator's question because I am not able to answer him with particularity. There is nothing surprising in Mr Nixon's role as a member of the so-called razor gang in recommending the abolition of that particular body. The decisions on the Review of Commonwealth Functions were decisions taken by the Government as a whole, decisions in which all of us participated and with which we are all in agreement. The fact is that we undertook the task of fining down the Government's consultative mechanisms. The same thing was done with respect to my own Department in a way which I am sure will enhance the consultative mechanisms which we have. Of course, all Cabinet Ministers, including the previous Minister for Social Security, participated in those decisions.

ANSWER.PARA: There is nothing at all unusual in the point raised by the honourable senator. We believe that in most of these areas more effective consultation will be produced by a finer mechanism. I will seek for the honourable senator the answer to the last part of his question with respect to where precisely the responsibilities for that form of research will lie in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that Senator Chaney in his answer said that he too took part in this deliberation, I now ask: Is it the Government's decision that rural research is of no importance at all to Australia's primary producers?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer to the eligibility of the Loxton District Nursing Home to receive capital and recurrent grants under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act. Has the Minister sought legal advice on this matter? If so, is it now clear which particular aspects of the Loxton case may lead to difficulty? Is the Loxton application an isolated case in this respect? In the event of the eligibility of the Loxton District Nursing Home being confirmed, will priority be given to its application as from the date of the application being first received?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain that I have all the information requested by the honourable senator. I understand that the Loxton District Nursing Home is a 31-bed home approved under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act and that it has applied for an additional 12 beds and for approval to operate a day care centre. The current policy applied to approvals under deficit financing arrangements authorised by the Nursing Homes Assistance Act is that organisations which are subject to control or financial support from a State government should not be approved for deficit funding. I think this is the centre of the issue which comes up in relation to the Loxton District Nursing Home. Honourable senators will appreciate that this policy is necessary to ensure that the States do not use Commonwealth provisions for deficit financing under this Act as a means of transferring their traditional financial responsibilities, with the Commonwealth then meeting the total operating deficit. This policy can be relevant in the case of the boards of cost-shared recognised hospitals which also conduct nursing home operations.

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed by the Minister for Health that the application of this policy currently is under review in the context of the Government's revised health care financing arrangements. The honourable senator will appreciate that there is some cross-over between the areas. This review will necessarily involve consideration of the continued eligibility for deficit funding of organisations already approved. Consideration of the Commonwealth's legal position will be incorporated within the review. I can assure the honourable senator that the Commonwealth's review of this matter will take into account total application of the relevant policy. In this context the Loxton District Nursing Home is not an isolated case but one of a number of cases which will be encompassed in the review. As I said earlier, a general issue of principle is involved.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WOOL TESTING AUTHORITY: PROPOSED SALE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, follows a question asked by Senator Tate. I ask the Minister whether he sticks by his answer that the reason the Government has decided to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority is to demonstrate the political differences between the major political parties. That is what he said. There is no point in the Minister's shaking his head; it is what he said. Does the same philosophical justification apply to other decisions of the razor gang? Are there other criteria such as the potential for increased efficiency or better service to the industry in respect of which the Minister is able to give a more detailed answer in support of the decision to sell the Wool Testing Authority?

—I think the Opposition should take a great interest in the program of aids for the disabled because some honourable senators on that side of the chamber seem to have hearing troubles. I will be very happy to examine the Hansard record, but the suggestion by the Leader of the Opposition in his question was that I said that the reason given for the sale was to demonstrate the differences between the Government and the Opposition. In fact I was challenged in the supplementary question on my suggestion that there was a side benefit of the decision in that it also had the effect of demonstrating the difference between the Government and the Opposition. I did not put that forward as the primary reason for the sale, and the question is therefore based on a total misunderstanding of what I said.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. I have noted with concern that the price of tin has fallen sharply over the last six months and that it is now at its lowest level for several years. As the Minister will be aware, Tasmania accounts for some 60 per cent of Australia's tin mine output. In view of the importance of the tin mining industry in Tasmania, and on the west coast in particular, I ask: What is the reason for this fall in price? What can be done about it?
—Get somebody to talk the shares up and you will be right.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ribaldry of members of the Australian Labor Party on this question indicates that they fail to realise the significance of the tin industry to Tasmania, particularly northern Tasmania, and the significance of it to Australia. It is true that there has been a recent fall in the price of tin. As I understand it, it is due largely to reduced demand resulting from lower levels of economic activity in industrialised countries and a running down of stocks by users because of the prevailing high interest rates. The ability of users to purchase tin surplus to United States strategic stockpile requirements is no doubt also a factor. The honourable senator will be aware that the effects of Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries oil prices over the past years have reduced very severely the ability of nations to trade other than by paying high prices for oil.

ANSWER.PARA: The price of tin seems likely to remain weak, in view of the lower demand and the ready availability of supplies in the absence of agreement by consumer countries in the International Tin Council to increase the price range which determines the operation of the tin buffer stock. That price range was last varied, I understand, in March last year. Australia and other producers argued strongly for an increase this year-I think about a month ago-in the April session of the International Tin Council. However, no increase could be obtained in the face of concerted opposition by consumer countries. A major effort is being made by producing countries to redress this situation at the next Council session in July. Because of the very particular significance of tin to Tasmania, I will bring the substance of the question to the attention of my colleague the Minister for Trade and Resources and ask him whether anything further can be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce a question concerning the massive advertising campaign being run by the Government called 'Not right now' which is conducted against the shorter working week.
—Two million dollars.

—The campaign calls upon Australians to oppose the shorter working week. In view of the incredible expense involved in mounting the campaign, I ask the Minister: Who authorised it? Was it a Cabinet decision? How long will the campaign run? Is it planned to extend the campaign to television? Which advertising agencies are involved? What is the total cost of the venture? I understand that the Minister may not have those detailed answers at his fingertips, but I wonder whether he could get them. The second part of the question is one which the Minister would be able to answer straight away. He would know that the recent gallup poll to which the advertisement referred showed that 33 per cent of Australians said, 'Yes, reduce gradually to 35 hours' and that nine per cent of Australians said, 'Reduce immediately to 35 hours'. That would seem to show that a total of 42 per cent of Australians would want to move to a 35-hour week in the foreseeable future. In view of that fact, does the Minister not concede that this advertisement is sneaky, misleading and bordering closely on being dishonest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should give my initial answer to the last part of the honourable senator's question and say, no, I certainly reject that suggestion about the advertisement. With respect to the detailed list of questions that the honourable senator has asked, he quite correctly predicted that I would not have all of that detail at my fingertips; I do not. I can tell him that at this stage there is no proposal that there should be television advertising on this subject. I can say that the figures that were being shouted by way of interjection from the Opposition are way out of line with the actual costs of the campaign, but I will obtain a precise figure for the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the recent gallup poll to which Senator Chipp referred in his question, I think it will be found on examination that the advertisments relate to an earlier poll taken on this matter. The gallup poll which was published in the last week or so is a subsequent poll on the same subject--

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to the poll of 26 March.

—I am sorry. The honourable senator was referring to the earlier poll. I thought that he might be referring to the poll which was published in the last week or so on the same subject matter; but, in any event, a very substantial majority of the Australian population-on the figures given by Senator Chipp, all but 9 per cent-believe that either we should not have a reduction of working hours or we should have a reduction on a gradual basis only. If one looks at the theme of those advertisements, which is 'Not right now', one sees that it is consistent with the thinking of the vast majority of Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: One might ask why it is necessary to advertise to the general public; but I think it will be broadly understood that decisions on working hours, although often made by arbitral tribunals, are also often made as a result of trade union action. The weight of trade union opinion is of particular relevance in this area and in light of the view of the great majority of Australians-that we should not be rushing into a shortening of working hours in this country, given the importance of maintaining our competitive position, of maintaining employment and of maintaining the improvements in employment which are so apparent at the moment-we have a public duty to put before the public the arguments in favour of maintaining the general system of working hours that we have in this country at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer and wish to ask a supplementary question. As the Government is so certain that a mere handful of Australians-only 9 per cent-do not want a shorter working week now, why must it spend such massive amounts of public funds in persuading such a minority?

—That is a quite reasonable question. I think one will find, from various polls that are available, that public opinion does shift in these matters, and indeed some shifts will be found even within the two that have been mentioned this morning. It is of importance that we should maintain within the Australian community a continuing attitude of general opposition to measures which we believe will be damaging to that community. The fact is that there is a real and proper concern in the community about levels of employment. The fact is that levels of employment in this country have been increasing steadily. We have been disappointed with the failure of the unemployment rate to drop in the way that one might have expected, given those increases in employment levels. I would have hoped that all honourable senators would be delighted at the very real reduction in unemployment evident in the most recently released figures. I notice that there has been a remarkable shortage of comment on those figures from honourable senators opposite, and, of course, they have not chosen to provide an opportunity for Government senators to make many speeches on that subject. I would have thought that most Australians would be delighted that in the recent figures a real reduction in unemployment rates was evident. The Government believes that it must continue to pursue economic policies which will ensure continued economic improvement in this country.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATION OF POPE JOHN PAUL II

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II today. Does the Government regard with alarm the increase in this form of senseless and tragic demonstration? Is the Leader of the Government confident that suitable security can be afforded delegates to the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all honourable senators are aware of the tragic report this morning of the wounding of Pope John Paul II in St Peter's Square in Rome. I should add, for the information of honourable senators, that the Prime Minister has sent a message to the Pope in the following terms:

ANSWER.PARA: I was deeply shocked and distressed to hear of the attempt on your life. The Government and people of Australia join with me in wishing you a full and speedy recovery. My Government deeply deplores such acts of violence which Your Holiness has strongly condemned.
I think His Holiness the Pope, in his actions and in his world-wide travels since he attained that high office, has caught the imagination of the great majority of people of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly feminists.
—I would have thought that on a subject as serious as this the interjections of the Labor Party might have been forgone.
—Holier than thou.
—You are inviting interjections, the way you are carrying on.
—Please cease interjecting at this serious moment.
—It is suggested that in making a comment upon one of the most tragic--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister is using this question for political propaganda purposes. I suggest that he stick to the basic question that was asked. It was asked in a dignified way and there should be a dignified reply to it.

—Mr President, that is not my point of order. I have another one to raise. The matter is of serious concern to the whole of the Senate and I would have thought the Leader of the Government, instead of responding to a question, would have made a statement which would have allowed the Opposition to respond in a suitable way. As it is, the question has been thrown into the place and the very method of answering has invited interjections from this side. I think that the Leader of the Government ought to have made a statement at the commencement of business and not responded to a question.
—I shall ask Senator Carrick to continue. Honourable senators, please cease interjecting.

—Because of the nature and seriousness of the incident, my remarks have been totally restrained and, I believe, quite unobjectionable to the whole of the Australian community. I have said that the community deplores the action and I have read the text of the Prime Minister's message. I would have thought there could have been no objection. I was going on to say, when there were interjections, that I believe the actions of His Holiness the Pope from the time he assumed that high office-his very wide travelling throughout the world, the leadership he has given, his remarkable courage and fortitude, his great integrity and his upholding of principles-would have caught the imagination, the respect and, indeed, the affection of all people of goodwill, whatever their religious beliefs. Against that background we deplore what has happened, as we deplore all violence. It is undoubtedly part of the general violence we are seeing throughout the world. It is part of the ugliness of the world scene today where democracy apparently cannot proceed and where people cannot move with freedom of speech without the threat of violence. The Government intends to ensure the maximum of security in the movements and visits of leaders and heads of state in this country. But there is a message in all of this. It is a very ugly message. It shows that man, whatever else he has achieved in his clever ways, has not been able to overcome human conflict. We are seeing human conflict in all its ugliness today.

—by leave-I indicate on behalf of the Opposition that we concur with what was effectively a statement given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) in answer to a question. I want that to be quite clear.
—by leave-I accept Senator Button's statement with total goodwill.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Communications confirm that the Australian Broadcasting Commission in the Northern Territory has been granted autonomy and full State branch status? Recognising that smaller units require much of the same infrastructure as larger units and must have appropriate funding to be effective, will the Minister assure the chamber that sufficient funds will be made available to enable the ABC branch in the Northern Territory to set itself up initially and then to provide the same range of services as is provided in the States? Will the Minister assure the chamber that the Northern Territory stations, particularly the television channels, will not become simply relay stations for southern programs?

—Although the honourable senator's question started with a question about autonomy, it really is a question about resources and funding for the Australian Broadcasting Commission in the Northern Territory.
—Now that it is autonomous.

—Yes. The honourable senator went on to ask about funding needs and resource requirements. I think this is properly a question for the Minister who is responsible for the portfolio. Some of these questions might have to be answered in a Budget context. I will pass these questions on to the Minister and seek a response.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to a question I asked of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick, on 29 April when he was representing the Minister for Transport in the absence from the Senate of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I remind the Minister that at that time Senator Carrick said that he would refer my question to the Minister for Transport and seek a reply. I have not yet received a reply. So I now ask whether I and the Senate can be told why it was that during the air hostesses dispute international airlines were not given the same right to carry within Australia those people connecting with international flights as was given to Qantas Airways Ltd. Has the Minister ascertained whether approaches were made to Qantas by other international airlines, as those airlines were directed by the Government to do, and whether those approaches were not acknowledged, replied to or acted upon? Can he tell the Senate why the Government did not give those airlines the same access to passengers directly from Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia, instead of those airlines having to wait for Qantas's overflow?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following information which I think answers substantially the points Senator Martin has just outlined: A number of international airlines had been in touch with the Department of Transport since the beginning of the flight attendants strike, indicating that they had vacant seats over domestic sectors should the Government approve carriage of domestic passengers by international operators. When the strike began before Easter, approval was given for the carriage by international carriers of the following classes of persons: Compassionate cases, Federal parliamentarians and other VIPs and people booked with the two domestic operators for trips connecting to or from international services. Priority was given to Qantas carriage. When the domestics returned to operations on Easter Thursday, approval was given for the carriage of domestic passengers on international services to cope with the first legs of the Easter rush, again with priority for Qantas. Return carriage was by the domestics.

ANSWER.PARA: When the strike was resumed after Easter the same initial approval for compassionate cases, Federal parliamentarians, VIPs and others in the course of international journeys was again given. When it became clear that the strike was not going to be settled quickly, the Government decided on 24 April to allow Qantas to carry domestic passengers suffering hardship. This included passengers stranded away from home, particularly at a great distance, and others with compelling reasons to travel. On 27 April the Minister for Transport announced a request to all international operators to carry other domestic passengers. This action was taken only when the protracted nature of the strike became clear. It is unlikely that Qantas being given priority for the carriage of people in the course of international journeys in Australia would have led to Qantas gaining an advantage over other international carriers on international legs. The great bulk of these bookings would have been made prior to the strike with international operators of the passengers' choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister, in his reply, referred several times to the fact that priority was given to Qantas. In my question on 28 April and again today I asked: Why was priority given to Qantas? Why was Qantas given that advantage over other carriers?
—I will refer that further question to the Minister.

—Was the Minister for Social Security accurately reported in the Canberra Times this week as having said in his address to the pensioners conference that pensioners have an advantage over wage and salary earners through indexation? If he was correctly reported as having said this, can he explain to the Senate why he said it, seeing that pensioners have in fact only a form of delayed indexation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see a report in the Canberra Times. I did not look particularly closely to see whether it was absolutely accurate in the literal sense. In that speech I certainly did make a reference of the sort that the honourable senator has suggested. I referred to indexation and the fact that the Government introduced twice-yearly indexation of age pension rates in line with the consumer price index. I referred to the fact that the latest increase took effect last week, taking the single rate of pension to $66.65. I went on:

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is worth mentioning in relation to this point that by this system pensioners have in recent years been fully protected against the effect of inflation in a way that wage and salary earners and other taxpayers have not.

I was referring to the fact that arbitration decisions with respect to wages have often been on a discounted basis, and to the fact that there has been less than full tax indexation over much of that period. I was referring to the fact that full indexation of pensions has occurred over that period, while full indexation of wages and salaries and full indexation of taxation downward have not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister agree that, insofar as the indexation of pensions is slower than the indexation of wages and salaries, pensioners are at a disadvantage compared with wage and salary earners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. I overlooked that part of the honourable senator's question. I would not agree that that is an accurate summary of the position. The fact is that when the indexation of pensions was introduced the basis of the indexation was that the May adjustment would be made in line with the rise in the CPI for the half year to the December quarter and the November adjustment would be made in line with the CPI increase for the half year to the April quarter. Although that means a delay, it, in fact, means that in a period of declining inflation the actual adjustments at any particular time are likely to be in excess of an adjustment in line with the increase in the nearest quarter. Of course, in a period of rising inflation the reverse would be true. It is a matter of which measure one chooses to take. Those choices have been made because there is some delay in receiving the figures and because there is a need to have some time for the processing of changes.

ANSWER.PARA: To take a very simple example-I do this merely to illustrate the point I am making-if the inflation rate in, say, the September quarter were 4 per cent, in the December quarter, 3 per cent, and in the April quarter, 2 per cent, and if one made the adjustment in May on the basis of the most recent figures one would have an adjustment of 5 per cent; whereas if one made the adjustment on the basis of the December figures one would have an adjustment of 7 per cent. So whether there is a benefit or a detriment to pensioners in choosing the basis of adjustment really depends upon whether there is a rising or declining rate of inflation. Of course, under the present Government in the main there has been a declining rate of inflation, for which we are duly thankful, our policies having worked to an extent towards that objective. Therefore, there has not been a detriment to pensioners in the system that has been brought in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security: Is it a fact that persons receiving invalid pensions are permitted to leave Australia, to take up permanent residence in an overseas country and to continue to receive benefits without undergoing the regular medical reassessment of their eligibility to which Australian resident pensioners are liable? If so, has the Government considered taking steps to ensure that pensioners living overseas are not maintained on benefits after their eligibility has expired due to improved health?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that in general there is portability of pensions and benefits in this country. That applies to invalid pensions, as to other pensions. That means that a person qualifying for the pension in Australia is free to leave, to live elsewhere and to continue to receive the pension. At times this can mean that he or she is receiving a lesser entitlement because, with respect to fringe benefits, for example, it is unlikely that any benefit will apply. So there may, in fact, be a smaller financial obligation upon the Commonwealth Government in that situation.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator in her question raised the difficulty of ensuring that the conditions for eligibility continue to be met. That, of course, is a matter that does have to be addressed. In fact, the eligibility conditions continue to be the same. Various steps are taken to check eligibility, as steps are taken in Australia. I cannot give the honourable senator the full detail in response to the question, but I can assure her that steps are taken to ensure that persons resident overseas do continue to have eligibility. I would not say, however, that we have a perfect system by any means.

We have before us the prospect of discusssions with various countries about reciprocal social service agreements. There has been a number of discussions to date and there will be further discussions in the future. I think an important element in those discussions will be the need to gain the co-operation of other countries in the maintenance of pensions payable to Australian pensioners overseas. This is an area where I would expect to see useful developments over the coming years. I cannot pretend that we could fix up overnight all of the problems there might be.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security will recall that when the family allowance scheme was introduced by the Government in 1976 the Government described it as the greatest thing since lace-up boots, or words to that effect. Is the Minister aware that because of the ravages of inflation the value of the family allowance for a mother of four children has deteriorated by $657.60 per annum and that, by comparison with the old child endowment and tax rebate scheme, which was discredited and described by the Government and all concerned as being totally inadequate, under the current scheme a person with four children is now $352 per annum worse off? If the Minister is not aware of those particular facts, why is he not aware of them? If he is aware of them, why has the Government not done something about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I am aware of the broad facts stated by the honourable senator and of the introduction of the family allowance in 1976, a change which certainly was regarded by the Government and spoken of by the Government as a major social reform. I would certainly so describe it myself. Before the major change that was effected in 1976-a change that I am sure Senator Harradine approved of-a substantial number of Australian families who did not benefit from tax deductions because they had very low incomes or no taxable income were left out of a substantial element of the assistance available to families to that time. They did receive the very low child endowment payment, but because they did not have a taxable income they did not receive the benefit of the tax deduction. One of the major effects of the 1976 change was to bring 300,000 low income families into the system in a full way, and that benefited some 800,000 Australian children in Australia's neediest families. So, the major element of that reform is the qualification that I would put on the sort of statistics that the honourable senator referred to in his question.

ANSWER.PARA: It is certainly true that because the family allowance has not been adjusted since 1976 there has been a decline in the real value of that allowance over that period. That is quite clear. I would, of course, not be arguing with that proposition contained in the honourable senator's question. As to those families who are at the poorest end of the spectrum in Australia, I think the generalisations made by the honourable senator in his question would not be true. It is true that even those poor families have suffered a loss in value. It would not be true, I think, that the level of assistance to them is less than it was prior to the introduction of this reform, when they were omitted from a large proportion of the help that was generally available to families.

The Government agrees that the position of families in Australia does need attention. Reference to that will be found in the Speech of the Governor-General when he opened this Parliament. I have indicated that the Government has under consideration the best means to extend assistance to families. A wide range of options is available to us, and those matters are under consideration. All honourable senators would be aware that I am not in a position to predict what might be in the Budget later this year. The Government has clearly indicated a commitment to families, and that commitment is one that we have under close examination at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. It arises from a statement reported to have been made by Dr Robert Endean, of the Queensland University, that the taking of predator fish by spear fishermen has left 500 kilometres of the Great Barrier Reef open to attack by the crown of thorns starfish. Has government research thrown any light on the cause and effect of crown of thorns infestations, and in particular whether the starfish continues to pose a serious threat to the reef? What restrictions are placed on fishing and other human activities by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act to protect the reef from damage by the crown of thorns starfish?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the statement reported to have been made by Dr Endean. The honourable senator will be aware that the Queensland Fisheries Service and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority undertook surveys of the crown of thorns infestation last year on reefs between Innisfail and Cooktown. Research to date has found no one cause, such as spear fishing, to which crown of thorns infestations can be attributed. Rather it is a multitude of causes that is more likely to be involved. Further investigations being developed by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority include a detailed historical study of previous crown of thorns populations and their relationships, if any, to human use of the reef. I think that is the key element.

ANSWER.PARA: The Authority is concerned about the recent apparent increase in crown of thorns starfish populations. But it must be added that, despite years of considerable research, there is still no hard evidence to support the suggestion that large crown of thorns populations are the consequence of human activity on or near the Great Barrier Reef. The Authority will continue to monitor the crown of thorns situation and to support appropriate research programs into the key question of causes and possible controls. In view of experience with the starfish since 1960, we do not expect quick answers.

I conclude by saying that the object of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act is to make provision for and in relation to the establishment, control, care and development of a marine park in the Great Barrier Reef region. Zoning plans for sections of the marine park established under the Act may make provision for the regulation of activities, including fishing of course, in those areas.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF HOME AFFAIRS AND ENVIRONMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it a fact that a considerable part of the work of the environmental division of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment has been devoted, firstly, to assessing environmental impact statements for proposed uranium mines such as Jabiluka and, secondly, to providing Commonwealth leadership in setting up codes of practice for the uranium industry Australia-wide? Is the division to be reduced in size as a result of the razor gang decision to let the States control nuclear activities? Does the Minister agree on the need for an expert national body analogous to the National Health and Medical Research Council which could set nuclear standards?

—I understand that considerable work has been done on the examination of environmental impact studies in relation to uranium projects. I am sure that the honourable senator would be concerned, as would everyone else, to see that that work was properly carried out, that the environmental impact studies were properly assessed and that they were regarded as important. I am unable to tell the honourable senator whether the environmental division has been heavily involved in this activity. The honourable senator asked whether much of its work was devoted to that activity and setting up codes of practice. I know the activities do go on. The honourable senator asked whether I agreed with a proposition in relation to a desirable structure. I think that is properly a matter for the Minister I represent, and I will seek an answer from him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button raised with me again today the question of a difference between a table in the report of the National Energy Advisory Committee and tables that were published in an attachment to a Press statement of mine. ANSWER.PARA: I refer to Mr Malone's article in the 'National Times' of 12-18 April 1981 commenting on the Report of the National Energy Advisory Committee . . . on 'Alternative Liquid Fuels'. TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April Senator Watson asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry concerning the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory. I undertook to seek further information on the necessity to introduce certain dangerous viruses, such as foot and mouth disease, into this laboratory in view of synthetic viruses which are now available. I have been advised by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) that no synthetic viruses are available. Senator Watson may be referring to recent genetic engineering research on foot and mouth vaccines using bacteria. This does not negate the necessity to handle foot and mouth disease and other exotic viruses in the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory. It will be vital to have access to these viruses for the development of diagnostic capability, research, training and quality control testing of vaccines.

—Last night Senator Colston raised the question of delays with respect to the processing of invalid pension applications. I undertook to check the position, although I had relatively recent information at that time. This morning I was advised that an additional medical practitioner started work on Monday, 11 May, in Queensland and is engaged specifically in matters related to those raised by the honourable senator. In other words, there will now be two senior medical officers available, instead of one, to process these applications.

-by leave-I wish to make a statement in relation to imputations made in the question asked by Senator Reid. Some weeks ago a man approached me at the request of a very highly regarded member of the State Parliament in New South Wales, Mr Maher. The gentleman's son, who was in his physical prime, was killed in an accident in the Australian Capital Territory. If I were a hypocrite I would have listened to this gentleman and then forgotten all about the matter. I exercised my right as a senator to question the wheels of justice in the Australian Capital Territory, and I will continue to do that. I refer to the alleged chastisement in the Canberra Times a few days ago. I went to one of my legal betters, Mr Maher, who said: 'Sleep well. They deliberately avoid the thrust of your criticism'. I can live with my conscience. I hope that the magistrate can live with his. I make an offer to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) because I respect him as a man. I hold a commission as a justice of the peace, as do other New South Wales senators. If it will help that magistrate, I will be happy to sit as an assessor on a bench with him and see how he operates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In so doing I draw to the attention of the Senate that this is another demonstration of those characteristics of indolence and insincerity which have become so much a part of the way of life of this Government. The average time for the non-appearance of a response to these reports, if one does one's arithmetic quickly, is 17 months. In respect of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on broadcasting, the time involved is nine months. In respect of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, the delay is nine months. The delay in the Government's response to a series of reports from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has been 14 months, 19 months, 27 months, 18 months, 15 months and 12 months respectively. The delay we have experienced in getting a Government response on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence-the response still has not turned up-is 18 months. The delay on a response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources is eight months. The delay on a response to the Joint Committee of Publications is 20 months. Responses have been outstanding on two reports from the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances for 23 months and 18 months respectively. The response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment has been outstanding for 23 months.

On my calculations the average delay is over 17 months. I do not think we ought ever to forget the undertaking on the part of the Executive in this respect. I remind you, Mr President, and your colleagues of what was said on 26 May 1978 by Senator Withers, the then Leader of the Government in the Senate, expressly on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) who made a similar statement in the other House. This is what was said:

Henceforth, within six months of the tabling of a committee report, the responsible Minister will make a statement in the Parliament outlining the action the Government proposes to take in relation to the report. If the six month period expires during a parliamentary recess, the ministerial statement will be made at the earliest opportunity in the next parliamentary sittings.
Senator Withers went on to say:

The procedure I have outlined reflects the Government's firm intention to see that the excellent work of parliamentary committees does not pass unheeded. We need to use to the full the talents and resources available in the House of Representatives and the Senate. One important way in which this can be achieved is the further development and enhancement of the parliamentary committees, . . .

Those words must be tasting pretty bitter in the Governnent's mouth now because this is yet another demonstration of its absolute incapacity and unwillingness to honour that very clear and unequivocal statement made to the Senate. It is an absolutely unequivocal demonstration of just how much contempt the executive branch, of this Government in particular, manifestly has for parliamentary committees. It is another ample demonstration, as I said, of that combination of laziness and hypocrisy which has characterised so many features of this Government's term in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not unduly take up the time of the Senate over this matter although I believe it is a matter of considerable importance. I want to speak particularly in relation to the report of the Committee of which I am honoured to be a member, the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. The report of that Committee on industrial research and development in Australia was the first with which I was closely associated. I am aware of the tremendous effort that was put into it not only by the members of the Committee but also by the people who gave evidence before the Committee, people throughout the community whom we would expect to have a consensus of opinion on this important subject. As a member of the Committee, I believe I have a responsibility to them to see that what they did was not wasted in terms of the time taken to bring down that report. I must reiterate that the area of industrial research and development is one of fast changing technology. It is an area which demands urgent attention. The report of the Committee has now been with the Government for a response for almost two years. I ought to make one point plain on behalf of the Australian Democrats: If the Government proposes to treat the committee system of the Senate in this way in future the Democrats will seriously question the value of our participation in the committee system at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
