DEBATE.TITLE: NORTH WEST CAPE NAVAL COMMUNICATIONS STATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The paper entitled 'Science and Technology Statement 1980-81' purports to be a statement on the Commonwealth Government sector in science and technology. It is a very comprehensive statement insofar as it embraces a number of departments and government activities. The statement is accompanied by two Press releases from the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) to which I will refer shortly. The Minister quite rightly reminded us that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development pointed out that in future science and technology policy must be taken together with economic and social policy. That is a statement with which the Opposition profoundly agrees. What one must question in the light of a statement like this is whether the Fraser Government is in fact taking science and technology policy together with economic and social policy.

In the Opposition's view there is a major deficiency in tying industry policy to science policy. The Opposition agrees very much with the view that there is insufficient private industry research in Australia. All the figures point to that conclusion. That was pointed out by the OECD in its 1975 report, some six years ago, on Australian science and technology and it was also pointed out by Project Score. The OECD, in its 1976 survey, which I think is the latest comparative survey available, showed that the percentage of gross expenditure on research and development performed by business enterprise was, for example, in Australia, 41 per cent; France, 59 per cent; Germany, 64 per cent; the Netherlands, 58 per cent; Norway, 59 per cent and Sweden, 67 per cent. Expenditure in all those countries was substantially ahead of Australia. I refer to three other countries by way of example. Gross expenditure in Portugal was 27 per cent; New Zealand, 24 per cent; and Canada, 36 per cent. If one looks at those figures one notes that the countries with advanced sophisticated industries, including small countries like Holland, Switzerland, Sweden, Norway and so on, far exceeded Australia in the volume of private or non-government research and development in industry. It is only over industrially under developed countries like Portugal, New Zealand and Canada that Australia has a better performance, comparatively speaking, in the level of research and development done in private industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you include Canada in that category?
—Yes, I would.
—Industrially under- developed?

—Yes, Senator. I would make the same observation about Australia. I think the problem is that for cultural, political and standard of life reasons Canada and Australia tend to see themselves as developed countries, but I argue that in terms of a number of economic matters they are underdeveloped countries and the figures of expenditure on research and development are an indicator of that underdevelopment.

SPEECH.PARA: The lesson I point to from these comparative figures is that there is a need for a proper industry policy in Australia as a prerequisite to business spending on research and development. There is also a need for a proper policy on technology transfer, a matter to which I have referred recently on a number of occasions in this House and particularly with reference to countries like Korea and Norway which have, compared with Australia, sophisticated policies of technology transfer. I argue-I hope in not too partisan a way-that the present Government has not a proper industry policy despite the recommendations of the report of the Jackson Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry, the report of the Crawford Study Group on Structural Adjustment and all the various other reports which have been commissioned by the Government and from which little results have flowed. One notes that according to the report of the Cabinet Review of Commonwealth Functions, the so-called razor gang, the Government is probably cutting out the industry committees with which it should be developing policies for industry, policies which would at least indirectly lead to greater capacity and interest in research and development in private industry.

The Minister's Press statement which has been issued with the science and technology statement calls for Australian private industry to more than double its spending on research and development in this decade. I am reminded-if I may venture a classical allusion in the presence of Senator Puplick-of a claim by Glendower to Hotspur in Henry IV. He claimed that he could summon spirits from the vasty deep. Hotspur replied: 'Yes, of course, but will they come?' The Minister for Science and Technology is in much the same category in exhorting private industry to spend more on research and development. He is just leaving it at that. It is not sufficient merely to do so. That is a piece of empty rhetoric. One has to examine industry policies to see whence the encouragement for greater research and development by industry can come.

One's attitude to research and development in private industry should in my view be very much dictated by our attitudes to such factors as the resources boom. Industry policy in relation to the resources boom involves, in the view of the Opposition, the necessity to put some of the revenue gained from such a boom back into new industry in the manufacturing sector which will create permanent jobs and a permanent wealth generating capacity for this country. That in turn will depend on the level of research and development in which private industry is prepared to engage. The argument about research and development in the private sector is an argument about opportunities which we would argue exist. We say that the present Government is neglecting those opportunities by ignoring the education base for research and development. Australia has a contracting rather than an expanding education base in terms of research. That is a bad thing for the long term future of this country. The actions which have been taken recently, to which I have referred, again indicate a short-sighted approach to the issues of research and development spending in private industry, and particularly technology transfer.

It is that second matter of technology transfer to which I shall now refer briefly. I argue that there is a very real need for Australia to examine, for example, some of its patent laws and its trade practices legislation in relation to this matter. We can look advisedly to the experiences, as I have said before, of countries such as Norway and Korea in terms of their policies on technology transfer, both of which involve a slightly stronger stance by government insofar as the terms under which multinational or foreign capital is brought into those countries. Multinational capital is attracted to Korea, but on certain conditions. The conditions are that the results of basic research are made available to the Koreans who specialise in the area of applied research. In Norway the stricture has been that foreign capital in the oil industry is very welcome provided that Norway provides the technology and the infrastructure. The result of that will be the development of a net export industry in some 12 years time, when Norway will be able to export oil industry technology, at great benefit to Norwegian companies and to the Norwegian economy. Australia does not take that stance with the importation of foreign capital. No conditions are applied in those terms. We have a very subservient derivative economy in terms of our examination of the conditions under which foreign capital can come to this country. We make very few requirements. That may be good in the short term but it is not good for the long term future of this country.

In dealing with the question of technology transfer I again make the point that it is significant that Canada and New Zealand are below us in the level of private research and development because they share the same problems. They have a very high proportion of overseas ownership of their industries. They are great raw material suppliers-or have been-and they are great agricultural commodity suppliers. But they share exactly the same problems in their manufacturing industries. Their industries are dominated by multinational or foreign capital. In that context very little research is done in Canada by private industry. Industry there says: 'Why do we need to do this? We can borrow it from overseas'. That is a nice short term solution-a soft option-but it is not a long term answer to a country's economic and developmental problems. Canada, New Zealand and Australia fall into the category of underdeveloped countries in that they lack the capacity to do their own thing in technology transfer and research and development. That is because of the subservience to foreign capital on much the same basis as I argued before. The real challenge is not to export business; it is to create policies which change us from the Canadian, New Zealand and Australian situation to one which is more comparative with the relatively highly successful economies of countries such as Norway, Sweden, Holland and Switzerland. It is not sufficient to give lip service to that. It is desirable that policies be developed.

We argue that in respect of these issues the Government is pulling in a variety of directions. There is no coherent leadership or policy in relation to these issues. In 1976, for example, the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, launched the Department of Productivity. He lauded the creation of the Department as something which would do great things for Australian industry and development. In fact, in answer to a question in the House he made the comment that it was a department which would be concerned with long term problems, not short term solutions. 'These problems will not go away', he said. I could not agree more. However, the Department of Productivity and its functions went away in 1980; it was abolished. Its remaining functions virtually went away at the behest of the razor gang.

However, as the Prime Minister rightly pointed out, the problems will not go away. It is a short-sighted, silly, short term and expedient solution to cut back on programs as the razor gang has done, for example, in relation to industrial management, productivity promotion and so on. I refer the Senate to page 33 of the razor gang's report, at which the Government's decisions on science and technology are set out. Far from displaying a serious and long term concern such as the Prime Minister did in 1976 about policies in this area, the razor gang's report provides a classic example of short term decision making. Moreover, in the first draft of the report, as it was released to members of the Parliament, a passage on that page was blacked out. It was reported that the razor gang had intended to cut a particular function, by way of government decision, but the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) threatened to kick up a tremendous fuss if pilot programs for innovation in industry were deleted. Thus, that proposal was blacked out of the report.

That is an example of decision making of a most bizarre kind. It is like bringing out a newspaper such as the News of the World to report the latest murder-although in this case it was not the normal kind of razor gang. To make such a decision about an important matter and have it changed at the last minute demonstates the degree of thought and consideration given by this Government to matters of long term policy. It is an example of the sort of policy making on the run that we do not want if these issues are to be addressed seriously in Australia. They may not seem terribly important at the moment but they are vitally important to generations of young children, to those as yet unborn, and to the lifestyle that they will have in Australia in years to come.

After 5 1/2 years of deliberation and numerous reports by the Australian Science and Technology Council and other scientific bodies, the Government is still making eleventh-hour decisions about science and technology in Australia. We are not in a position to make and afford eleventh-hour decisions. Press statements such as that of the Minister for Science and Technology in support of this science and technology statement are merely superficial and do not address the real problem. In 1976 it was arguable that, at least philosophically, this Government was on the right track in relation to science and technology policy-even if only on the basis of its recognition, in the words of the Prime Minister, of the fact that these were long term issues involving the future of Australia. As we have said on numerous occasions the razor gang has provided a classic example of the taking of short-sighted, short term initiatives, of decisions made on the run and changed even in the printing process. That is not the way to attain good government in this country, government which will benefit future generations and Australian industry.

We again sound these warnings. No doubt they will fall on deaf ears but at least in years to come we can have the satisfaction of reading Hansard and of thinking that we were probably right. Accordingly, I commend the reading of this report on science and technology to the Senate and hope that more serious account will be taken of some of the issues raised in it than has so far been apparent on the part of the Government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MARINE SCIENCES AND TECHNOLOGIES RESEARCH GRANTS SCHEME

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish briefly to refer to an answer that was given to a question today concerning the starfish problem of the Great Barrier Reef. As Senator Button has said, much of what is uttered in this place falls on deaf ears. I recall debates taking place in the Senate on the control of the starfish problem of the Great Barrier Reef and requests being made of the Government to display more interest in it and to accord it a higher priority. Although I have not read the Marine Sciences and Technologies Research Grants Scheme report, I take it that the amount of money available for research has been increased. The answer that Senator Baume gave this morning, after all these years, showed no understanding of the problem. If, after that passage of time, we have not appreciated the desperate situation faced by the reef it is a very sad state of affairs indeed. I have moved that the Senate take note of the paper so that it will be placed on the Notice Paper. We can then debate whether the amounts made available for research into this problem of the Great Barrier Reef are suitable. I know that Senator Bonner would be interested in such a debate, as should all Australians and particularly Queenslanders. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
The paper makes a correction to the annual report of the Australian Heritage Commission for 1979-80. I do not want to place this matter on the Notice Paper. However, the paper states:
The statement on page 2 left-hand column ''During the year the Government determined a ten year moratorium on oil drilling . . .''. should be replaced with:

'During the year the Minister for Science and the Environment the Hon. David Thomson, M.C., M.P., reaffirmed the Government's commitment to protection of the Great Barrier Reef from damage caused by human activity. He referred to the Prime Minister's statement of June 1979 when Mr Fraser announced that there should be no further exploration for petroleum in the Great Barrier Reef Region and that there should be no renewal of pertroleum exploration permits in the Region until the results of both short and longer term research were known. In the same month the Prime Minister and Premier of Queensland confirmed that it was the policy of their respective Governments to prohibit any drilling on the Reef, or any drilling or mining which could damage the Reef.'

That is a very important statement. The statement should have been included in the report, as the correction states. We are almost at the end of another financial year, with another report almost due, and the Senate is advised of a correction-and it is a substantial correction. I would like some explanation from the Commission as to why it took so long to bring this important correction before the Senate. For a correction to reach us almost at the end of May in the year following the annual report seems to indicate that something is wrong with the administration and organisation of the Australian Heritage Commission. I hope that criticism is taken note of. It is a criticism which is not alone in the Senate with regard to the lateness of reports. But this is astounding. I cannot understand why we should suddenly have a piece of paper notifying a very important correction 11 months after the event. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH LEGAL AID COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission Act 1977.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the replacement of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission by a Commonwealth Legal Aid Council. For convenience I shall refer to these bodies as 'the Commission' and 'the Council', respectively. The Bill gives effect to a decision of the Government which was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) following the recent Review of Commonwealth Functions.

The Commission was established in 1978 pursuant to the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission Act 1977. It does not itself provide legal aid but has a range of functions related to the scheme for legal aid to be provided by State and Territory commissions. The Commission's functions, which are set out in detail in section 6 of the Act, provide overall for the Commission to have an advisory, co-ordinating and monitoring role. In particular, the Commission has the functions of keeping the need for legal assistance in Australia under review, of making recommendations to the Attorney-General and to the State and Territory Commissions, of collecting and publishing statistics, of undertaking research and of furnishing an annual report for tabling in Parliament.

The Act provides for the Commission to consist of a part time chairman, a full time deputy chairman and six part time members. Two of those members are to be nominated by the Attorney-General and two by the Attorneys-General of the States which have established commissions providing legal assistance in respect of Commonwealth matters. One member is to be nominated by the Law Council of Australia and one by the Australian Council of Social Service. The Commission has the assistance of a separate staff, which is under the control of the full time Deputy Chairman.

Some of the Commission's many functions are, of course, of greater significance than others. The Commission itself has recognised this. It has also recognised that its resources are not unlimited. It accordingly resolved last year to adopt an order of priority for its various functions and to confine its activities normally to the functions of greater significance. Briefly stated those functions are as follows:
1. Collation and analysis of statistics;
2. Liaison with professional bodies and with national community interest groups;
3. Examination of the basis of Commonwealth Government financial support for legal aid;
4. Research relating to the need for legal assistance, the functioning and effectiveness of other schemes and new methods of financing and providing legal assistance;
5. Convening meetings with representatives of State and Territory Commissions;
6. Maintenance of a library and clearing-house of legal aid materials and publication from time to time of a newsletter; and
7. Matters specifically requested by the Attorney-General.

In introducing the present Bill I want to stress, as I did in answer to a question asked by Senator Evans without notice on 26 March 1981, that there is no intention on the part of the Government to reduce its commitments to the level of legal aid or the commitments it has made in agreements with the States to maintain the level of activity of legal aid. I want to emphasise that it has always been the policy of the Government that no person should be denied legal aid because of lack of means. This is a continuing aim of the Government and is evident from annual appropriations for legal aid, which, excluding Aboriginal legal aid, have increased from $19.6m at the time the first State legal aid commission commenced operations in Western Australia in April 1978 to $26.9m in the current financial year-an overall increase of some 37 per cent.

The Government does not question the desirability of an independent Commonwealth body with functions broadly similar to those to which the Commission itself has resolved to give priority. The Government is concerned, however, that the structure and working arrangements of that body should be dictated by efficiency and economy. In the light of experience since the establishment of the Commission the Government has concluded that there is room for improvement in this regard.

There are two main and related causes of concern with the present arrangements. One is that the functions of the Commission overlap those of my Department, with consequential duplication of effort in some matters and uncertainty as to responsibility in other matters. The uncertainty also presents difficulties for the State commissions. Those problems are accentuated by the other cause of concern, which is the separate staffs of the Commission and my Department. The existence of two separate staffs dealing with the same or closely related matters makes for unnecessary bureaucracy and is uneconomic and inefficient. In saying this, I am not, of course, reflecting on the capacity or dedication of individual officers. My concern is exclusively with the system in which those officers have to operate.

With these considerations in mind the Government has concluded that the Commonwealth's legal aid body, while retaining its independence, should have a closer working relationship with the Attorney-General and his Department. To avoid the problem of overlapping functions I have mentioned it is proposed that the body should confine itself to advice and matters incidental thereto, leaving the Department to attend to matters of an executive nature. It is also proposed that staffing assistance for the body should be provided by the Department instead of by a separate staff. In recognition of these changes, which are expected to result in significant cost savings, it is proposed that the new body be named the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council. In respects other than those I have mentioned the Council will be very similar to the existing Commission.
The membership of the Council will be the same except that:

There will be no full time Deputy Chairman; members at present appointed on nomination (including two nominated by participating States) will be appointed instead after the Attorney-General has consulted with the bodies which at present do the nominating. Experience has shown that the present provisions are unduly restrictive and inflexible; and
Appointments will be by the Attorney-General instead of by the Governor-General.

The functions of the Council will be broadly those which the Commission is now performing. Some functions will be exercisable on the Council's own initiative but these can be supplemented by ad hoc requests by the Attorney-General. The functions are expressed in broad terms in proposed section 5 of the Bill. In the course of performing those functions the Council will, of course, undertake research, assisted as appropriate by officers of my Department or consultants.

Functions to which the Commission has given priority are those of maintaining a library and providing a clearing-house of legal aid materials. It gathers those materials and circulates them to legal aid agencies and interest groups. These are very useful functions and they will be continued by my Department consulting as appropriate with the Council. The collection and analysis of statistics will be similarly continued by my Department. The Council itself will be required to provide an annual report for the Parliament.

The Council will not have the functions of making recommendations to State commissions. While the Commission has had the power to make such recommendations, it has seldom exercised it in practice. Where it is appropriate for matters to be raised with State governments or commissions, it is better that they be raised by the Attorney-General or by his Department. The functions the Commission has under the Commonwealth-State agreements will be taken over by my Department. In particular, the programs and estimates of expenditure of State commissions will be submitted to my Department, which in any event, must be closely involved in all budgetary matters. The States with which the Commonwealth has entered into such agreements-Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia-have agreed to these changes.

As I mentioned earlier, the Council will not have a staff of its own but will be serviced by staff of my Department. To meet the increased workload that will be imposed on my Department, some of the present staff of the Commission will be absorbed into the Department. The placement of other staff will be considered after consultation with the Public Service Board and staff associations.

I would like to place on record my appreciation of the work of the foundation Chairman of the Commission, Sir John Nimmo, the present Chairman of the Commission, Mr Justice Else-Mitchell, the past and present members of the Commission and the staff of the Commission for their loyalty and dedication and for the work they have done since the Commission commenced operations. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Evans) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) proposed:
That Government Business take precedence of General Business after 8 p.m. this day.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the rather unanticipated non-appearance on today's business sheet of the Freedom of Information Bill will the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) tell us, as time is not to be made available tonight in the General Business period, how much time, if any, the Government will make available for the consideration of this Bill during the present session? Are we to take it from the non-appearance of the Bill on the business sheet today that the Government has, in fact, made a decision now to abandon it? Are we to take it that the Government has made a decision to postpone it until the next session, or are we simply to take it that this is another demonstration of the inability of the Government in its present general state of neurotic disarray to make any decision at all about the future of the Bill? Can the Attorney fill us in on the Government's intentions with respect to this very important Bill and tell us, if it is not going to be debated today, when in fact it will be debated?

—I take it that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) will answer Senator Evans's questions at the conclusion of other honourable senators' remarks. I voice support, of course, for what Senator Evans has said. I also want to make a point about the early abandonment of General Business. It has been stated many times by honourable senators on this side that General Business ought not to be abandoned so early in the piece. I take it that we will be sitting until well into June. I would have thought the opportunity to debate General Business would still have been made available to us. It may be argued that what is listed on the business sheet now is a substitute for General Business. A whole series of first readings of Bills is listed. Those debates cannot refer to any item on the Notice Paper. If the debate refers to an item which is firmly entrenched in the Notice Paper a point of order could be raised. Even though there is a flexibility for honourable senators to debate a variety of matters the opportunity for General Business has been again taken away. I was going to say that it has been abandoned. I still make the point that it ought not to be taken away so early in the piece. The matter of whether arrangements have been made, to which some of us are not privy, will possibly be explained. It is necessary to make these comments to prevent this sort of action from becoming a precedent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again lodge my strong objection to the taking away of senators' rights by Government Business taking precedence of General Business. My colleague Senator Cavanagh would have done the same as I am doing now if he had not been called out of the chamber on urgent business. Over the many years Senator Cavanagh has been a senator, he has always protested against the Government's taking away the rights of senators, particularly back bench senators, to indulge in debate on Thursday evenings under General Business, whether it be a debate on reports on which a motion that the Senate take note of the paper has been moved and the debate adjourned to a later day or on matters of importance to senators of which they have given notice. Senator Cavanagh is back in the chamber now. I am very pleased to welcome him back. He can speak for himself. His meeting must be over.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at the Notice Paper and the items listed under notices of motion, I see that I have no fewer than eight notices of motion which I wanted to see come forward for debate because they are very important matters to my State of South Australia. Most of them deal with unfulfilled promises made by the South Australian Liberal Premier. I think they need to be aired in this place. Whilst most people say that this is a States House, I dispute that. It does not operate along those lines. While it is said by Government members that it is a States House, I intend to make use of it and air State problems in this place. I want to raise those matters which I consider are very vital to the economy of the State. They ought to be aired in this Federal Parliament. Because of the decision of the Government to take away General Business tonight no opportunity will be available to have these matters aired until we come back in the Budget session.

Senator Chipp and Senator Mason, I think last Thursday when we debated the same motion that Government Business take precedence of General Business, gave warning to the Government that it will not be able to get away with this sort of thing as soon as we come back for the Budget session because the numbers will be on this side of the chamber if the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats combine to uphold the rights of members. So the Government should have taken warning from what Senator Chipp said. I hope that he sticks to the statement he made. Without delaying the Senate unduly I say again that I want to place on record my strongest protest at the actions of the Government so early in the piece.

I want to refer to just one other matter which was referred to by Senator Evans; that is, the non-appearance on the business sheet today of the Freedom of Information Bill. Senator Evans might be of the view that the Bill is not listed because some of the debates have been dragged out. I would not agree with him if that is his thought. My view is that the Government does not want this Bill to come on for debate. I read in the Press today that this matter was raised in Cabinet yesterday and the decision was that the Freedom of Information Bill was to be brought on for debate. Apparently, like other things which appear on the Notice Paper, it has disappeared from the business sheet.

We have only to look at yesterday's to see what was put in front of us. We were to debate the motions for the first readings of the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill and Appropriation Bill (No. 3). Let us look at today's Notice Paper. It is just like playing draughts. The people in the office of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) must be having some great fun with the way they are moving about the Bills listed on the Notice Paper. Today Appropriation Bill (No. 3), which yesterday was the third of the Bills listed for debate on the motion for the first reading, is listed first under Orders of the Day. The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill is now listed after Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and takes precedence over the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill. With the way that the order of Bills on the Notice Paper has been altered in this place even during a day, I am beginning to wonder whether we will get on to debating the Bills in the order in which they appear now. The Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill easily might still be put back and be debated before the other two Bills. I again lodge my strongest protest at the action of the Government in taking away the rights of back bench senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been told that I have been spoken for on this matter. I thank Senator McLaren for including me in his remarks. I have fought on this matter for 16 years-three years of my 19 years were exempted because the situation did not apply-on every occasion it has happened. It is the routine of the Government. I feel so strongly about this matter, knowing that I could never succeed while I remained in this place, that I am retiring this year to let Janine Haines from South Australia take a place here. During the short session she was a senator she voted against the taking away of General Business. I made that sacrifice for the purpose of justice in this matter. I hope the Government, in its few remaining months in office, will not insist that there has to be a multitude of retirements before we get justice in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cavanagh has stated very frankly that he has fought and protested against Government Business taking precedence of General Business on Thursday night for only 16 of the 19 years that he has been in the Senate. Of course, during the three years when his party was in government he would have had the attitude held by all governments that I have heard of and had experience with. At this stage of a session governments seek to intrude on time otherwise granted to private members by giving precedence to Government Business. It seems that, no matter how much we try, it is a feature of any parliament under any government that there is a bank-up of government legislation at the end of a session. The fact is that a great deal of time has been granted to private members' business throughout this session and, indeed, other sessions. It is wrong to think of private members' business being confined to Thursday evenings. Private members are able to bring forward matters of public importance or urgency motions on numerous occasions. They frequently make use of the opportunities provided by the adjournment debate. Under our system they are provided with very many opportunities and they quite rightly make full use of them. We are talking about an exceptional and a very short lived restriction of one of those rights.
—Are you justified in taking away a right, if it is not done too often?

—As I have said, this situation has occurred traditionally. It has been only a very minor intrusion on those rights. I think the fact that Senator Cavanagh, with all his eloquence and determination, has not been able to rectify this situation over the 16 years that he has been trying to do so indicates that there is a fairly widespread recognition that the Government is putting forward a reasonable proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me comment on Senator Evans's question. I think Senator McLaren is also interested in this matter. The fact that the Freedom of Information Bill has not been placed on the order of business sheet today is not a ground for coming to any of the conclusions that Senator Evans has postulated. During this week we have not made the progress with legislation that it appeared likely we would make. Yesterday we did not complete the program for the day. The appropriation Bills are becoming more urgent at this time of the year and, in any event, such Bills must be given absolutely top priority by the Government in any session of Parliament. Perhaps when I was speaking earlier about the rights of private senators, I should have mentioned that a large number of senators are taking advantage of their rights to speak in first reading debates. The Government does not seek to curtail that right, but a number of senators still wish to speak on the first reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and on the first reading of another money Bill. In order to get those Bills through the Senate today it seemed necessary to give them first priority. We estimate that they will fill the day's program. As I have said, consideration of another Bill was not completed yesterday. We could have placed the Freedom of Information Bill on the program for consideration after the Bills to which I have referred had been disposed of, but it seemed to be an unrealistic exercise. People may have prepared unnecessarily for a debate which was very unlikely to be brought on. That is the only reason for the Freedom of Information Bill not being placed on the order of business sheet.

There is another factor, although it is not conclusive. The Government has not yet completed its consideration of the very large number of proposed amendments to the Freedom of Information Bill that have been tabled. Certainly, if we had time today we could have proceeded with the Committee debate ahead of that final consideration. A number of amendments could be dealt with promptly. However, I am sure that the Government will complete its consideration of the amendments before we meet again in 10 days time. We have in mind that in the first week after Parliament resumes we may be able to get a reasonably lengthy run at the Bill. If we have some hours of Committee debate-I do not know whether we will be able to complete the debate in that time-we ought to have some indication of how long it will take to deal with the remainder of the Bill. I hope that we will be able to break the back of the questions to be considered in the series of proposed amendments.

The position is quite clear. There has been much unnecessary speculation about it. Senator Evans has raised it again today. I do not criticise him. He is properly entitled to ask what is going on in relation to the Bill. I hope that I have been able to make it clear that the Government hopes to provide time for the Senate to debate the Bill. It appears from the way in which the legislative program is shaping that we will have time to do so in the first week after the break. Of course, it all depends on how much time senators wish to devote to other pieces of legislation. The Government has great faith in private enterprise and market forces. If large numbers of senators wish to speak on other pieces of legislation, I am afraid that the Government cannot do anything about it. We must bow to the numbers and deal firstly with the matters to which the majority of senators give priority.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have a statement on the Bills and the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement and speeches read as follows-

I will be introducing today various Bills pursuant to the Commonwealth's obligations under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. Before I discuss the individual Bills, I would like to outline, for the benefit of honourable senators, the administrative and legislative context in which the Bills will operate.
Formal Agreement on Companies and Securities

The formal agreement executed by the Commonwealth and all the States on 22 December 1978 provides the framework for a co-operative Commonwealth-State scheme for a uniform system of law and administration regulating companies and the securities industry. The scheme covers the relevant law operating in the six States and the Australian Capital Territory. There is also provision for the scheme to be extended to the Northern Territory and to the external territories of the Commonwealth. Background material on the formal agreement and on the four basic elements of the co-operative scheme is set out in paragraphs 7 to 36 of the explanatory memorandum on the Companies Bill which has been circulated to honourable senators. The basic aim of the scheme is to ensure that wherever possible, any person or company should be able to deal on all general companies and securities matters as if that person or company were only subject to one system of law and administration throughout Australia. The co-operative scheme thus provides a framework for uniform general laws on companies and securities matters that will apply throughout Australia. It was, however, never intended to fetter the sovereign right of any parliament to pass particular laws which are not inconsistent with the general legislation agreed to under the scheme.
Keeping Company Law Uniform

There have been far too few examples of uniform laws being achieved across State boundaries in Australia. Company law, of course, is one area in which a measure of uniformity was achieved in the 1960s but did not continue. Under the co-operative scheme, we have a mechanism for continuing uniformity. An inevitable consequence is that the Commonwealth Minister has only 1 vote in 7 in determining the content of the legislation which is introduced into the Commonwealth Parliament, as all such legislation must be approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. Indeed, after the initial legislation has been enacted it is conceivable that the Commonwealth Minister would be required to introduce legislation of which he did not approve. Amending legislation requires the approval of only a simple majority of members of the Council. However, it is apparent from the spirit of co-operation and give-and-take which has emerged already in the Council's deliberations that any future legislation will also be the product of consensus.

It is not surprising that a scheme of this magnitude has taken some years to get off the ground. By the time the companies code is in operation, it is expected that the Parliaments of Australia will have enacted more than 50 Bills. But it is only after the initial legislation has been enacted that the real fruits of these labours will become apparent. There will no longer be any need for action by State parliaments to keep the scheme uniform as amendments passed by this Parliament will flow automatically into the laws of the States. Even when the Ministerial Council decides that the amendments should operate slightly differently from one State to another so as to pick up some local evidentiary differences-for example, this can be achieved by translator amendments-regulations will be made in one State varying the Commonwealth amendments in their operation as laws of that State.

Uniform legislation is, of course, only half the package. Uniform administration of those laws by the National Companies and Securities Commission acting through the various Corporate Affairs Offices is the feature which will set the scheme apart from existing practices. Legislation setting up the National Commission was passed in 1979 and the members appointed early last year.
The Substantive Codes

In addition to the legislation establishing the National Companies and Securities Commission and supporting its operation in jurisdictions other than the Australian Capital Territory, the substantive legislation for the scheme at this stage will be contained in four codes:
(a) a share acquisition code which will regulate the acquisition of company shares;
(b) a securities industry code which will regulate the securities industry;
(c) a companies code which will cover the remaining areas dealt with in the current companies and marketable securities legislation; and
(d) an interpretation code which deals with the interpretation of the Commonwealth legislation under this scheme.
Public Consultation

The formal agreement foreshadowed a major exercise in legislative uniformity and law reform where this was necessary. In embarking on this exercise, this Government and the other governments which are parties to the formal agreement have sought to ensure that there is at all times adequate opportunity for the proposed legislation to be considered by interested persons. Comments were sought and received on the proposed acquisition of shares, securities industry and companies codes. The Companies Bill which I am introducing today is an amended version of the Bill which was introduced to the House on 27 August last year by the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the Hon. R. V. Garland, M.P. Notwithstanding a period of public exposure of an earlier draft prior to that introduction, additional comments were sought on the Bill as introduced into the House. In addition to the process of public consultation, committees of interested Government and Opposition members and senators have continued to receive regular briefings on the scheme.
Progress in Implementation of the Co-operative Scheme

A point has now been reached where substantial progress has been made towards bringing into operation the co-operative companies and securities scheme. The original Commonwealth Acts relating to the share acquisition code, the securities industry code and the interpretation code have already passed through this Parliament and received royal assent. Our aim is to bring these codes into operation in the Australian Capital Territory and the six States on 1 July 1981 and we are hopeful that the companies code will be operative from 1 January 1982. I would now like to discuss very briefly the first of the Bills that I am presenting today, the Companies Bill.
Companies Bill 1981

An outline of the principal features of the companies code and, in particular, the main changes it makes to existing companies legislation, is set out at paragraphs 37 to 43 of the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated.

Clearly, the most important feature of this Companies Bill and of the previous exposure drafts which differentiates them from the existing law is the 'one place of registration' concept. These modifications to the existing law are required to ensure that an Australian company incorporated in a jurisdiction covered by the co-operative scheme can lodge all its documents with the local corporate affairs office in its jurisdiction of incorporation without the need to lodge documents anywhere else. Similarly, overseas corporations will have to register in only one of the jurisdictions covered by the co-operative scheme.

The Australia-wide nature of the scheme has also been reflected in several major parts of the Bill. For example, in the areas of special investigations, schemes of arrangement and liquidations, the provisions of the existing law have been recast to overcome jurisdictional difficulties which have been faced in the past. The national emphasis of the co-operative scheme is also reflected in the clauses providing for a national system of registration for auditors, liquidators and official liquidators. The capacity of companies to change their headquarters has also been improved with the provisions relating to transfer of incorporation. There are also a number of other improvements to the existing law which have been made independently of the need to provide for an Australia-wide system of company law.

There are some areas of the Bill such as the division concerned with registration of charges which reflect both categories of change: provision is now made for charges over company property wherever situated to be registered in only one participating State or Territory. At the same time, however, the consequences of registration or failure to register will be fundamentally different from the existing law-in brief it reflects a change from a partial invalidity system to a priority system as recommended in the seventh interim report of the Eggleston committee. Further changes have been made in the current Bill from the exposure drafts which involve some departures from the Eggleston committee recommendations in the light of public comments. To identify quickly the other changes from the last draft of the Bill I would direct honourable senators' attention to Appendix D of the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. There is also a comparison, in Appendix C, of the provisions in the April 1980 and August 1980 exposure drafts.

It will be apparent from an examination of the Bill and a comparison of Appendices C and D that the changes made in the current Bill generally represent fine tuning changes rather than ambitious law reform exercises. Whilst everyone agrees in the main that there are areas of company law in need of fundamental reform, it is not so simple to achieve general agreement in the community on any particular measure of reform. Accordingly, in order to get the scheme into operation without any further delay, the changes in the current Bill, though many, are not radical.

Some of the areas where there have been further refinement of provisions in the exposure drafts include divisions relating to the powers of inspection of the National Commission, ratification of contracts made before formation of companies, companies financing dealings in their own shares, the duties and liabilities of directors, disciplinary proceedings against auditors and liquidators, and substantial shareholdings.

Perhaps I should also mention some things which are not in the Companies Bill but which nevertheless are of considerable practical importance. The first is that the Companies Bill does not contain provisions corresponding to the Ninth Schedule to the Companies Acts and Ordinances in force in the various States and Territories. The Ninth Schedule deals with the content of accounts and group accounts to be lodged by companies. That does not mean that company directors will be able to determine for themselves what matters to include in their accounts. It simply means that with a view to having flexible accounting provisions which have some chance of remaining relevant to the purposes for which they are designed, the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities has decided that these provisions should take the form of regulations. The aim is, of course, to enable these provisions to be amended more readily than would be the case with such provisions contained in the principal legislation. Lest this decision should give rise to any apprehension as to the ultimate content of those regulations, I hasten to add that the proposed regulations will not involve significant departures from the existing Ninth Schedule. The regulations will contain the provisions as exposed for public comment, amended in a few relatively minor ways in the light of public submissions. These proposed changes are set out in paragraph 1,300 of the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

There are two additional matters which are not covered by this Bill but which may yet be the subject of an amending Bill when the Ministerial Council decides upon the extent to which certain disclosure principles should operate. The first is the disclosure of the operations of trading trusts. Honourable senators will recall that provisions concerning disclosure by companies operating business through trusts formed part of the first exposure draft of the Companies Bill. When introducing the August Bill into the House last year the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the Honourable R. V. Garland, M.P., indicated that those provisions had been removed but that Ministers would be giving further consideration to the inclusion of more appropriate provisions at a later stage. The examination of this matter is still proceeding, and in the interim, the Companies Bill does not contain special provisions relating to the operation of trading trusts.

The second matter highlighted last August as requiring further work was that concerning the extent to which overseas incorporated companies should disclose information as to their Australian operations. Again, this is a matter which will require further work to be done before the Ministerial Council is in a position to consider amendments to the legislation. It may well be that draft accounting requirements relating to such disclosure would need to be submitted for public comment before being submitted to the Parliament. Accordingly, legislative amendments on this subject may be some time away yet. Whilst drawing attention to the possibility of additional accounting requirements, I would like to mention one matter of particular concern to the accounting profession, namely the permitted size of accounting partnerships. Ministers drew particular attention to this matter when seeking public comments on exposure drafts of the Companies Bill. The Ministerial Council will be making a decision on this matter in the near future.

I should mention that some amendments to this Bill are likely to be introduced during the second half of this year. This Bill is being introduced at this stage, however, to enable the six State parliaments to pass legislation in the second half of this year adopting the Companies Bill. This should then enable the entire scheme to be in operation by 1 January 1982. Experience with the other codes has demonstrated that the need for some modifications to the principal legislation will become apparent only when the State adopting legislation and the Commonwealth regulations are being settled.
Mr President, I commend the Companies Bill to the Senate.
Companies (Fees) Bill 1981

The Companies (Fees) Bill is related to the Companies Bill in that it deals with the fees payable under the Companies Bill. The actual amounts of those fees will be set out in regulations to be made under the Fees Bill.
Details of the Bill are set out in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the benefit of honourable senators.
The Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. Mr President, I commend the Companies (Fees) Bill to the Senate.
Companies (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1981

The object of the Companies (Transitional Provisions) Bill is to enact, for the Australian Capital Territory, the transitional provisions that are necessary for the introduction of the new companies code. This Bill will come into operation on the same day as the commencement of the Companies Bill itself. The States will not be having separate Companies (Transitional Provisions) Bills. Each State will, however, include in its Companies (Application of Laws) Bill appropriate transitional provisions which will be modelled on those contained in the Bill that I am now introducing, with such modifications as are necessary to take into account the particular circumstances of that State. As with the Companies (Transitional Provisions) Bill itself, the transitional provisions in the various State (Application of Laws) Bills will require the unanimous approval of the Ministerial Council. Mr President, I commend the Companies (Transitional Provisions) Bill to the Senate.
Companies (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981

The Companies (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill contains miscellaneous amendments to certain Commonwealth Acts consequent upon the repeal of the Australian Capital Territory Companies Ordinance 1962 and the enactment of the Companies Bill 1981. The Bill does not affect the States as it relates only to Commonwealth Acts. Each State will however need to pass similar legislation in relation to any State Acts that contain references to the existing State Companies Acts.

Details of the Bill are contained in an explanatory memorandum that has been circulated for the benefit of honourabe senators. Because this Bill and the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill do not form part of the co-operative scheme legislation they therefore do not require the approval of the Ministerial Council. The Miscellaneous Amendment Bills passed by each State will again not be part of the scheme legislation. There will also be a separate Companies (Miscellaneous Amendments) Ordinance containing consequential amendments to Australian Capital Territory Ordinances. Mr President, I commend the Companies (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill to the Senate.
Crown Debts (Priority) Bill 1981

The Crown Debts (Priority) Bill reflects the Commonwealth Government's view that the Crown in right of the Commonwealth should be placed in the same position in an insolvency situation in relation to ordinary debts as any other creditor. This decision was announced to the House by the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Fife, on 13 September 1979 following a report that Senator Missen tabled in this chamber as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. The report concerned the right of the Crown to be repaid debts owing to it in priority to other creditors in matters of bankruptcy, corporate liquidations or other cases of impecunious persons or corporations.

The Senate Committee in its report recommended the complete abrogation of all Crown priorities in insolvency administration. The Government examined the report and was in agreement with the main thrust of the Committee's argument. The Government supports uniformity of insolvency administration which was of particular concern to the Senate Committee. It also acknowledged the desirability of placing the Crown on an even footing with the private sector so far as possible.

Accordingly, the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs announced that the Government had decided to abolish all remaining Crown priorities in the Commonwealth sphere except in relation to tax instalment deductions and withholding tax on dividends and interest remitted overseas and to seek the abolition of all remaining Crown priorities in the State sphere. Special considerations apply in relation to these two categories of taxation debts and separate them from other Crown debts. Other changes have already been made to bankruptcy and taxation legislation in pursuance of the Government's decision.

The Crown Debts (Priority) Bill will abrogate the prerogative priority of the Crown in right of the Commonwealth and will ensure that, in the case of the insolvency of a corporate or unincorporate body, the Commonwealth is under an obligation to repay preferential payments in circumstances where other creditors would be obliged to do so and that it is bound by any compromise or arrangement entered into by such a body. Details of the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the benefit of honourable senators.

The Crown Debts (Priority) Bill is not part of the co-operative scheme since it only affects the Crown in right of the Commonwealth. The Bill I am here introducing accordingly did not need the approval of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. Nevertheless, as the drafting of the terms of the Bill is interrelated with that of the Companies Bill it has been decided that both Bills should come into operation on the same day. Mr President, I commend the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill to the Senate.
Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981

The Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill (No. 2) will amend the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980 consequent on the provisions that are set out in the Companies Bill 1981 and will also amend the substantive provisions of the share acquisition code. Details of the amendments are set out in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated.

Provisions in the Bill consequential on the Companies Bill will come into operation when the Companies Bill commences and the other provisions will come into operation when proclaimed. This Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. I commend the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill (No. 2) to the Senate.
Companies (Acquisition of Shares-Fees) Amendment Bill 1981

The Companies (Acquisition of Shares-Fees) Amendment Bill makes a minor amendment to the Companies (Acquisition of Shares-Fees) Act 1981. This amendment will bring these provisions into line with equivalent provisions in the Companies (Fees) Bill 1981. Details of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares-Fees) Amendment Bill 1981 appear in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated. The Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. I commend the Companies (Acquisition of Shares-Fees) Amendment Bill to the Senate.
Securities Industry Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981

The Securities Industry Amendment Bill (No. 2) has two separate functions. Part II of the Bill makes certain amendments of a technical nature to the substantive provisions of the Securities Industry Act. Part III of the Bill amends the Securities Industry Act 1980 to take account of certain provisions in the Companies Bill 1981. Details of the amendments are set out in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the benefit of honourable senators.

Provisions in the Bill consequential on the Companies Bill will come into operation when the Companies Bill commences and the other provisions will come into operation when proclaimed. The Securities Industry Amendment Bill (No. 2) has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. I commend the Securities Industry Amendment Bill (No. 2) to the Senate.
Securities Industry (Fees) Amendment Bill 1981

The Securities Industry (Fees) Amendment Bill 1981 makes a minor amendment to the Securities Industry fees Act 1980. This amendment will bring these provisions into line with equivalent provisions in the Companies (Fees) Bill 1981. Details of the Securities Industry (Fees) Amendment Bill appear in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated. The Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. I commend the Securities Industry (Fees) Amendment Bill to the Senate.
Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Bill

The Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) alters two definitions in the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1980. The Bill will come into effect when the Companies Bill comes into operation. Details of the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) appear in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated. The Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. I commend the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have just had put in front of me the list showing the order of speakers. There has been yet another change in the speaking list. This confirms what I said a while ago when I was speaking to the previous motion before the Chair, that the staff and the Ministers and the Government must be having some great fun playing draughts and shuffling people around all the time.
—Not necessarily.

—The Government Whip says, 'Not necessarily'. But why do the changes occur so often? Every 10 minutes we get a different list of speakers. Be that as it may, I now find myself continuing a speech which I commenced on Tuesday night on the first reading of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1981. But because of what the Government has been doing-shuffling Bills around all over the place-I now find myself making that speech in the first reading debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1980-81. It is often said that all good things come to those who wait, but some have to wait longer than others. At least my turn has now come.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Tuesday I commenced to talk about the Joint Sitting which was held in this place to elect a senator to replace the late Senator John Knight. I had made my remarks about the late senator. To get my speech into its proper context, I will have to go over some of the remarks that I made at that time. On that occasion I said that I had hoped that the matter that I wanted to raise would be raised during the Joint Sitting, because that was the most appropriate time to do so. Unfortunately it was not raised at that stage. As I said, I missed the opportunity to raise the matter myself, but I think it is only right and proper that the attitude of the present Government when it was in opposition to Senate representation of the Territories be put into the record.

The matter to which I want to refer is the legislation which had been before the Senate on three occasions previously, while the Whitlam Government was in office. Its purpose was to allow the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory to have Senate representation. This afternoon I confine my remarks to Senate representation for the Australian Capital Territory. I said last Tuesday that I found it very interesting, when we were sitting in this chamber on 5 May, to hear the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) nominate Mrs Reid to be the replacement senator for the Australian Capital Territory. It was particularly interesting to hear the remarks of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick, when he seconded the nomination. I refreshed my memory of what Senator Carrick said during the debate on the legislation when it was before this House on three different occasions and also when it was before the Joint Sitting in the other place. I do not think he spoke on the latter occasion. In seconding the nomination of Mrs Reid, Senator Carrick said:
I am sure that she will be a considerable acquisition to the Senate.
I am not going to dispute that statement. The remarks that he made which were of great interest to me were these:
She conforms to the requirements of the Electoral Act and other legislation. I am happy to commend Mrs Reid to the Joint Sitting.

What we have to remember is that if it had not been for the Joint Sitting which was forced upon the Whitlam Government in 1974 and which was held in the other place across King's Hall, the Joint Sitting of 5 May would not have taken place because there would have been no legislation in this Commonwealth to allow either the Northern Territory or the Australian Capital Territory to have representatives in the Senate.

As I said earlier, this legislation came before this chamber on three occasions, and on each such occasion members of the then Opposition, who now form the Government, had the numbers and voted against it. After the double dissolution in 1974 but before the Joint Sitting was held, the Liberal Party challenged the legislation in the High Court of Australia, but that challenge was defeated. Again, after the Joint Sitting it took another challenge to the High Court and again the legislation which was passed by the Joint Sitting was deemed to be valid. We can see that those people who are now in government-I will list them for inclusion in Hansard at the end of my speech-fought tooth and nail to prevent people such as Senator Kilgariff, Senator Robertson and Senator Ryan and now Senator Reid taking their places in this chamber.

The Senate (Representation of Territories) Bill first came into this place on 31 May 1973. On the same day the second reading speech was delivered. On 7 June 1973, Senator Jessop led in the debate for the then Opposition. As I said, when I was speaking on this matter last Tuesday I expressed regret that I had to speak about Senator Jessop in his absence. Unfortunately, I have to do the same thing today, because I understand that Senator Jessop has another commitment interstate. But that will not prevent me from reading into the record the remarks of Senator Jessop who was the lead speaker for the then Opposition. Some of his remarks may make Senator Kilgariff blush. In particular, some of Senator Carrick's remarks may make him blush and wonder about the person who now leads him. I had to wait a week to speak on this matter. Now, a further two days have gone by. Senator Jessop, in his opening remarks on this Bill, said:
We believe that this proposal-
That is, to legislate to give Senate representation to both Territories-
is contrary to the spirit of the Constitution by which the sovereign States agreed to the establishment of the Federal Parliament.
He went on further to say on that day:
We believe that if this Bill were approved, this principle would be destroyed by giving the balance of power to Territorial representatives and the Senate would no longer be a true States House.

I ask Senator Kilgariff, who is in the chamber now, to ponder those remarks because they are very pertinent. It would appear that we have done away with the Constitution because we have people like Senator Kilgariff sitting in this place. That debate took place on 7 June. Later on, at the end of his speech, he said:
We cannot support the measure.
On 14 November 1973 when the matter again came into the House, Senator Jessop, again the lead speaker for the then Opposition, said:
The Opposition has not changed its attitude in relation to this Bill.
He was speaking of the Senate (Representation of Territories) Bill. He said:
We do not lend our support to the proposition before the Senate.
He went on further to say:
We maintain that the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory have adequate representation.
Those were the remarks of the then lead speaker for the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Senator Jessop said that he believed, and his party believed, that both the Territories had adequate representation in the Parliament. At the conclusion of his speech on 14 November 1973, Senator Jessop said:

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, the Opposition rejects both of these Bills.
On 17 July 1974, in speaking to the legislation when it was again introduced into this Parliament, Senator Jessop in the course of the second reading debate said:

Therefore, as a responsible member of the Senate, I believe that anything which will endanger this chamber in which we sit constitutionally and anything which will weaken the influence of the States-this place is a States House-ought to be rejected by any responsible member of this chamber.
Of course, the proposition was rejected by those who sat behind him. He further said:
Honourable senators opposite refer to the need for Senate representation of the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.

Then he referred to what Senator Gietzelt had said. He had said in a previous speech that he maintained that the Territories were adequately represented. I interjected, as I usually do when I do not agree with what the honourable senator is saying. He said:

Senator McLaren always rises to the bait, and I am very glad of that fact. In South Australia State Australian Labor Party members have not been able to put the views expressed by their electors because they have been bound by Caucus decisions. That is not so with respect to our Party.

I quoted from Mr Burr's speech when I was speaking on the amendment to the Address-in-Reply. We find that in fact the people who now sit opposite are also bound by Caucus decisions. But they are not as honest as we are. When we go to the people at election time we do not make any secret of the fact that we abide by a majority decision of our party. We do not hoodwink people into believing that we can act as free agents once we are elected. That is what the Liberals do repeatedly. Anyone who reads Mr Burr's speech will see what free agents Government members are. Mr Burr stated the penalties imposed upon members of the Liberal Party in particular if they do not toe the line. The penalties are all stated in Hansard. We saw some evidence of the penalties when we read the report in today's Press about what took place yesterday at the party meeting. Even the Premier of Queensland was huffing and puffing about what he would do. The Premiers are now licking the boots of the Prime Minister, running around like little lap dogs and doing as he says. So much for the free agency of honourable senators opposite! Senator Jessop went on to say:

We reject this Bill purely and simply because it would weaken this place as a States House. It seems quite incredible to me that the Government should put these proposals without consulting the States.
Senator Jessop then repeated that he believed that the Territories were adequately represented. Further he said:

I just cannot see that there is any argument at all to be put forward to change my mind about this measure. I think that the Labor Party can be likened unto white ants, because with this Bill they seem to be nibbling away at the very core of the Constitution that set up the Senate as a States House. I think it is valid to raise constitutional matters in this debate.
He went on to say:
Even a person such as myself without any great legal knowledge can see immediately that this measure could be challenged by the States if it was ever enacted.

Of course this measure was challenged by the Liberal Party of Australia in the High Court and was proved to be valid. Some of his other comments are very interesting, similar comments were made by other members of the coalition. I will refer to them later. Senator Jessop said:

It is quite fair to suggest that the people of Norfolk Island, Christmas Island and other territories could be justified in asking for Senate representation and I would be very surprised if it did not happen.

It has not happened as yet. These are the spurious arguments that were put forward by members of the then Opposition who now sit in government in trying to prevent residents and electors in the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory from having representation in this Senate. People should be very concerned about that matter and not be hoodwinked by the platitudes mouthed in Parliament last Tuesday week by the Prime Minister and supported by Senator Carrick. In the Joint Sitting on 6 August when introducing the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act Senator Murphy said:
These Bills, like the other 4 Bills under consideration in this first Joint Sitting, have been before each House of the Parliament on 3 previous occasions.
That is why they were brought forward at the Joint Sitting. He further stated:
The effect of these proposals will be to give representation in the Senate to 140,000 voters in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory.
He also said:

When the Parliament reassembled a month ago these Bills, along with the other 4 Bills, came before each of the Houses for a third time. The result was the same. The Opposition parties continued to deny representation in the Senate to the people of the 2 Territories. The deadlock persisted. The Governor-General . . . convened this Joint Sitting of the members of the Senate and of the House of Representatives on Tuesday last week.
Of course he spoke on 6 August. He continued:

A further attempt was made in the past few days in the High Court of Australia to prevent the enactment of this Bill, along with the other 5 Bills, into law. That attempt to stop the proceedings that are taking place here in Parliament today, I am pleased to report, has failed. After all these frustrations we now have come together to deliberate upon the Senate (Representation of Territories) Bill and the Representation Bill and to enact them as laws of this Parliament.

That is what we did. Of course we know, as I said earlier, that after that Joint Sitting the decision taken by those duly elected representatives was again challenged in the High Court. I will quote briefly a remark made by the late Senator Greenwood, who vigorously opposed this legislation. He said:
We ought to recognise that the Labor Party is a party which, since it has been in government, has exercised a power of patronage and corruption which is unequalled anywhere in Australia's history--
If Senator Greenwood were here now I do not think he would utter those words because they would be fired right back in his face.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have certainly been exceeded now.

—As my colleague has said, there is no doubt about that. When one looks at the record one sees some very interesting remarks. Also on the 6 August in the Joint Sitting Mr Sinclair added to the words used by Senator Jessop in trying to hoodwink the people and to fool them about the real reason we introduced this legislation. Mr Sinclair said that people from the Australian Antarctic Territory, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, the Coral Sea islands, Heard Island, Macdonald Island, the New Guinea Trust Territory-which, of course, has its own charter now-Norfolk Island, Ashmore and Cartier Islands-would seek representation here. That is the sort of smokescreen that Government senators and their representatives put forward to try to fool the people into believing that we were doing something corrupt and were not being genuine in our endeavours. I think that they stand condemned for that. Mr Sinclair further said in the same speech:

SPEECH.PARA: This measure is one of a series of measures. It is interesting to note that of the 6 measures that we are considering at this Joint Sitting, three in fact relate to representation either by distorting electorates in order to determine the number of members in the House of Representatives or by distorting the numbers in the Senate in order to ensure the probability of a Labor majority in that chamber. This legislation is completely repugnant to honourable senators and members on this side of the chamber on the same basis as it was on each of the 3 successive occasions when it came before both Houses of this Parliament.
