It is for that reason that I intend again to vote against it. I believe that it does not enhance the opportunities for democratic government in this country.

Again I ask Senator Kilgariff: What does he think about those remarks which were made by a very senior member of the party of which he was once a member? He was a member of that party when he was elected to this chamber. He resigned for reasons best known to himself to join the Liberal Party. I have quoted the remarks made by senior members of the now Government. All of their remarks denigrated the Australian Labor Party and sought to deprive the people of the Territories of representation in this chamber. As I have said, last Tuesday week it was interesting to listen to the remarks of the Prime Minister, supported by Senator Carrick. It will be very enlightening for honourable senators opposite, who may not have been here or read what was said, to hear his remarks. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who is very much in the news these days, at the Joint Sitting asked:
What is the Government doing about the people of the Territories-
He also referred to Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Christmas Island, Norfolk Island, Ashmore and Cartier Islands and the Coral Sea islands. He continued:
There is one man on a meteorological station on one island. Is the Government going to send him here to look after himself as the Senate representative?
That is the sort of stupid argument put forward by senior party members to try to prevent the people of the Territories from having a voice in this chamber. Even Mr Killen said:
I would not expect honourable gentlemen and ladies opposite to be thrilled by that observation--
He was talking about all the Bills before the House-

But the simple truth is that to add 4 new senators to the Australian Parliament at this time would hardly convey the impression that the Government had a glorious sense of redemption, had a high sense of purpose. Those who come later will say of this decision that it represented a monumental piece of folly.

Have we ever heard Senator Kilgariff, the late Senator Knight or the now Senator Reid repeating those words? I repeat them: 'Those who come later will say of this decision that it represented a monumental piece of folly.' If those people agreed with what Mr Killen said-he is still a senior Minister in the Government-they would resign immediately from this Parliament. They would be genuine and resign and say that they agreed with what the members of their party said about their being in this place. But, of course, they will not resign; not on your life! Mr Killen, when talking about the Bill, said:

The purpose of this Bill, or rather the effect of it, will not be to give people representation in this Parliament. The Bill represents the most significant assault ever on the Australian Constitution. If this Bill is carried, becomes an Act and remains a valid Act of Parliament, it will be the most significant de facto alteration ever made to the Australian Constitution.

Those are words of a senior member of the now Government which were uttered to try to hoodwink the people into believing that the Labor Government, under Mr Whitlam and particularly under the Minister responsible for this legislation, Mr Daly, was doing something dishonest. The members of the present Government even mentioned that in their speeches.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting I was relating to the Senate my concern at the attitude of the present Government when it was in opposition to having in this chamber representatives from the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. I was quoting from some of the statements made by various senior members of the then Opposition and now very senior members of the Government. I want to quote from the remarks made by Mr Hunt, now the Minister for Transport and a very senior man in the Country Party. Whilst the Country Party from the outset opposed legislation providing for Territory representation I must give Senator Kilgariff some credit because when he was giving evidence before the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Northern Territory, of which I was a member, in its inquiry into constitutional reform for the Northern Territory he personally thought that the Territory ought to be represented in this chamber. His party did not agree with him. When it came to a vote, as the record shows, Country Party members always voted against the legislation, except at the Joint Sitting when Mr Calder who was then the House of Representatives member for the seat of the Northern Territory, was forced by some of the statements that he had made on previous occasions to cross the floor and vote with the Government on the day. I quote from page 69 of the Joint Sitting Hansard. On 6 August 1974 Mr Hunt said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be frank. This Bill is brought into this Joint Sitting in the hope that when it is carried it will provide the Labor Government with a majority in the Senate thus enabling it to achieve its philosophical and policy objectives. It is purely a political stunt that could well slow down the constitutional advancement of both the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.

I interpolate that it was a Labor government that gave the Northern Territory a fully elected House of Assembly, something that the Territory was not given under the party Mr Hunt represented and still does. He went on:

Other speakers have pointed out that it makes a complete mockery of the Senate as a States House and there are all sorts of doubts as to its constitutional validity. No doubt these will be tested in the High Court at the appropriate time.
I referred to that before the suspension of the sitting. When it was tested twice in the High Court the Liberal Party, supported by its ally the Country Party, was soundly defeated. Mr Hunt went on:

Let me conclude by saying that I am diametrically opposed to this Bill for the reason that it destroys the concept of the Senate being a States House. As the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Killen) said it shatters the constitutional framework of this country. It deals it a mortal blow . . .

Those are very interesting words when we remember the words uttered by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and by Senator Carrick in this place only a little more than a week ago. Let me go further-this is the most interesting comment, to my mind and to the mind of many of my party colleagues-and quote from what Senator Carrick said at the Joint Sitting on 6 August on the same Bill. At page 81 of the Joint Sitting Hansard Senator Carrick said:

. . . these 2 measures now before us, the Senate (Representation of Territories) Bill and the Representation Bill, are the most important in their future potential to alter the whole framework of this Parliament, of this parliamentary system and, therefore, of the structure of decision making in this country. But they are memorable for something more than that. They are memorable because the Government has produced a hybrid mule of very strange proportions.
I refer back to his remarks of Tuesday week when he was talking about Mrs Reid, as she then was. He said:
She conforms to the requirements of the Electoral Act and other legislation.

Senator Carrick had probably forgotten the words he used when he said that what the Labor Party was doing was producing a hybrid mule of very strange proportions. Yet he was very happy to welcome Mrs Reid, who is now present to this chamber. I say to Senator Reid that she ought to read some of the remarks that were made by Senator Carrick and take them up with him to see what he thought about people who might want to represent the Territories. At the Joint Sitting of 6 August 1974 in the same debate Mr Street, now the Minister for Foreign Affairs, said:
This legislation demonstrates the essential hypocrisy of the Labor Government.

We were called hypocrites because we introduced legislation which provided that the Territories should have Senate representation. So we were accused of being hypocrites. That is not the only time we were accused of being hypocrites. I now say to those people who sit on the Government side as representatives of the Territories that they ought to have another think and change their minds as to whether we were hyocrites because we in the Labor Party were the ones who gave them the opportunity to take their place in this chamber. Mr Street went on:
No less an authority than my friend and colleague, the honourable member for Moreton,--

Of course most of the people on the other side are always happy to quote from speeches of the honourable member for Moreton because he butters up his speeches with a lot of rhetoric, but when one takes away all the rhetoric one finds very little in them. They still lean on the honourable member for Moreton, Mr Killen, for a quote. Mr Street said:

No less an authority than my friend and colleague, the honourable member for Moreton, with his usual felicitous turn of phrase, in most moderate and temperate terms described this legislation as an assault on the Australian Constitution and our federal system. It would not just provide territorial representation in the Senate, as envisaged by section 122 of the Constitution; it would also provide territorial senators who would have full voting powers in the Senate. It would substantially affect that part of the Constitution referring to the establishment and working of the Senate.
Therefore this legislation is nothing short of an attempt to subvert the Constitution.

I put it to honourable senators opposite, including the two Government senators who represent the Territories that when the next vote is taken in this chamber they ought to take cognisance of what Mr Killen said and refrain from voting. If honourable senators opposite are going to be consistent and fully support Mr Killen, in all fairness they ought to refrain from voting. However, I know they will not do that because they are now members of this place despite what their party said before about what a terrible thing we in the Labor Party were inflicting upon the Australian people and how we were subverting the Constitution.

It is interesting to note from the division on that legislation on 6 August 1974 at the Joint Sitting to see the people who voted against Senate representation for the Territories. The people I am going to refer to are those very same people who took their place in this chamber on Tuesday of last week and supported the nomination of Mrs Reid. I have no objection at all to Senator Reid's being a senator because I am a member of the party which every time legislation came before the Senate on Senate representation put up a strong argument on why the Territories should be represented. So I am not objecting to Senator Reid's being a senator, but it is very interesting to see the names of the people who voted against people like Senator Reid sitting in this place. These people are still members of the Parliament and they were in this chamber last Tuesday week. They include Mr Anthony; Senator Baume, who is now sitting opposite; Senator Bonner who is present; Mr Bourchier; Mr Bungey; Mr Cadman; Senator Carrick; Senator Chaney. Even Don Chipp, who was a member of the other place at the time and who is now a senator, voted against that legislation. The list of names continues: Mr Connolly, who is still a member of the House of Representatives; Senator Davidson; Mr Drummond; Senator Durack; Dr Edwards; Mr Fisher; Malcolm Fraser; Geoff Giles; Senator Guilfoyle; Mr Hodges; Mr Howard; Mr Hunt; Mr Hyde; Senator Jessop; Mr Katter; Mr Killen; Senator Laucke; Mr Lloyd; Mr Lusher; Mr Lynch; Mr MacKellar; Mr McMahon; Mr McVeigh; Mr Macphee; Senator Martin; Senator Maunsell; Mr Millar; Senator Missen; Mr Nixon; Mr O'Keefe; Mr Peacock; Senator Rae; Mr Ian Robinson; Mr Ruddock; Senator Scott; Senator Sim; Mr Sinclair; Mr Snedden; Mr Street; Senator Townley; Mr Viner; Mr Wilson and Senator Withers. Three people were paired and can be taken as having supported that opposition to Senate representation. The tellers were Mr Donald Cameron, the present member for Fadden, and Senator Young. Fifty-four people in all.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can Senator Reid sit here?

—Senator Reid must feel very awkward sitting here today knowing that all those people on three occasions and at the Joint Sitting objected to her being here as a Territory representative. Perhaps when matters are being discussed in the party room Senator Reid ought to ask those people why they objected to people like her being in this chamber and representing the Australian Capital Territory. Their attitude is an indication of what they think of the people in the Australian Capital Territory. That is why the Labor Party now holds three of the four seats in the Australian Capital Territory. Incidentally, three of those seats are held by women. One woman, of course, is on the Government side.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Labor Party ever got the numbers in this place-it probably will after the next election-and if it introduced legislation to repeal the present legislation for representation for the Australian Capital Territory I wonder what would be the attitude of Senator Kilgariff and Senator Reid. It would be very interesting to find out what attitudes they would adopt then. Neither of them were in this place, of course, when the deliberations were taking place on the legislation that gave Senate representation to the Territories, so they cannot be accused of voting against it but Senator Baume can be accused of voting against it because on every occasion--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Mr Calder? He made his position clear.
—Senator Baume could not have been in here a while ago when--
—I listened to what you said.

—I mentioned Sam Calder. I told the Senate why he had made his position clear. If Senator Baume is prepared to look at the debate in the Hansard record he will find that Mr Calder asked Mr Speaker whether he would be allowed to sit in the corridor rather than vote against the legislation or vote for it. Of course, because of the interjections from the supporters of the then Government-the Whitlam Government-he was forced to honour some of the promises he had made in the Northern Territory. He is the only member of the National Country Party on record as having voted for the legislation. I have no doubt that had Senator Kilgariff been in this place at that time he would have supported it also because the Hansard record of the hearings of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Northern Territory shows that he said on quite a few occasions that he supported Senate representation for the Northern Territroy. Of course, his party did not.

SPEECH.PARA: I put these facts on the record to point up the double standards of the people who now sit in government. The attitude they took when in Opposition is completely different from the attitude they take now. I am sure it would be very interesting to go through the Hansard records and then in this place refer to all the contradictory comments that honourable senators opposite have made since this Government came to office. Perhaps when I have a little spare time I might do that and so embarrass again the people who sit opposite. This is one event which-I said this when I rose to speak last Tuesday-should have been mentioned at the Joint Sitting which was held on Tuesday, 5 May. Of course, under the Rules for Conduct of Business each speaker was given only five minutes. One could not put all these points in five minutes. It has taken me about 35 minutes to put all these facts together.

The attitude of this Government to Senate representation for both Territories is on the record for people to read. Senator Reid and Senator Kilgariff sit in this place and vote on legislation which they support in the main knowing that their presence here was opposed at every opportunity by the party they represent. I think the Labor Party can be proud of the fact that when in government it introduced legislation for the Territories to be represented in the Senate. The Labor Party should be given due credit for that. It gave Senator Reid and Senator Kilgariff the opportunity to sit in this place. It believes in electoral democracy in this country. It is due to the action of the Labor Party that both Senator Kilgariff and Senator Reid have the privilege of sitting in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — Today we are debating the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1980-81. This first reading debate gives honourable senators the opportunity to speak about matters other than those contained within the Bill. Today I want to talk about a tour that I went on recently into South East Asia. I was accompanied by my wife and by a very prominent official of the World Vision organisation. We left Australia on 14 April and went first to Thailand, where we spent some time. In a sense, my tour was a fact finding mission. As I have done in the past, I wanted to go into countries where the World Vision organisation, with which I am very much involved, is working on a number of projects. I thought it was appropriate that I take my wife to look at these projects because I had seen them before. We went to Thailand, the Philippines, Singapore and finally into Kampuchea and Phnom Penh.

SPEECH.PARA: We arrived in Bangkok on 14 April and decided to visit some of the refugee camps. Much has been written and said about refugees from both Cambodia, which is now called Kampuchea, and Vietnam. Australia has had a lot of experience with people who have come from these two countries. Some are called 'boat people'. As an Aborigine I find that rather ironic because from what I can gather from history most of the ancestors of the people who are in Australia today were boat people who came with Governor Phillip almost 200 years ago, and landed at Botany Bay. My fellow Aborigines and I find it rather ironic when we hear some of the criticisms about the so-called boat people coming to Australia, because the ancestors of many of the people who are in Australia today were in fact boat people.

We visited a refugee camp called Sakeo II, which is some 70 kilometres from the Thailand-Kampuchea border. In that refugee camp there are about 36,000 people-men, women and children. It appeared to me, my wife and to Roger Walker from World Vision that there were children everywhere. Whilst they appeared to be healthy and happy, one of the strange things we noticed was that there were no toys. There was nothing for the children to play with. There were people everywhere-children, men and women-living in the refugee camp.

I should now like to pay tribute to the people of Thailand for at least extending a refuge to people who have fled from countries such as Cambodia, which is now called Kampuchea, and Vietnam. At least they have been given refuge for a time. I suppose there are people who criticise the conditions under which these people live but at least Thailand is one country in South East Asia which has allowed the refugees from these countries at least to have refuge for a time. We spent almost a day at Sakeo II. The people at that refugee camp are from Kampuchea and are known as Khmers. To distinguish between Khmers and the Khmer Rouge, I should like to point out that the Khmers are people from Kampuchea who have found it necessary to flee from that country because of the things that were happening. The people at that refugee camp were living in houses that were built on stilts and had galvanised iron roofs. They were single army barrack-type dwellings.

One needs to travel to those places to realise the situation and to understand the conditions under which people live in those refugee camps. The heat is something that we as Australians-unless we live in places such as Darwin-cannot understand. The heat which they have to put up with in those camps is terrific. One of the strange things we saw which gave us great heart was that around each of the primitive dwellings the refugees were trying to grow all sorts of vegetation. It is a credit to World Vision because World Vision provided either the small plants or the seeds so that the people could grow the plants around their homes. Generally, water was caught off the galvanised iron roofs by receptacles that people had made themselves out of concrete. Water reticulation in the camp was non-existent. Yet the people were able to keep themselves clean. Their clothing was clean. Whilst they lived under exceptional conditions they were certainly trying to do the best they could.

In this camp there was a hospital which was funded and, to some extent, run by people-nurses, sisters and doctors-who are involved with World Vision. When we visited that camp we met a young lady who is a fully qualified nurse and who had spent time in many parts of the world where there were problems. She had come to serve the people in this refugee camp, Sakeo II. We looked at what the people were trying to do for themselves. I think that what they were doing is a very great credit to these gentle and wise people who have no desire to lose their culture. They had a little workshop in which they made a number of things. For example, they made soap. It might be difficult for people in Australia to understand how valuable a little piece of soap can be-a piece of soap to wash one's face, one's clothing and that type of thing. These people were so ingenious that they were able to manufacture soap out of coconut oil because they were concerned for their people and they wanted to be able to take care of themselves. In this little workshop where they made different things in an effort to preserve their culture, they even made instruments. I was presented at that camp with a type of violin which was one of the things they were making to help preserve their culture. They also made different types of tools of trade under almost primitive conditions. For example, they made tomahawks out of pieces of steel. To heat the steel to the right temperature they devised a type of blower which would keep the heat going to get the right temperature.

The aid agencies which are working there as well as World Vision are working under almost primitive conditions, conditions which they would not experience in their own country. I do not think that we can give enough credit to this type of people who are dedicated to giving this kind of service to people less fortunate than themselves. As I said, a number of aid agencies were working in that camp and I cannot speak highly enough of them for the type of work they were doing. When I think of it, I cannot help but marvel at the dedication which these people gave to God and to man. They are basically Christian people who are giving their Christian love and dedication to a people who are, unfortunately, less fortunate than themselves.

From that camp we went to visit a refugee camp called Khao-I-Deng which is only seven kilometres from the border between Kampuchea and Thailand. We were told there that at one stage the camp had housed 120,000 people. I wonder whether honourable senators can visualise what it means for 120,000 to be cramped into an area of, say, from this building to the lake and back-about 150 acres of land.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the population of Ipswich, for example?
—It is only 78,000 people, and I am talking of 120,000 people living in a refugee camp--
—Close to the population of Hobart.

—Yes, the total population of Hobart. These 120,000 people were cramped into this area. This brings me to another very serious thing that is happening in these refugee camps. What happens in these refugee camps-and Australia is as guilty of this as any other country-is that we tend to go into them with so-called compassion but what we are actually doing is carrying out a kind of brain drain. We are taking out of those camps people who should be going back into Kampuchea to rebuild Kampuchea, or Cambodia as it was called. Instead, what we are doing is draining off all the people who have the expertise, the knowledge and the understanding because they are acceptable to our country, because they can fit into our country; they can fit into the environment and the conditions in which we live in our country. But what we are actually doing inadvertently-or advertently-is creating a kind of brain drain from the refugee camps of the people who should be helped to go back into their own country to rebuild it. In the Khao-I-Deng refugee camp there were 120,000 people; there are now 49,000 people. So we can see what has happened in that camp alone. There has been a brain drain from that camp into countries such as the United States of America, Great Britain, Canada, France and Australia and other countries. We have drained the brainy people from those camps so the loss will be not to the camps but to Kampuchea as a whole. The houses in this camp were built out of bamboo and rattan and were thatched and on high stilts. Unfortunately, just before we arrived an accident occurred and a whole hospital was destroyed by fire. Sixty per cent of these Khmer are peasants or agriculturalists who have fled from Kampuchea for reasons that I will speak about later. Fortunately, or unfortunately-whichever way one likes to put it-these people have no understanding of politics. They are just simple, ordinary people who want to get back to their farms and to their rice paddies to work them and to be able to make a contribution to their own country. But because of what has happened under the Pol Pot regime-and I will be speaking about that later-they have had to flee their country. I suppose one could say that perhaps they were more fortunate than many other people in that area. But here they are seven kilometres from the border of their own country. Can anyone envisage a Queenslander, a New South Welshman, a Victorian or a South Australian having to flee from his own State and live only seven kilometres from the border of that State? What a traumatic experience it must be to be able to almost look over to one's own country with a desire to go back there but not to be able to get there because of all the kinds of things that prevent one from doing just that. The situation at the moment is that Pol Pot and his butchers-and I will talk about them later-are still at the border between Kampuchea and Thailand trying to prevent people from going back to rebuild their own country.

SPEECH.PARA: After visiting Thailand and looking at those two refugee camps, my wife and I and Roger Walker went back to Singapore. We then travelled from Singapore into Kampuchea by the airline run by Krissair which was first established by the World Vision organisation. We travelled on the Argosy, a fairly old aircraft but still very serviceable. Whilst we were made very comfortable, it was not like getting on a DC9 and flying from Canberra to Sydney. At least it was comfortable enough. We spent 5 1/2 hours on that aircraft. We travelled from Singapore to Ho Chi Minh City where we stopped for a couple of hours so that the aircraft could be refuelled and we could walk around and stretch our legs. From there we went to Phnom Penh.

I make these remarks because there are people who will say: 'Neville Bonner could have been snowed by the Heng Samrin Government and the Vietnamese'. But when we arrived at the airport we were met by a person from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. We took our suitcases and everything else to the hotel. We had a very short briefing and the person from the Ministry said: 'Senator, I am here representing the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. I have been told to ask you what you want to see'. Naturally enough, I had been briefed by my colleague from World Vision, Roger Walker, as to the types of things we should look at. The things we wanted to look at were orphanages 1, 2 and 3, the paediatric hospital which is funded and run by World Vision, the pig farming which had been re-established by World Vision, the poultry industry which was starting again and which was funded by World vision, the condensed milk factory and the textile factory. One of the two most important things I wanted to look at was the school which the Pol Pot regime turned into a prison and a torture chamber. I have some photographs of different things which I will exhibit as I continue my speech. We also wanted to look at some of the mass graves.

The experience we had in Phnom Penh was one of the most horrific experiences which my wife and I have ever had. Phnom Penh is a very sad city indeed where there are approximately 250,000 to 500,000 people. But prior to Pol Pot taking over on 17 April four years ago there were approximately 2.5 million people in Phnom Penh. Phnom Penh is a city almost as big as my city of Ipswich. It has beautiful buildings, shops and all the things which one normally would want to see in a city. Pol Pot absolutely and totally ravaged the city. He did so in such a way that it is almost impossible for anyone in this country or in any free country really to understand and visualise what happened. People were driven out of their homes on to the roads and sent out into the country. It almost defies anyone really to express exactly what happened.

I have some photographs of what happened when Pol Pot took over the city of Phnom Penh and the whole of Kampuchea. One photograph shows how 2.5 million people were driven out of Phnom Penh with nothing at all. They were not allowed to take a solitary thing out of their homes. If they happened to take things out of their homes they were shot and killed because they were regarded as people who supported the capitalist regime or were regarded as educated people. I have with me a photograph which I would be quite happy to show any honourable senator after I have finished speaking. But people-men, women and children-were driven out of the city of Phnom Penh by this terrible regime of Pol Pot. When we toured the city of Phnom Penh, as I said, we looked at the orphanages. I have some photographs which I will be quite happy to show to any member of the Senate when I have finished speaking. The things which children in these orphanages and schools remembered of the Pol Pot regime were depicted in their paintings on the walls. This photograph is of a soldier--

TALK.START.PARA: —Show them to Malcolm Fraser. He is the one who was so keen on the Pol Pot regime. Show them to your Prime Minister.

—I am speaking of my experiences, and I am sharing those experiences with honourable senators. If honourable senators do not want to listen to what I am trying to tell them, for God's sake, they should at least have the courtesy to let others listen to what I have to say.
—I am suggesting you tell your Prime Minister what the Pol Pot regime did.

—I am not playing cheap politics today. I am speaking purely and simply as a humanitarian who went to that country and saw certain things. I will have more to say later about what the Labor Government or this Government did. I am saying now that what I have to say should be of interest not only to Senator Ryan but also to all honourable senators because we are talking about humanitarianism. If some honourable senators do not know what humanitarianism is, for God's sake, they should shut up and listen to somebody who knows something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have taken a photograph of a painting drawn by young children on the wall of one of these orphanages to show what they remembered of what happened under Pol Pot. I am quite happy to show these to anyone who may be interested, not for political purposes but for humanitarian purposes. They show how the Pol Pot regime used children to drag ploughs which normally were dragged by oxen. They forced children to drag ploughs in the rice paddies. Children were forced to take the place of oxen to drag the carts taking material from one point to another. Again, I can show these photographs to people if they are interested enough to look at them. These are photographs which I took of what happened just outside this school which was used as a prison and as a torture chamber. Here is a photograph showing how supporters of the Pol Pot regime hung people by their feet, pulled them up by a block and tackle and then dropped them head first into a container of water, half drowned them and then pulled them out. They were then asked to make confessions, and when they did not they were dropped back into the container and were pulled out again. This was continued until they were exhausted. Finally, their heads were held in the water until they drowned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The worst regime in history.

—Yes, the worst regime in history. But what has the free world done about it? This is the question I ask today. The photographs that I have before me show children in some of these camps and a child in the paediatric hospital run by World Vision in Phnom Penh. I invite honourable senators from both sides of the chamber to examine these photographs. One is of a child who is actually seven months old. These children need great help from the peoples of the free world, the peoples of the West. I will have more to say about that later.

SPEECH.PARA: Still further photographs depict other aspects of the Pol Pot regime in Kampuchea. Prior to Pol Pot's takeover of Kampuchea there were 60,000 Catholics in Phnom Penh. Today zero Catholics are to be found there. That means that 60,000 Catholic Kampucheans were tortured and murdered by the Pol Pot regime. Another photograph is of a photograph on the wall of a torture chamber. Shown are children as young as six and a seven years as well as students who, when Pol Pot finally won what was called 'The War', came home and were murdered, tortured and butchered by Pol Pot.

Other photographs show mass graves. I am happpy to make them available to any honourable senator who is concerned enough to look at them. My wife and I and Roger Walker visited one of the many mass graves around Phnom Penh. Some 14 graves were opened up and the skulls and bones placed on top of the mounds. However, I would say that in that area three times as many mass graves were not opened up-so in all some 20,000 people were involved. Another photograph shows a young girl student who was tortured and murdered by Pol Pot supporters. Other photographs show the kind of thing that was perpetrated by the supporters of the regime. When they arrested someone they took a photograph of him. After they tortured him they took another photograph. After he was murdered they took a third photograph. I have before me a series of photographs of young men who were academics and were murdered by Pol Pot after they had suffered the tortures of hell. One can see that from the photographs of the bodies their throats were slit to ensure that they were dead. I have many such photographs for honourable senators to view.

I propose now to read an example of the rules of this bestial, torturous, murderous regime. Let us remember that this fiend, Pol Pot, is still alive and kicking in a part of Kampuchea; that he is supported totally by Red China and is provided with the arms, ammunition, clothing, food and other facilities that that country can furnish. We know where he is getting that support from but unfortunately, because of world politics, people are not prepared to say. The following are some of the rules laid down for inmates of this torture prison:
1. You must answer accordingly to my questions. Don't turn them away.
2. Don't try to hide the facts by making pretexts this and that. Your are strictly prohibited to contest me.
3. Don't be a fool for you are a chap who dare to thwart the revolution.
4. You must immediately answer my questions without wasting time to reflect.
5. Don't tell me either about your immoralities or the essense of the revolution.
6. While getting lashes or electricfication you must not cry at all.
While one is being lashed by electric wires, set on a handle, or receiving electric shocks, one must not cry out at all. These are laws that were laid down by the Pol Pot regime-
7. Do nothing, sit still and wait for my orders. If there is no order, keep quiet. When I ask you to do something, you must do it right away without protesting.
8. Don't make pretexts about Kampuchea . . . in order to hide your jaw of traitor.
9. If you don't follow all the above rules, you will get many many lashes of electric wire.
10. If you disobey any point of my regulations you will get either 10 lashes or five shocks of electric discharge.

But one must not cry out when all of these things are done; one must just bear it and not say anything at all. I suppose that what I am really all about is the fact that Australia as a country is not prepared to do what it should be doing to aid Kampuchea-again because of politics, a subject which I do not wish to discuss in this connection. What I am all about is humanitarianism. People in Australia and in many countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations say: 'We cannot recognise the Heng Samrin Government because it has been propped up by the Vietnamese, who invaded Kampuchea'. But why did the Vietnamese invade Kampuchea? That is the most important question for us to answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably there was no single reason.

—I suppose that there was not. The fact is that they did invade, and drove out the bestial Pol Pot regime, which was responsible, on a very conservative estimate, for the torture and death of some 3 1/2 million people. The Vietnamese drove out this beastly man and his followers. Let me compare that situation to what happened in Uganda. Honourable senators will recall that some time ago I made a speech about what Idi Amin was doing in Uganda, about his being responsible for the death of Bishop Luwum and about his many other crimes. The countries of the world were aghast at what Idi Amin was doing. Julius Nyerere of Tanzania sent in his troops. They did exactly what the Vietnamese did in Kampuchea. They got rid of Idi Amin and his forces. I suppose that in the same sense they re-established Obote as the head of the Government of Uganda. That was rightly applauded by Australia and the world. Julius Nyerere got rid of Idi Amin and his vicious, horrible troops, that did such dreadful things to the people of Uganda. The Vietnamese did very much the same sort of thing in Kampuchea. We say we cannot abide that kind of thing because it was an invasion of Kampuchea.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to get into that area. All I am saying is that here we have a country whose people are in need of help to rebuild their country, to enable them to get back on their feet and to run their own country. From my experience of talking to people at all levels in Kampuchea, not only people in the aid agencies but also the ordinary people in the city of Phnom Penh, I would say that the Kampuchean people regard the Vietnamese people, rightly or wrongly, as their saviours. Despite the Pol Pot regime, all the things I have spoken about, the photographs I have shown and the bestial treatment that they received, they regard the Vietnamese people as their saviours. I say very sincerely that if the Vietnamese people were to move out of Kampuchea tomorrow, there is no doubt whatsoever that Pol Pot and his supporters would be back in control of Kampuchea. There is not the slightest doubt in my mind, in the minds of the people in Phnom Penh, in the minds of the people of Kampuchea or in the minds of the aid agency people that that is what would happen.

I am very grateful indeed for what our Government has done in providing immediate relief for Kampuchea. We have done remarkably well in a sense because we have given immediate aid. The blockage is because we will not do anything towards the rehabilitation of the country because to do that, we say, would be to recognise the Heng Samrin Government which is supposedly a puppet government of Vietnam. Be that as it may, as far as I am concerned there is a need in Kampuchea for aid that we are capable of giving. I do not give a continental damn how we give that aid-whether we give it by recognising Heng Samrin or through the voluntary aid agencies which are more than capable of giving aid to that country.

Let me talk about some of the things that I saw in that country. I looked at the milk factory which at present is providing about 200,000 cans of condensed milk for the people of Kampuchea. Unfortunately the factory has only sufficient raw material-powdered milk, glucose and things like that-to keep it going until the end of this year. It has only sufficient sugar to sweeten the milk to keep it going until September. Where in the name of Hades will the factory get the materials to keep it going? It cannot. There is no light at the end of the tunnel.

I looked at the textile factory. I do not know how many honourable senators here today have any understanding of how textile factories work. There are a couple of textile factories in my home city, so I have a little working knowledge of what textile factories are all about. The textile factory is divided into approximately three sections. One section is where the yarn comes in and is made into cotton; the next one is where the cotton is turned into material; and the next section is where the printing and everything else is done. Because the factory does not have sufficient power only one-third of the factory can work at any one time. That textile factory employs about 800 people-500 men and 300 women. Only one-third of it is able to work at any one time. What does a textile factory mean to people? It means the difference between having clothing and not having clothing.

What really shocked my wife is that she learnt from conversation with a number of womenfolk in the city of Phnom Penh that there is nowhere in that city at the moment where a lady can buy the necessary cosmetics and the ordinary things that women need and use. They cannot be procured because they are not being produced. Yet we sit here in our ivory towers and say: 'Oh no, we cannot help them to get these industries going again because that is rehabilitation and we cannot have rehabilitation as that means recognising the Heng Samrin Government and the Vietnamese people'. I believe we can do those things. We can and must try in some way to open up a dialogue with the Vietnamese people and with the Heng Samrin Government so that something can be done in that area of the world which is so sorely in need of help. I believe we can do it.

One really serious matter is that no government in the free Western world has ever done anything about taking these people to the International Court of Justice, as we did with the nazis in Germany and other war criminals. I find it difficult to describe Pol Pot and Ieng Sary and the people involved in what happened in Kampuchea. I find it difficult even to talk of them without having an emotional feeling about the whole thing. What really shook me was that while we were in Singapore on my way home from this visit my wife and I learnt from two reputable Australian journalists that Ieng Sary was shopping in Singapore. He was walking down the street a free man. After all the atrocities that he perpetrated against the Kampuchean people he was walking down the streets of Singapore buying things in shops. Pol Pot is still alive. No one is prepared to take either of those people or their regime to the International Court of Justice as we did in the case of the nazis in Germany after the last war. I hope and pray with everything I have that some country-I hope it will be my country and my Government-will have the intestinal fortitude and the courage to initiate that kind of thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not do it while Fraser is there.

—I am not making a political speech. I am making this speech on purely humanitarian grounds. I find it difficult to understand why someone who is a so-called humanitarian would introduce politics into the whole thing. I do not profess to be the most experienced person in foreign affairs or in many of these areas, but I speak purely and simply as a humanitarian with a love of people. I have a love of people. I want to see people being given a fair go and I want to see something done so that they can retain their sense of dignity and pride in themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: The Kampuchean people are a beautiful, proud and wonderful people. Unfortunately over a number of years they have gone through the kinds of things that, fortunately for Senator Keeffe, we have never experienced in this country. We should get down on our hands and knees and thank God that we live in a country such as this.

Finally, I shall read an extract on what happened in Kampuchea. At least the people of Kampuchea and the Heng Samrin Government have taken Pol Pot and his cohorts to task. They took Pol Pot to the courts in Kampuchea and Pol Pot was found guilty of a number of charges. The extract from the article reads:

At the sitting of August 15, 1979, the Tribunal heard the Act of Accusation of Genocide committed by Pol Pot and Ieng Sary read by the Prosecutor at the People's Revolutionary Tribunal. According to this act, Pol Pot, Ieng Sary and their gang have been accused of the following crimes:
1. Systematically carrying out a plan of increasingly ferocious massacre against all strata of the population.
2. Forcible and immediate evacuation of the urban population, and systematic displacement of the rural population, causing the death of a large number of people.
We understand the number of dead is now something like 3 1/2 million people-

3. Organisation of a regime of repression and coercion in the people's communes where the population was forced to toil until exhaustion, was reduce to slavery and living conditions conducive to physical and moral destruction.
4. Destruction of all human ties, repression of thinking, negation of the human being who was reduced to a solitary slave whose sole tie is subordination to Angkar.
5. Liquidation of Buddhist bonzes, religious, believers. Systematic liquidation of intellectuals, destruction of religion and national culture.
6. Massacre of children, persecution and corruption of adolescents with a view to turning them into torturers devoid of all human feelings.
7. Thorough destruction of the national economy, bringing the population to starvation.

That was the accusation the Heng Samrin Government made in trying to bring these people to justice. They have not been brought to justice, unfortunately, because the peoples of the West, including Australia, have not had the intestinal fortitude or courage to do what this group of people have been able to do.

I hope and pray that somehow, somewhere and in some way we can see our way clear at least to open dialogue with the people of Kampuchea through their Government at the moment. I hope, and have proposed this to the Australian Government, that a delegation of Australian parlia- mentarians-I do not care from which side of the chamber they come-visits Kampuchea and not only goes into Phnom Penh, as I was able to do, but also looks at a broader area of Kampuchea and report to the Australian Government.

I was told by the Vice Minister for Foreign Affairs in Phnom Penh that any time I and my wife would be most welcome in Phnom Penh. He said that we would be welcome to look at Kampuchea. I hope that perhaps in some way and somehow we can organise a delegation of parliamentarians from this Parliament to visit that country, look at it, talk to the people, come back to Australia and make a report to the Australian Parliament. Perhaps then our Government will be able to do something for a beautiful and lovely people who are certainly more than worthy of help from the free world. The Western World should give them some help so that they can retain what they want most-to be recognised as people and to do the things they want to do and not what someone else wants to impose on them.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring up the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare entitled 'Another Side to the Drug Debate-a medicated society?'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I have the honour to present to the Senate the report of the Standing Committee on Social Welfare entitled 'Another Side to the Drug Debate- a medicated society?'. This report follows on from an earlier report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare. That report exposed for the first time a number of drug-related problems, particularly in relation to alcohol and tobacco. The report that is presented today deals with another aspect of the drug debate, namely, the use of prescription and over the counter medication. In many respects this is the first comprehensive report done in Australia on this particular aspect of drug use. None of us would like to be accused of contributing in some form or manner to the drug problem, but as a consequence of almost total community support for medication, we have all at some stage contributed to it.

Let me say at the very outset that the Committee does not condemn the use of medication in our society. On the contrary, the Committee has been quick to highlight and comment on the beneficial effects of the use of medication in our society. What the Committee is deeply concerned about is the way in which we have come to rely on, and use drugs. In particular, medication in the wrong hands or inappropriately used can have devastating results from the point of view of both the individual and the community at large. The dividing line between the legitimate use of drugs for either medical or social purposes and inappropriate use is indistinct. For example, some people are able to use analgesics or psychotropic drugs without harm but many others become dependent on them both emotionally and physically. Because of the dramatic advances made in medical treatment, particularly over the last 50 years, both the medical profession and community have placed great expectations on the use of medication.

The dramatic advances in medical science and technology have enabled us to understand many of the so-called modern disease processes more fully and this has helped facilitate the development of preventive and curative treatments. The Committee supports these advances but it believes that if the pathways controlling mood come to be fully understood and drugs which alter mood are developed, we should not accept as a norm a society in which widespread drug taking is used to treat the outcomes of social distress. The Committee believes that we have to ask ourselves whether this is the sort of society we want and, indeed, whether the need for widespread drug taking reflects serious problems in our society.

In our society the giving of medication is a symbol of caring. The symbolic gesture is an important aspect of the use of medication, quite apart from any specific pharmacological effect that it may have. The desire to give a person something to make him better is strong and in many cases, although the medicinal benefit is probably minimal, the psychological benefit may be considerable. This is not to say that drug treatment is not an important part of the total health care in our modern community. Rather, the Committee believes that the expectations of drug therapy are becoming too great and that perhaps society is becoming too dependent on drug treatment as a cure for social as opposed to medical problems. What is equally worrying is that the medical profession has been forced to involve itself not only in the treatment of disease but also in trying to cope with all sorts of social and community problems which society regards as an illness but which the profession has not been trained to deal with.

It is against this background that the Committee has written this report in the hope that the Senate, the Government and the people will gain a greater awareness of the proper use of medication in our society. I now wish to elaborate briefly on a number of major findings arising out of this report.
Development of a Data Base for Planning and Explaining Public Policies

The first obstacle the Committee came up against in trying to understand and appreciate fully the use of medication in our society was the lack of adequate data from which to draw meaningful conclusions. To date, most people have relied on Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme figures to indicate levels and trends in consumption. Far too much reliance has been placed on PBS data for policy and research purposes. In total, PBS and Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme figures represent only 74 per cent of all ethical drugs bought from pharmacies and only 47 per cent of all drugs used. In certain therapeutic classes the level of total consumption which is accounted for by PBS figures is as low as 30 per cent. The Committee, through its research, has provided what it believes for the first time in Australia a comprehensive set of figures on levels and trends of total drug consumption. In addition, the Committee has compiled figures on a selected range of drugs, in particular psychotropic drugs, which it believes give a more realistic and meaningful insight into our drug-taking patterns and habits.

The Committee believes strongly that the Commonwealth requires a more comprehensive data base and in particular one that will enable comparisons to be made from one region to another or from one community group to another. If drug taking is only masking more serious problems in our society it is essential that policy makers have at their disposal adequate comparative data to identify specific problems faced by particular groups or regions in our society. With this in mind the Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth Department of Health develop a data base which is able to give an adequate assessment of the consumption of therapeutic drugs. This could in part be achieved by purchasing data from commercial sources such as Intercontinental Medical Statistics (Australasia) Pty Ltd but the Department would still need to negotiate with manufacturers and distributors to gain more comprehensive data on hospital consumption and the sale of proprietary drugs to non-pharmacy outlets.

I do not want to go into detail at this stage about the various levels and trends of consumption of particular drugs in the Australian community. However, the Committee was able to determine from its research that over the period 1975 to 1979 the consumption of proprietary drugs from pharmacies rose slightly, the increase in consumption of ethical drugs from pharmacies was moderate and the increase in drug consumption generally in hospitals was significant. Overall, the Committee reported that total drug consumption between the period 1975 and 1979 increased moderately.

In brief, the Committee's research into the community's drug taking habits and patterns revealed the following: Approximately $55 per head is spent on drugs per annum; psychotropic drug intake is presently averaging out at around 29 daily dosages per head of population per annum; there are 4.36 prescriptions per head dispensed under the PBS per annum; there are 22.22 prescriptions per head dispensed under the Pensioner PBS per annum; there are 18.55 prescriptions per head dispensed under the Repatriation PBS per annum; hospital drug consumption has risen substantially in recent years; surveys have revealed that between 47 to 60 per cent of the population are regular users of medication; more women than men take drugs; both the very young and elderly are major consumers of medication; and an alarming number of patients do not take their medication as directed.
Drug Evaluation and Control

In an attempt to try to examine the evaluation, distribution and control procedures in Australia, the Committee continually came up against problems of non-uniformity of legislation between the Commonwealth and States, overlap of responsibility between the Commonwealth and States and the existence of a maze of committees, boards, councils and other groups that had been set up to carry out a particular function in the drug area. In addition, in the area of evaluation, distribution and control, the Committee could not accept the numerous explanations given by the Commonwealth Department of Health that it had been unable to fulfil a number of its functions adequately due to lack of resources. The Committee believes that these functions are important and have been introduced to ensure the proper regulation and control of all facets of drug manufacture and distribution. Therefore, the Committee does not accept as satisfactory the explanation of financial and manpower shortages. We believe strongly that rules and regulations are of minimal value unless there are adequate resources to ensure that they are complied with at all times. In this respect, the Committee has made a number of recommendations aimed at ensuring that all these functions can be carried out efficiently and effectively.

The responsibility for evaluation, quality and control of therapeutic substances is shared by both the Commonwealth and States. The Committee recognises that there will always be inherent problems with respect to any shared functions but the Committee believes that with careful planning and co-operation between the Commonwealth and States many of these problems can be minimised. One of the major findings of the Committee in this respect concerns the establishment of a national registration scheme incorporating a national products register. At the present time there is no comprehensive listing of all therapeutic substances produced and marketed in Australia, let alone a comprehensive evaluation of all therapeutic substances on the Australian market. It is the Committee's belief that the safety of the community is of utmost importance where pharmacological substances are involved. The inadequacy of the current system threatens that safety. The Committee further believes that a national products register without the backing of a national registration scheme will be of no assistance in the area of control. Therefore, the Committee has recommended that the national registration scheme as already outlined by the Commonwealth Department of Health be instituted as soon as practicable along with the proposed national products register.
Drug Manufacture and Distribution

The only point I wish to raise today regarding firms and people involved in manufacture and distribution of drugs concerns the way in which their long term viability is determined or influenced by government policy. The Committee has made it quite clear in the report that any policies aimed at the restructure, rationalisation or income maintenance should be devised in such a way that the demand for therapeutic substances is not increased; that is, if there is an over-supply of manufacturing capacity, pharmacies and doctors, the Committee would be strongly opposed to any policy that tried to increase the demand to match that supply. It would rather see policies aimed at coming to terms with the inherent problems associated within the supply side.
Drug Promotion

The Committee in the report has highlighted a number of problems associated with the promotion of drugs in Australia. The Committee found that advertising does tend to stereotype people and this had the potential to create a situation where drug taking becomes the norm for that particular situation. The Committee also found that there was a great deal of variability in the control over advertising in the print and electronic media. In particular, the Committee found many shortcomings over controls in the print media and as a result has made several recommendations which it believes will remedy that situation. Finally, the Committee found that advertising does play an important role in informing and educating doctors and in this regard the Committee believes that the educational content of advertising needs to be improved. The Committee has made recommendations to that effect.
Adverse Drug Reactions

No drug is free of the possibility of adverse reactions due to individual sensitivities or allergies though in many cases these may be very small. The doctor must make the appropriate risk-benefit decision when prescribing any course of medication. Because the clinical trial and evaluation prior to marketing are limited, it is necessary to adopt procedures which will enable adequate post-market surveillance and help in the early detection of any unknown adverse drug reactions. No matter how thorough the research and evaluation is prior to the release of a drug there is always a likelihood that unexpected adverse reactions may appear after many years of carefully supervised medical use. In the event that such a situation arises, the medical profession needs to be able to follow up immediately all patients who have used that drug. The Committee found that the present post-market drug surveillance and the detection of adverse drug reactions is ad hoc, is subject mainly to voluntary reporting and is limited to only a very few drugs. We are all only too aware of the thalidomide tragedy and we would not like to see similar events occurring in the future. However, under the present system of surveillance, the Committee cannot rule out that such an event will occur again. It is in this regard that the Committee has recommended the establishment of adequate and effective schemes designed to monitor and detect the occurrence of adverse drug reactions and in particular it has recommended that hospitals should be required, as part of their accreditation system, to establish adequate facilities for monitoring and reporting adverse drug reactions. The public has a right to expect that all drugs on the market are safe and effective in their specific use and that adequate checks and safeguards are still applied in the post-marketing phase.
Medication, the Solution to Society's Ills

I wish to draw to the attention of honourable senators the major findings and purpose of the report. In this report the Committee has looked at many aspects of drug use in our society. It has examined the conceptual and philosophical framework behind society's almost unquestioned faith in medication and has discussed the evaluation, production and distribution systems. The Committee has concluded that the medical use of drugs in our society has played an important role in the past and will continue to play a significant role in the future. This is not to deny that there are a number of problems with respect to the use of medication. In this report the Committee has drawn attention to a number of areas of concern and has made recommendations which would significantly improve the handling and use of drugs in the community. However, the Committee believes that the present and future use of drugs should be assessed against the broader aspects of health and not simply in the context of curative and palliative medicine. The ultimate objective of medical care of which drugs are an integral part is the attainment of a better level of community health and well-being. Even when drug treatment is effective, there is still a need to satisfy ourselves that its use is the most appropriate course of action.

It is with these matters in mind that the Committee believes that there is a need for the Australian community to declare for itself a long term strategy which takes better account of all aspects of health, both curative and preventive, and which ensures that each determinant of health is given appropriate weighting and support. Possibly one of the major contemporary misunderstandings concerns the belief that more medical care which includes not only drugs, but doctors, hospitals, health centres, et cetera, leads to better or improved health. The Committee believes that most Western nations have poured vast amounts of money, manpower and time into the medical system, not for the benefits which it confers but in the belief that such emphasis can lead to a healthier, happier and more productive society. While this belief may be undisputed from the individual's point of view, it is not at all clear from a societal point of view that this ever-increasing health care expenditure has achieved the desired result.

The report has also drawn attention to the fact that the concentration on medical care in the health area is symptomatic of society's tendency to medicalise-to coin a phrase-as many problems as possible. This approach has led society to spend more and more money on medical care. It has reinforced society's belief that individuals cannot adequately look after themselves without the assistance of the medical profession. This has placed more and more pressure and responsibility on the doctor and has made him a scapegoat when he fails to achieve the impossible. To try to measure up to patient expectation the doctor has relied very heavily on the availability of a great battery of drugs. The Committee acknowledges that this is a very complex problem and that there would be difficulties and resistance to any attempt to de-medicalise or reclassify particular illnesses or dysfunctions. Nonetheless, the Committee believes that many problems have been wrongly or simplistically diagnosed as medical matters when in actual fact such problems would be best dealt with in a broader, societal and community context. In fact, the Committee believes that for some problems it is only a societal approach which can hope to be effective in the long term. To an extent certain disorders have already become locked into the medical system and it would be difficult in the short term to try to change the way in which we treat some problems. Once again, it is in this regard that the Committee believes that the declaration and implementation of a long term strategy which will place less reliance on medication, valuable as medication is, and give greater attention and value to other determinants of health, will be the most sensible and feasible course of action.

The report has commented on the suggestion that our modern diseases have arisen primarily as a result of society's departure from the conditions of life under which man has evolved. If this is so, one could reasonably ask whether it would be feasible to return to such conditions of life in order to eradicate or modify the diseases that are presently afflicting mankind. It would appear that if we are to make progress in the improvement of society's health and well-being, not only will we have to place relatively less reliance on medicine, including drugs, but we will also have to be prepared to modify our lifestyles. In terms of modern day values, the achievement of good health is not without its costs and sacrifices. Principally, these require the denial of present pleasure for future benefit.

The Committee does see a dilemma in pursuing a course to bring about improved health within the community. Society has known for quite some time that health and quality of life are improved by taking exercise, avoiding tobacco, alcohol and other drugs, and limiting the consumption of food. The dilemma is that to promote health activities which will encourage better health is also to put at risk the long term viability of many industries and thereafter employment opportunities within our community. That is, we have come to depend very heavily on a tobacco industry, a drug industry, an alcohol industry and a refined food industry as well as many other activities which act either directly or indirectly in some degree against the attainment of good health.
What Can Be Done?

Health is about many things. Medication has played its part well and will continue to play a significant role in the maintenance of health. However, medication alone cannot promote or guarantee a health society. All aspects of health must be equally cherished and desired. Beneficial effects of medication will not be enhanced if society continues to rely heavily on the availability of pills and cures to put them back on the road to good health. Medication cannot do what indivudals are unwilling to do. What must be made clear is that the report is not advocating alternatives to drugs but rather the need to place less reliance on drugs. While the Committee sees the maintenance of health as being very much the responsibility of the individual, it recognises that governments can provide the necessary framework or incentives to enable individuals to make health promotion decisions based on relevant and meaningful information. That is, governments must ensure that individuals have access to the best information possible to improve the decision-making processes regarding health matters.

The Committee, in the report, has made a number of recommendations which it believes will lead to a healthier and less drug-dependent society. As a first step, the Committee has recommended that all governments in Australia reaffirm their support both to the concept and implementation of the declared strategy outlined in our previous report, 'Drug Problems in Australia-an intoxicated society?'. This reaffirmation should also take into account the reappraisal of that declared strategy as outlined in this report. Such a commitment in the Committee's view will help establish the necessary framework from which all aspects of the drug problem can be considered and feasible policy options developed. I am pleased to see that the Commonwealth Minister for Health has announced the establishment of a national body to draw up and implement a uniform drug strategy. This Committee will follow carefully the progress of this Commonwealth-State ministerial committee on drug strategy.

To date, the emphasis has been on the treatment of disease, not on the promotion of health. In particular, what is needed is a better balance to be struck between the amount spent on medical care and the amount spent on all other factors which have some relationship to health. The Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth Department of Heath undertake a study to obtain more information about the relative importance of all determinants of health. An evaluation study of this nature would provide a valuable insight into the relative merits of medical care, including the use of drugs, compared with all other determinants of health. This study could then be used to reassess the allocation of public funding in the area of health. The Director-General of Health, in his 1979-80 report, devoted his opening remarks to the issues and philosophy of health promotion. This Committee will also watch with interest further developments taken by the Commonwealth Department of Health in the area of health promotion.

The mass media has been used by virtually every sector of the community to promote their activities or to further the use of their products. In the same way the Government should make effective use of the mass media to get across positive messages on health to the general public. Health needs to be promoted along similar lines to all other products in the community. Therefore, the Committee has recommended in this report that the Commonwealth Department of Health undertake a pilot study to examine the feasibility of using the mass media to get across to the public effective messages concerning determinants of health other than drugs. These messages could cover such things as diet, exercise, road safety, relaxation and hygiene. In the Committee's earlier report we recommended that the Government take the initiative to discourage activities which are deemed harmful to the individual's health. In particular it recommended the banning of advertising of such products as alcohol and tobacco. The Committee once again urges the Commonwealth and State governments to act upon the recommendations made in this earlier report regarding promotion, advertising and sponsorship by alcohol and tobacco companies.

Finally, may I say that the Committee recognises only too well that there are many problems associated with governments actively supporting and promoting a better state of health and well-being within Australia. It also recognises that such changes cannot be expected to come about overnight. This is where the Committee believes that the Government should make a long-term declaration regarding the desirable state of health and well-being within the community. Such a declaration would provide a positive impetus to those activities which promote health and at the same time would give adequate warning about other activities which are detrimental to health. If we do not make a move in this direction, our health-or to be more specific, our ill-health-will come to depend more and more on members of the medical profession and the vast battery of drugs that they have at their disposal.

In conclusion, I wish to express my personal appreciation to my fellow Committee members for their contributions during the inquiry and during the deliberations which followed. I should also like to record the Committee's gratitude to the former Chairman, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume. Because of his elevation to the ministry he was unable to proceed with the drafting of the report, but his ideas and influence did have great bearing on the Committee's deliberations. In addition, I should like to record the Committee's gratitude for the co-operation and assistance received throughout the inquiry from State governments and many departments, organisations and individuals. Our thanks go also to our Committee staff. The technical nature of the report has meant that additional demands were made on the secretarial staff. They were required to familiarise themselves with the correct use of innumerable medical terms, and the committee is deeply appreciative of their dedication to the task. The Committee thanks the previous secretaries and particularly the present secretary, Peter Kiel, who joined the Committee only half way through the preparation of the report. I would also like to thank Pat Mowbray, Pam Gulloni and Elanore Gilmore for their support. Thanks also go to our personal staffs and to the various specialist staffs of the Parliament for their ready response to our many and varied needs during the inquiry. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare and as a concerned person I should like to endorse the comments made by Senator Walters on the presentation of this report, titled 'Another Side to the Drug Debate-a medicated society?'. As the title of this report suggests, the Committee has posed the question of whether we have indeed become a medicated society. My colleague on the other side of the chamber has already briefly outlined the major findings of the Committee's research into the community's drug taking habits and patterns. I would like to elaborate on some of those findings because I believe that the data that this Committee has compiled shows quite clearly that we have become a medicated society.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1977-78 Australian health survey revealed a number of what I believe are alarming facts. The survey showed that approximately one-half of the population was taking medication in the two days before the survey was undertaken. That medication was taken either on a doctor's advice or was self-prescribed. The breakdown of the figures on the population reveals that around 48 per cent of children under age five; 31 1/2 per cent of the community in the age group five to 14 years; 43.6 per cent in the age group 15 to 24 years; nearly 50 per cent in the age group 25 to 44; and over 61 per cent in the age group 45 to 64, were taking medication. Perhaps what is most alarming, nearly 75 per cent of those in the age group 65 and over were taking medication in the two days before the survey was undertaken.

The results of that survey have been known for quite some time. Unfortunately, there has been very little official comment to date on the implications and the ramifications of this apparently widespread drug-taking phenomenon. The Australian health survey, as well as other data collected by the Committee, revealed quite conclusively that more women than men take medication. In particular, nearly twice as many women as men take medication prescribed or suggested by a doctor. I am quite sure that my colleagues on the Committee would support me when I say that medication has been used to mask many problems faced by women in our community. It is a poor reflection on our society if we have to tell many women that the problem will not go away but that we can give them something to make them feel good or help them cope with their problem.

I found from the evidence that too many doctors put women into convenient boxes. They saw them as poor, distressed women trying to cope with the problem of being a mother and a wife without looking at the underlying problems that caused their distress. We find these days that many women in the bigger cities of Australia are trying to cope with too much. They are trying to cope with being mothers and with being the wage earner, the provider in the home-or at least a part provider in the home. I found that many women had the sort of day that would distress a labourer on the wharf, a man with better physical attributes to help him cope with the problems.

Many women these days have the sort of day in which they get up at six o'clock in the morning to put on the washing, get the kids up, get them bathed and ready for school, give them their breakfast, cut their lunches, get them off to school, go to work, work all day, shop on their way home in the evening, prepare the dinner, put the children to bed, do the housework, do the ironing, do the mending and all the other household tasks, then fall into bed at midnight. They then have to get up at six o'clock the next morning to repeat it all over again. That is not a life for a draught-horse, let alone a human being!

Other women in our society today are isolated at home. Because we have such poor public transport systems, because the price of fuel is so great, they have no means of getting out of their houses. They are isolated from mothers, grandmothers, aunts, or the world that they grew up in. Their only companions are small children. Small children are lovely people, but the conversation of a five-year-old, a four-year-old or a three-year-old, all day every day can be very distressing. Many of these women find themselves distressed and looking for help. There are women in our communities today who have never learned English. They grew up in another part of the world. Their mother tongue is not English. Perhaps they were not particularly adept at using or writing in their own language. They have never learned to use or write in our language and they find themselves isolated. Too many of those women finish up on the other side of the doctor's desk asking for help, and too many doctors find that the only help that they can give them is to prescribe a pill. They tell them: 'Go home. Take a pill. Become a cabbage. Forget that there are other things in the world to worry about or that you are a human being'.

Our report also discussed at some length the incidence of drug taking among children-in particular, as I pointed out, children under the age of five.
