It is distressing that the only way that society can deal with problems that manifest in small children is to give them drugs. It is distressing that so many children under the age of five have problems. At the moment, when children become ill, we take them along to the doctors and the doctors inevitably prescribe some medicine for them. Whilst I have some reservations about doctors' ability these days properly to diagnose and prescribe medication-because of the training they get-I, along with my colleagues, found it most disturbing to find that nearly 30 per cent of children under the age of five are given medication which could be self-prescribed; that is, that the parents or friends of the child have taken it upon themselves to decide what is appropriate and most beneficial for the youngster. We have doctors who, without a great deal of training in the pharmaceutical area-in some cases we were told in evidence they had no training in the pharmaceutical area-prescribe medication for children. We found in the world of the professionals that in some instances doctors had no training in the pharmaceutical area and yet they were the only people who could prescribe drugs. They did not understand what the reaction of a drug might be or the reaction of one drug on another. I find that situation alarming and appalling. I hope that those people who are in a position to look at the training of doctors in the future will look very closely at that area.

Another area about which we heard evidence was self-prescription. People had got into the habit of taking a pill. Doctors told us that it was the patients' fault and they demanded a pill. On the other hand, we heard evidence which showed that people had got into the habit of believing a pill would solve all their problems. We also found that the older a person got the more likely he or she was to have a number of prescriptions and to have a cabinet filled with bottles and boxes of potions and pills. If a daughter turned up with a child who had some ailment then it was likely, we found, that grandpa or grandma would go to the cupboard and find something that might do the child some good. We were appalled that that action goes on. We were also appalled to find that repatriation pensioners and age pensioners with ailments repeatedly went to doctors to get a prescription. They had their prescription filled, and then they put the bottles and boxes away. We found to our horror that many people felt that unless they had an ailment their pension would be taken away from them; so the whole cycle was prolonged. People who did not need medication were prescribed medication because they fronted up to a doctor to show that they were worthy of a pension. The off-shoot was that in many instances they used that material to prescribe for their entire families.

It is sad that during the International Year of the Child considerable attention was paid to the physical, emotional and sexual abuse of children, but unfortunately very little attention was paid to the chemical abuse or assault on children. From a drug manufacturer's point of view, what could be better than establishing drug-taking habits at a very early age? Once the pattern has been established it is not surprising that by adulthood the population has almost an unquestioned faith in the power and benefits of medication. I saw no evidence to show that the medical profession was taking much of a stand against that situation. In the area of drug-taking patterns and habits, it is alarming to hear statements to the effect that 45 per cent of psychoactive drugs go to elderly people, who constitute less than 10 per cent of the population. Probably only 20 per cent of drugs taken by the elderly are necessary. Forty-eight per cent of patients in a Sydney nursing home took psychoactive drugs before admission to the home, but after admission the figure rose to 92.3 per cent. A significant number of elderly people are in institutions because of drugs prescribed by doctors who failed to appreciate that the elderly have a reduced tolerance of many agents. In many cases the drug dose to elderly people should be halved. Therefore both ends of the population spectrum come in for a great deal of chemical abuse simply because other people, including doctors, have taken it upon themselves to give or prescribe medication because they believe it will be good for them. They see it as the only answer to a problem that they are not prepared to face. I agree with Senator Walters. I believe governments have a duty in this area if they believe the good of the country depends on the good health of the country.

I return to my original point, and that is: What does this drug-taking phenomenon reveal about our society? The report that has been tabled certainly does not say that all drugs are bad. On the contrary, it has gone to great lengths to highlight and emphasise the beneficial effects of medication. On the other hand, the Committee was unable to give total and unquestioned support for all forms and use of medication-that is, we are not saying that all drugs are bad, but at the same time we are not saying that all drugs are good. What we have said in this report is that drugs or medication should not be seen as the main determinant of health.

Senator Walters has already highlighted the major thrust of this report. I endorse this major thrust and believe very strongly we must, as a society, promote all positive aspects of health. We must develop preventive strategies and we must be prepared seriously to tackle those problems in society which most of our drug taking has continued to mask. Whilst health is ultimately very much the responsibility of the individual, there is still a great need for government participation in the health area to ensure that individuals have the right sort of information on which to make proper health care decisions. If we simply leave it to the private sector, every member of the community will be bombarded continually with various vested interest groups to take a pill for every ill. I take a strong view, as I have said, on the question of doctors' education. I believe they rely far too heavily on the material that is made available by the pharmaceutical companies and yet they are the only people who are allowed to prescribe drugs. They have the least education in the area and yet are the only people with the ability to prescribe. I believe this report has put medication into its proper perspective in the health care arena and if, as a community, we put medication into that perspective we will become a far healthier and happier society. I commend the report to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is in charge of the chamber because my contribution to the discussion on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1980-81 is dedicated to three aspects of his portfolio-namely, the effects of agent orange on the community in general and on veterans in particular; the problems now being encountered at two levels in relation to repatriation pensions; and the incident that took place in this city on Anzac Day. Firstly, I refer to the problems associated with agent orange and the manner in which many veterans have been affected because of their exposure to it. I take the Minister to task for his remarks passed earlier this year. He said that much of this was in the imagination or words to that effect and if it was not caused by the psychological aspects of war--
—I did not say that.

—The Minister is reported in the Press as having said that. He said the other problem was caused by sexually transmitted diseases. We realise that STD-caused problems are fairly widespread in Asian areas, but I think it is unfair to make that blanket charge so far as ex-servicemen are concerned. A veteran has given me permission to state his case publicly in an attempt to obtain justice in medical treatment and thus cure his problems caused from exposure to agent orange. The gentleman concerned, Graham Kenneth Scarce, lives in my city of Townsville. As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is taking notes I quote the file, which is No. MSS2348. This man is married. He served in South Vietnam at Nui Dat between 1970 and 1971. He was a plant operator. The young men there were told at the time that while helicopters were operating and other methods of spraying were being used in the area it was quite safe and there was nothing to worry about. In the humid Asian atmosphere most of these men wore long slacks, gaiters, boots and hat but they seldom wore shirts. Obviously, a large part of their skin was exposed to the spray. The rash on the young man I mentioned is brought about by the chemical used at that time. It disappears under some medication but reappears. On the last occasion the rash reappeared his local doctor gave him needles to stop the itching from the waistline to the hair line. He has had the rash on previous occasions but not the needles to tone down the itching.

SPEECH.PARA: In his present employment he wears light overalls. His employer is quite happy about this. Although uniforms are usually supplied for the type of work that he does with one of the major airlines, unfortunately he has to buy his own lightweight overalls. He was asked by the local doctor to be tested for agent orange exposure while he was in the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital in Brisbane recently. He was also advised by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs that there is no record of his application to have his problem accepted as a war-caused disability. Nothing happened to his claim so he put in a second claim but he was told it got lost. That is the sort of thing that is happening in some sections of the Department of Veterans' Affairs today.

At the end of my contribution to this debate I want to make a short statement because I think Senator Bonner may have misunderstood an interjection I made, but I will not include the explanation in my speech.

I have photographs of this rash. The Minister may examine them if he wishes. The rash last appeared on 17 January 1981 and gradually spread. The man was given injections to stop the itch. There are colour photographs of the body from near the groin to the left side of the body trunk and photographs of the stomach and the chest. They were taken at various stages following the onset of the rash. So there is photographic proof of how the rash spreads in periodic outbreaks. There are photographs of the rash on the lower back and the buttocks. The photographs were taken over a period of several days by the man's wife. There are photographs of the rash on the back, the stomach and under the right arm. Each one shows a very angry rash quite clearly and it can be identified without the aid of any sort of apparatus. I hope that this case will be considered.

Many other people have reported to my office in Townsville that they all have a similar complaint. They are supposed to lodge their details but nothing is ever done about them. I understand that the Minister was to go to America but we have seen no report of any findings that he made as a result of his examination of American veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not been yet.
—It was publicised that the Minister was to go earlier this year.
—I am going in June.

—If the trip was called off and the Minister is not going until June I hope he will bear some of these things in mind when he goes. Many ex-service organisations are extremely worried, as are the veterans themselves, about the long range effects, particularly on the children of the veterans who are involved. Graham Scarce has two young children, both of whom suffer from some reasonably serious disability. What I am saying applies to others. I quote from a recent article in the Telegraph about Barry Kelly and his wife Sue. Barry is also a Vietnam veteran. I will not incorporate the whole of the article but I want to read three or four paragraphs. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: One of his jobs in the mid-sixties was to spray the jungle around the camp with a backpack filled with chemicals.
'We were told it was to kill mosquitoes and the undergrowth to give us a clear field of fire', he said.
'The choppers had 44-gallon drums inside them. A big spraying arm came out and they sprayed all over the jungle and the camp site.'
Mr Kelly said the spray left a white sticky substance on the jungle foliage.
He said Australian soldiers sprayed with back-packs wearing only shorts, socks and boots and a hat.
That is similar to the experience of Graham Scarce. The article continues:
'It was some sort of insecticide in unmarked drums,' he said.
Mr Kelly is now convinced the herbicide used was Agent Orange.
Agent Orange a cocktail of the herbicides 2,4-D and 2,4,5-T, was widely used in the Vietnam war to deprive the Viet Cong of cover and food.
Mr Kelly also suffers from aggression, anxiety, severe headaches and a blistery skin rash.
He is not the only member of the family affected-the children, Jodie, 12, Jarren, 10, Sharyn, 9, and Daniel, 4 all suffered birth defects.

That is another case which has been publicised. Ex-service organisations generally, probably excluding the Returned Services League of Australia, which did not take much notice of this from the start-I will have more to say about that later-are concerned. The Legion of Ex-Service Men and Women at a national conference carried a number of complementary resolutions. The Legion's journal states:
Vietnam Veterans and other ex-service personnel should be interested to learn that the Australian Legion is trying to assist with your claims on the Government.
We are in no position to judge who is right and who is wrong but will continue to urge the Government to carry out immediate and urgent enquiries into the effects of chemicals and radiation.
The following motions were forwarded to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, from the Legion National Council, in November 1980. Acknowledgement was received in December but to date-
That is, two or three weeks ago--
no official reply has been received.
I was present at that conference. The resolutions were carried unanimously. They read:

1. 'That while accepting the long-term usefulness of the epidemiological enquiry into the effects of Agent Orange and other chemicals, Congress urges the Federal Government to initiate an immedate public enquiry into the effects of the Agent Orange programme and other chemicals; that such enquiry have wide ranging terms of reference.

Congress, therefore, urges the Government to establish a Judicial Enquiry, a Royal Commission or a Senate Select Committee. Those concerned can then publicly place their submissions before such an Enquiry and from this should flow acceptable guidelines for the processing of Agent Orange and other chemical warfare disability claims.'

2. 'That until such time as the Government commences and completes its enquiry into the effects of Agent Orange and other chemicals, or Radiation, on veterans, where a medical practitioner considers they are affected by chemicals or radiation they be granted exgratia payments equal to Repatriation benefits.'
3. 'That until the investigations into the chemicals 245T and 24D are completed the import and manufacture of these chemicals be totally suspended.'
4. 'This Congress requests the Government to establish an immediate survey into the effects on veterans of radiation, irrespective of locality in which veterans served.'
That was a series of complementary resolutions. As no reply had been received the resolutions were adopted at the congress of the same organisation in Melbourne a couple of weeks ago.

Unfortunately when the effects of agent orange became apparent a considerable time ago the predecessor of the present Minister for Veterans' Affairs decided to set up a committee of inquiry-a committee without teeth, incidentally -but it took many months for it to be established. So for all practical purposes the Department is totally ignoring the effects of agent orange on veterans.

I notice that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is retiring from the chamber. Obviously he does not intend to listen to the rest of my story about the problems in his Department. This is not uncommon in the Department, many areas of which are in a state of disarray. I am not blaming the employees of the Department. The problems are caused by Government policies and by the inability of the current Minister to grapple with a very difficult portfolio in a difficult situation. I remind him that on 9 April 1981 I put question No. 648 on the Notice Paper. It remains unanswered. I now wish to refer to those parts of the Repatriation Act which cause veterans a great deal of distress and which neither the Minister nor the senior officials of the Department of Veterans' Affairs seem to be able to cope with. In question on notice No. 648, I asked:
(1) Is any action proposed to amend s. 107VL of the Repatriation Act.
(2) Does the annual report of the Repatriation Review Tribunal (1979-80) state that the Tribunal conducted 5,165 hearings and completed 3,775 applications during the year 1979-80.
That information was included in the report. I asked further:
(3) Were 972 applications (630 entitlements and 342 assessments) referred back to the Commission under section 107VL (2) of the Act.
(4) Do delays of up to 12 months occur with many of the referrals; if so, what action is it proposed to take to rectify this state of affairs.

A rumour is now current in government circles that an amendment which is long overdue will be made to the Repatriation Act. The transfer of Repatriation Review Tribunal cases back to the Repatriation Commission constitutes a very big blockage in the pipeline in getting cases treated. It ought not to have--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was amended last week. A Bill was passed here last week to correct that.
—It did not correct it in toto.
—Yes, it did.

—I hope the Minister is right. I understand that the current rumour is that other amendments will be made to the Repatriation Act. If the Minister says that that Bill does correct the situation in toto then I am pleased about it.
—Have a look at the Bill which was passed last week.

—I will re-examine it. I will accept the Minister's challenge. Many hundreds of cases which have experienced inordinate delays are still in the pipeline. The situation is even worse because for some reason or other Service pensions have become extremely difficult to come by because of delays. Delays of anything up to three or four months can occur before some cases are handled by the Department. I should like to give an example of an ex-serviceman who wants to retire at age 60 or an ex-servicewoman who wants to retire at age 55. They usually want to program their lives so that by the time they leave their regular employment their application for the Service pension has already been made and they are in a position to receive the Service pension immediately. The situation is even worse of course, if the case involves a burnt-out digger who has qualified for pension through illness or other war-caused disabilities at an earlier age, particularly if that person still has dependent children going to school.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Department of Veterans' Affairs has a serious staff ceiling problem similar to that experienced by the Department of Social Security then something should be done. Those two Departments ought not to be forced to make their clients suffer because of their inability to obtain sufficient staff. A lot of criticism was made of Mr Lanigan when he was the head of the Department of Social Security. In spite of the problems the Opposition had with him as the permanent head of the Department of Social Security-he was very close to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and was able to keep the then Minister for Social Security under his thumb-since he has left the Department the situation has deteriorated. Now that the new permanent head has taken over the Department of Social Security I hope that sufficient staff will be provided for the various regional offices as well as the State offices and that we will overcome the problems experienced in the Department of Social Security. Perhaps Mr Lanigan was thinking of that the other day when he landed at Coolangatta airport in a Canberra Aero Club plane, and ran into two other aeroplanes.

The other rumour circulating in the Department, of course, is that Sir Richard Kingsland who has always been approachable-I have found him quite approachable when I have been dealing with difficult cases-will retire possibly in September or October this year. The rumour is that his place will be taken by Sir William Keys, the National President of the Returned Services League of Australia. If an appointment to this position is to be made from outside the Public Service I do no think it will be welcomed by many of the returned Services people, particularly those who are disabled. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who is in charge of business in the Senate at the moment can laugh his head off but that rumour is current not only in the Department of Veterans' Affairs but also in a number of other departments. This probably accounts for some of the very pro-establishment statements that Sir William Keys has been making over the last few weeks. It certainly clears the decks. I hope that such an appointment has only been thought about and that nothing will be done about it. The only way to clear the air, of course, is for the Goverment to make a full statement on this matter.

The other problem on which I want to touch briefly is concerned with radiation. All government departments have backed away from trying to find any proof of or any cure for radiation-caused illnesses. In a recent newspaper story Mr Pat Creevey who represents the Australian Nuclear Veterans Association-he is an authority on the subject-was reported as saying:

New information shows cancer deaths in 1975 among veterans of British nuclear bomb tests in Australia during the 1950s and early 1960s, were apparently more than four times higher than in the overall population.

From evidence that is given to the Labor Party from time to time I believe that is probably a very conservative increase because some figures indicate that it is even higher than that. I have asked questions of the former Minister for Social Security as the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I have been told that no surveys have been carried out, that the Government in fact knows nothing about it, that it does not intend to do anything about it, that it proposes to let the status quo remain. As a result of the incidents that took place in this city on Anzac Day I received a telegram in the following terms:
Why can RSL hierarchy get traffic law changed for Anzac Day when they cannot get the present regime to honour existing laws on veterans.

That was signed by Graham Bell, Queensland President of the Vietnam Veterans' Association. That sums up the situation. I am still waiting for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to defend his Labor parliamentary colleague in another place, Mr Ken Fry. If one looks at the Parliamentary Handbook of the Commonwealth of Australia one can examine the record of the Minister and that of the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry). Perhaps the Minister is unable to handle his portfolio because he did not join the boy scouts. I cannot see from his record that he joined the boy scouts at any stage. He was old enough to have gone to Vietnam but, judging by the executive positions he has has held in the Liberal Party, he apparently belonged to the cheer squad-cheer them as they leave and hope they do not come back; or cheer them when they come back, if they come back at all. He did have something to do in his private life because he was the Secretary of the South Australian Road Transport Association (South East Division), Inaugural Secretary of the South Australian Bulk Fertilisers Spreaders' Association, and the South East Log Hauliers' Association. I suppose that helps him to know something about the transport incidents in which some of the people in Vietnam were injured.

On the other hand, we find that Ken Fry served with the Australian Imperial Force from 1939 to 1945 and served overseas in New Guinea, Borneo and South East Asia as a member of an infantry batallion. Obviously when Mr Fry speaks he does so from a background of wide experience. I was very disappointed at the letter I received from Sir William Keys addressed to me and dated 1 May 1981. I should like to refer to some of the passages which are quite insulting. He stated:

You will be aware of problems that have developed over Anzac Day arising out of the efforts of a group of women calling themselves 'Wimmin Against Rape'. This group both last year and this year have attempted to participate in the Anzac Day march and wreath laying ceremony.

I do not know that there is anything strange about that because I have seen members of bowling clubs, golf clubs, boy scout associations, girl guides and schools all tag onto Anzac Day march. Some of them, of course, have never seen a shot fired in anger. Certainly the little ones have never seen a shot fired in anger and I hope that they never will. They have been encouraged to participate in these sorts of demonstrations by senior officials of the RSL. I do not condemn the RSL as an organisation; I condemn some of the people who have achieved top ranking status in the RSL and who are very much the hawkish type, who are part of the establishment and who are anti-working class. They use this status, usually at the State level, to obtain a knighthood. One seldom sees them obtaining any Australian order-even an Australian knighthood, for those who still believe in knighthoods. The letter goes on to state:

You are also aware that the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Michael Hodgman, has caused the Traffic Ordinance to be amended to provide for it to be an offence for a person to disturb or disrupt the Anzac Day Parade or the ceremony conducted at the Australian War Memorial. In addition, the amending Ordinance now provides for it to be an offence for persons to act in a manner likely to disturb or disrupt such parade or ceremony or engage in conduct offensive or insulting or likely to give offence or cause insult to such persons taking part in such a parade or ceremony.

I think the organisation known as Wimmin Against Rape is quite a legitimate organisation. It is entitled to demonstrate peacefully. I understand that that was all its members wanted to do. Had they been allowed to do that, the chances are there would have been no problems at all at the Anzac Day ceremony. A well-known Anglican churchman in this city has suggested that there should be a way around the problem and that there ought to be representations by any democratic organisation entitled to participate in this sort of ceremony. In a further paragraph Sir William states:

It is an occasion on which the Nation remembers those who have died in war and pays an appropriate tribute. That tribute itself in the march, the service, and the laying of wreaths is the clearest expression of the cost and the ugliness of war. In this way, the Anzac ceremonies are a most moving and effective appeal for peace.

By not allowing constituent bodies or bodies that have a right to show publicly their dislike of war and of the things that happen in war the RSL, which controls Anzac ceremonies in some areas of the country-not in many areas-allows the hawks associated with the hierarchy to display a total ignorance of democracy. In fact it even tried to suppress democracy in this city by getting the Minister-the Minister is very much to blame too-quietly to put in an ordinance providing this sort of effect on the local scene. On the next page Sir William stated:
The group of women to which I have referred were this year organised by the 'Canberra Anzac Day March Collective' and the League believes that they have certain political objectives.

How would anybody know whether they have certain political objectives? I suppose the League would say it is non-political. The great majority of sub-branches are non-political. People from all walks of life and from all political parties who have the qualifications join the RSL. But there are some areas-Canberra is apparently one-where democracy does not apply inside the RSL. Sir William Keys, by writing this type of letter and by publicly doing similar things, obviously indicates that he is one of the establishment people. He further states:
Prior to Anzac Day this year, this group had organised workshops on April 3,5,12, 18-20 inclusive, and on the 22.

How would Sir William Keys know this was done unless he had inside knowledge-probably from members of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation or one of the other security intelligence organisations-about where they met and what they did? It would appear that he had a plant somewhere in the organisation who was able to assist either him or the police. The latter part of the letter-it is fairly lengthy-states:
There has been a great deal of publicity in all forms of the media that the amending Ordinance has infringed the rights of individuals.

I understand that this ordinance will be talked about in this place at another time. I do not want to go into all the details and start putting up an argument, but I stress that this ordinance was brought in in circumstances which are less than satisfactory. It gave Sir William Keys the opportunity to come out with a very tough letter such as that, which I think is less than democratic. It is an insult to people who belong to the Returned Services League. Mr Fry took up the cudgels on behalf of the women involved. In one of his Press statements he said that he was quite ashamed about what happened at the local level. At that time he felt ashamed to be a member of the RSL. Then the RSL got highly excited and took out resolutions suggesting that Ken Fry ought to be expelled from the RSL. That is another negation of democracy and of the so-called objectives of the Returned Services League.

I also took out membership in the RSL. The last time I saw anything like this happen was in the 1940s when a McCarthy-like witch hunt went on inside the RSL, allegedly to make communists leave the organisation. There were, of course, in World War II communists who were killed in action. Two of them were members of my battalion. Both did not come back; they were killed in action. Apparently, it is all right to be a member of the Australian Services, to belong to a political organisation which most of us do not support and to be killed in action. But some people would not do anything for such people if they returned, whether or not they were maimed, nor would they let them join an ex-services club to help their own comrades. At that time I was a delegate to the south-eastern district of the Returned Services League, or the Returned Soldiers', Sailors' and Airmen's Imperial League of Australia, as it was in those days. My credentials were questioned because I was a militant unionist and a member of the Labor Party. A Macarthy-like smear campaign went on inside the RSL at that time. If Sir William Keys had been around no doubt he would have been one of the commanders of that smear force.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to that boorish old war-horse, Yeo?

—He was in charge at the time. He was one of the hawks. In fact it was only advancing age which caused him finally to be defeated. I was defended at the south-eastern district meeting by a member of the Liberal Party who gave an assurance to the assemblage that I certainly was not a member of the Communist Party and had never been a member. I was a member of my own political party which was opposed to his, he respected me for it and we had a good personal friendship. It was only because of his intervention that I was not expelled from the RSL at that time. Because it was an embarrassment to some of my more conservative friends who belonged to the Country Party, I think it was called then, and the Liberal Party-in the early days of the Liberal Party-I decided to resign from the RSL. I remained outside it for about three years until the McCarthyists had run out of hot air. Then I rejoined and had continuous membership from 1946 to 1949. I have had continuous membership from 1951 to 1981, this year. I am a financial member of two sub-branches. I am a member of the incapacitated sub-branch. One needs to be more than 50 per cent incapacitated to become eligible for membership of that branch. I am also a financial member of my local sub-branch. I have a good relationship with everybody in the two sub-branches, regardless of our political outlooks on anything. It angers me that this sort of thing should happen in the bush capital. The problem that Ken Fry encountered was taken up very well by a local resident who wrote to Sir William Keys defending Ken Fry. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: My father, now 89, believed that he fought in World War I for democracy. The inscription on one of his medals suggests that the ''Great War'' was for maintaining and defending civilization.
I was in the US Army from 1949 to 1952, during the Korean war. I also believed that we were in that war to condemn totalitarianism and to defend democracy.

I am now an Australian citizen. I believe that civil rights of citizens are of paramount importance in our democracy. I am not on the ''left''. I handed out 'how-to-vote' cards on behalf of the Liberal party at the last election.
There is a man, a local resident, who belongs to a conservative organisation who also is highly disturbed at what he saw. He went on to state:

But I am very upset at the actions of the RSL in trying to reserve for itself the right to make a public witness on Anzac Day. That is a day for all of us to give our testimony to the horrors of war, as we remember the dead.
I commend to you the editorial in the Canberra Times on Saturday last.
That was a very good editorial which I do not propose to incorporate in Hansard. I suppose everyone has read it. He went on to state:

I am particularly distressed that the RSL should see fit to criticize Mr Ken Fry the Member for Fraser, in whose electorate I happen to be, for his honest, sincere and democratic statements. I do not support his party, but I respect him as a man and as a citizen. He does well by the members of his electorate. He is right to support the freedom of our fellow-citizens, including women, to participate in Anzac Day activities, in ways they find appropriate. Your organisation owes him, and the members of his electorate, an unreserved apology. He continues to fight for our freedom of speech, of public assembly, of dissent from majority opinions.

Is not that what democracy is supposed to be all about? Are not we supposed to demonstrate, to participate and to indicate how we feel about things, even though we may be in the minority? The writer adds:

Because of my job in education, I am well aware of the feelings aroused amongs most young people (and they are very fine young people) as a result of RSL actions vis-a-vis the Anzac Day march. At the conclusion of a Sunday service on 26 April our young people expressed their shock to think that police had arrested many women for following their consciences. Those arrested included a few students, and at least one member of the religious denomination to which I belong, the Society of Friends. They are not 'militant lesbian Marxists' . . .
That label was put on them by a Federal politician who is a member of the Liberal Party. He ought to be ashamed of the expression that he used. The writer continues:

I can assure you that any attempt to victimise these freedom-seeking and freedom-loving citizens will be counter-productive to your organisation, which is, surely, in need of good not adverse opinion in the community at large.
The writer concludes:
Might I urge the RSL to recognise that civilians also suffer and die in wars.
The writer has signed his name to it and has told Mr Fry that it can be used publicly. The letter is there for anyone who wants to read it.

In summary, there are a number of things that this Government has failed to do and continues to fail to do. It looks as if the future will be equally bleak. Agent orange victims are not being properly dealt with. The onus must fall on the shoulders of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) who, apart from saying that it is an STD problem, or a psychological problem, will not do the right thing by them. He has dismissed their complaints publicly in that way. It was a scandalous and disgraceful statement to make in fobbing off the matter. No attempt has been made by the Government-again it comes back to the responsibility of the Minister-to see that a proper survey is carried out to ascertain how many people in the community are suffering from radiation as the result of the explosion of bombs which took place under the protection of previous Liberal Party governments.

The pension situation is also bad. There are inordinate delays in the payment of service pensions. I accept the Minister's assurance that recent amendments will remove the problem. I am not sure that they will, but I hope that they do. On the other side of the coin, I am not suggesting that anybody should resign from the RSL. I would like to see everybody join it and take control away from the hawks, who have turned into a vehicle for political propaganda in several areas, though not largely at the sub-branch level. I would hope that as a result of open discussion such as this improvements and corrections will be made. I am reminded of what was said by the Premier who was present in Parliament House last night. He came to take home the bank but went home with the petty cash. When Indonesia invaded East Timor he sent a telegram of congratulations to Indonesia. That is the sort of hawk in the community that every one of us must fight. I am sure that the small 'l' liberals on the other side of the chamber would agree with those sentiments. I hope that the points which I have raised will be taken seriously by the Minister and that he will not continue to treat the effects of agent orange as a joke, as he did earlier this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the last week or so Federal-State relations seem to have been in fashion. Now that we have finished hearing the synthetic indignation of the Opposition it would be a good idea if we got down to real problems. There are not many political federations in the modern world-probably not more than a dozen, however loosely one might define them. Although federations have unique advantages-any other solution for Australia is inconceivable at this time and for the foreseeable future-they also have enormous difficulties. That is why, of course, not many nations have dared to try federation as a political solution. These difficulties are well known. They may be summed up as disputes over the division of powers and disputes over the division of tax revenue. We are about to become involved again in this dispute over the division of tax revenue because of the imminent renegotiation of the income tax-sharing formula. We may or may not have finished deciding the total amount to be distributed to the States. What we certainly have not yet decided is the actual relative distribution between the States. It is for this reason that I bring the matter to the attention of the Senate and because, as I shall show, my own State of Victoria is badly disadvantaged by the present formula.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I do that we should count our blessings as well as our problems. Compared with most other federations, we have a very homogeneous population-compared to India with its religious divisions, to Canada with its Quebec problem or to the United States with its negro minority-compared with those countries we are extraordinarily lucky. Our second great advantage is that we have no badly depressed States or regions. Looked at in terms of income per capita, Victoria is the richest State. If we give Victoria's per capita income a base figure of 100, then that of New South Wales is almost identical on 99.8, followed by South Australia on 97.5, Queensland on 93.6, Western Australia on 91.9 and Tasmania on 90.

It is perhaps worth noting that the spread between the richest and the poorest States has reduced sharply in the last 20 years although the order of States in regard to per capita income has changed little. Twenty years ago Western Australia was at the bottom of the table and Tasmania was next. Now those States have changed places. Although the order of States has changed little, the important thing is that the range between the richest and the poorest has dropped from 16 per cent in the late 1950s to 10 per cent now. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing these facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must emphasise that by world standards the 10 per cent range between the richest and the poorest states is very low. In Canada, for instance, the range is 40 per cent between the richest and the poorest states and in the United States it is 50 per cent. Although the average per capita income is remarkably consistent throughout the Australian Federation, there are sharp differences between the dominant types of economic activity in the various States. New South Wales and Victoria are important manufacturing as well as primary producing States. Western Australia has the highest value of production per capita of cereal grains, wool, sheep and fishing. Queensland records the highest production per capita of food, beverages and tobacco. South Australia and Victoria lead in per capita production of motor cars. Tasmania leads in paper and paper products. All States, including the Northern Territory, have very large mineral and energy resources. Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia have petroleum or natural gas. New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria have coal. Tasmania has hydro-electric power. Queensland and the Northern Territory have uranium. New South Wales and Queensland have lead, zinc and copper. South Australia and Western Australia have iron ore. Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory have bauxite. All States have some other minerals as well. It also needs to be recognised that the mineral and energy resources of Queensland and Western Australia are very large by world standards and that the present rate of economic and population growth in those two States is higher than those of the other four States.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the differences in per capita incomes between the States are at present relatively small, there are significant differences in the capacities of the various States to provide comparable government services without imposing unreasonable taxes or burdens on their citizens. The factors which contribute to those differences between the States are numerous. There is a difference in the capacity to raise taxation. There is a difference in natural resource revenues. There is a considerable disparity in population in each State. There are differences in the age structure of the population of each State. There are differences in the dispersion or density of population. There is disparity in the physical size of each State. There are differences in the physical and economic environments. It follows that if the capacity of State governments to provide services and the tax burdens imposed on State residents are to be roughly equal, some differential payment must be made to State governments by the Federal Government. The concept of differential payments is not in dispute-certainly not in Victoria. It is the amount of the difference that is the issue.

The Federal Constitution made provision for three kinds of fiscal transfers from the Commonwealth Government to the States. First, there was a tax sharing arrangement whereby the Federal Government transferred to each State at least three-quarters of the net customs and excise revenues derived from consumption in that State for a minimum period of 10 years after Federation. That has now lapsed. Secondly, after a transition period the Commonwealth Government was required to transfer all its so-called surplus revenue to the States on such terms and conditions as this Parliament thought fair. The Commonwealth very understandably has never had any surplus revenue, so that has effectively lapsed too. Thirdly-this is the key provision-by section 96 of the Constitution the Commonwealth Government can grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as this Parliament thinks fit. That power has been widely used far beyond anything dreamed of by the authors of the Constitution. It has enabled the Commonwealth to interfere in many matters-for example, education-which by the Constitution are exclusively a State preserve.

In the early years of Federation equalisation grants were made to the various State governments under section 96, but those were so blatantly pork-barrelling exercises and the whole procedure was so unscientific that in 1933 the Commonwealth Grants Commission, as it is now called, was instituted as a semi-judicial body, independent of Parliament and political influence, to consider applications from the States for grants of financial assistance under section 96. Initially the task of the Grants Commission was to consider claims from South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania for special grants and to formulate criteria for the assessment of the amounts. On such criteria the Grants Commission in 1936 said that special grants should be determined by the amount of help found necessary to make it possible for a State, by reasonable efforts, to function at a standard not appreciably below that of other States. Very little has changed to alter that attitude over the years. Section 5 of the Grants Commission Act 1973 defines a grant of special assistance to the States in almost identical words.

However, the task of the Grants Commission was soon complicated by a radical change in the taxing power of the States. At the time of Federation income tax was a preserve of the States. The Federal Government levied no income tax. In fact the first Federal Budget for a full year was for $21m, of which just under 80 per cent came from customs revenue. The pressures of World War I forced the Commonwealth Government into the income tax field as a temporary war time measure but, like nearly all temporary measures, it became permanent and until 1942 Australians paid two income taxes, one State and one Federal, with separate tax forms and collection systems. That became unworkable during World War II, when some people would have been paying more than 20 shillings in the pound. So in 1942 the Curtin Labor Government imposed uniform income tax. It was in fact a rather neat manoeuvre for a Labor Government. First, it declared that all Federal income tax had to be paid by an individual before any State income tax was paid. Then under war powers it requisitioned the State income tax offices and records and called up their officials. Then it imposed a very high rate of income tax which left no room for a State income tax. Finally, it offered the States reimbursement, as a section 96 grant, of the amounts they had been collecting previously, provided they stayed out of the income tax field. The States did not like it, but with no tax records or staff they had little choice but to accept.

That is substantially the situation today, although the amount of tax reimbursements has varied and a 1957 High Court decision held that the States could levy income tax if they wanted to. Perhaps they could-but how? To set up a separate tax collection system would be political suicide. Even when the present Government, under its new federalism policy, offered to collect State income taxes for the States, there was still a catch-22. If a State allowed an income tax rebate to its residents so that they paid less tax and the State received less revenue, obviously that State's entitlement under the tax reimbursement formula would be looked at very critically by the Grants Commission, since it would obviously be too well off vis-a-vis the other States. If a State were brave enough to put a surcharge on its citizens, although that would be a strong argument for an increase in its tax reimbursement share, it is most unlikely that the government concerned would be around to receive it. For those reasons the power of the State governments to legislate for tax rebates or surcharges has never been used, nor is it ever likely to be used.

The key to all this is the tax reimbursement formula. Initially, of course, it just gave the States back what they had been collecting themselves. In 1946 a new formula was introduced which increased tax reimbursements to the States each year on the basis of current population and average wages. Then over the decade to 1958 the criterion was gradually modified to a so-called 'adjusted population' basis which took account of population density and the number of school age children. This was a reasonably fair system-at least in the circumstances of the time-but over the following years it became seriously distorted by events such as the incorporation in the formula of special grants given to South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania; special grants to Queensland; and the effects of the takeover of the South Australian and Tasmanian railways and of the transfers of payroll tax and tertiary education. All those events resulted in the relativities between States being seriously distorted by the mid-1970s.

The present situation is recorded in a series of 'Points of Understanding' adopted by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the State Premiers in June 1976. These points set out the basic elements of the personal income tax sharing scheme when it commenced operation at the beginning of the 1976-77 financial year. The scheme was to be related to personal income tax and not to company tax or any withholding taxes on interests and dividends. The States were to be given a guaranteed percentage of personal income tax. This figure was to be made certain by being incorporated in a Commonwealth Act. The percentage figure was initially 33.6 per cent of the estimated income tax of the current financial year, but by a 1978 amendment of the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act it became 39.87 per cent of the preceding year's income tax take.

As announced last Monday week, this year it is proposed to reduce the figure to 38.32 per cent of last year's income tax take, but this will require an amendment of the Act. Of course, it is up to the Parliament to decide whether it passes the amendment. It has been suggested-this too will require an amendment of the Act-that it should in future be about 20 per cent of the total Federal revenue rather than about 40 per cent of income tax revenue. This will probably be to the disadvantage of the States for, with the dropping of automatic indexation, income tax collection is likely to rise faster than the rest of Federal revenue.

Be that as it may, the total tax reimbursement entitlement for all States under this system is first determined, as was done last Monday week, and then comes the division between the States, as will be done later this year. The breakdown of the amounts between States, which appeared in last week's newspapers, is all speculation based on the existing formula. I do not think the States which get the most controversially good deal at the moment-Queensland and Western Australia-should spend their money yet. Victoria and New South Wales should not give up hope.

In the scheme adopted in 1976 the initial per capita relativities between the States were to be the same as those in the preceding year. Subject to certain conditions and to any absorption of specific purpose payments, these relativities were to be carried forward into subsequent years so as to maintain the proportionate relationships between the per capita entitlements of the States. The four less populous States were to continue to be entitled to apply to the Commonwealth Grants Commission for additional grants. Most important of all, there was to be a periodic review of the relativities between States. Advice for this review was to be sought from an independent body and the first review was to be made by 30 June this year.

In 1977 it was agreed that the review should be undertaken by a special division of the Commonwealth Grants Commission consisting of six members. One of those was appointed on the joint nomination of Victoria and New South Wales. Two others were nominated by the remaining four States. Of course, three were nominated by the Commonwealth. The principle to be followed was that the payments to the States should enable each State to provide, without imposing taxes and charges at levels significantly different from the levels of the taxes and charges imposed by other States, government services at standards not appreciably different from the standards of the government services provided by the other States.

In the course of the review the special division was charged to take account of the different capacities of the States to raise revenue; the differences in the amounts required to be expended by the States in providing comparable government services; and to examine the matters that influence the determination of State factors and any event that has occurred since those State factors were determined that, in the opinion of the special division, affect the appropriateness of the continued application of those factors. The terms of these guidelines are of crucial importance, as are also the matters upon which the guidelines are silent. There was no mention, for instance, of the different budgetary practices and accounting procedures between the States. There was no direct reference to the difference from State to State in capital and recurrent expenditures. There was no mention of the role of loan finance in provision of government services by each State. There was no definition of the range of government services that were to be reviewed. A question that comes to mind on this last point is: Will the review be limited only to services which are financed from the State Budget. It is important to realise that this will be the first time that the relativities between States in tax reimbursements will have been looked at comprehensively.

If the special division of the Grants Commission does its job thoroughly-I am sure it will-there will, of course, no longer be a need for any of the States to apply to the Grants Commission for additional money because the relative disadvantages will have been eliminated by variations in the rate of per capita tax reimbursements. In a little more than a month we will know the answers to all our queries as to how the Grants Commission deals with this most complex problem. Nothing we say in this chamber will, I am sure, alter the conclusions of the Grants Commission. I am equally sure that these conclusions will go at least some way to rectifying the financial injustice suffered by Victoria in recent years.

Because some honourable senators do not seem to comprehend the nature and extent of these injustices and because some have brought in totally irrelevant issues, such as protection, I think it is necessary to explain the problem in some detail. I will explain in some detail in a few minutes the reason protection is totally irrelevant to this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the 10-year period to 1957-58 the tax reimbursement share for each State was increasingly determined on an adjusted population basis so that in 1958-59 Victoria was receiving almost its population's share of the total grant; that is, 26.63 per cent of the total grant for a population that was 27.83 per cent of the Australian total. This slight drop below the population share arose because the adjusted population formula made special allowance for the number of school children in the population and for the area of the State.
—That is fair enough.

—Yes, as I said, it was certainly relatively fair in the circumstance at the time. But since that period, Victoria's position has deteriorated progressively for three reasons. First, there was the incorporation of claimancy grants to Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania in the tax reimbursement formula. Victoria's share fell dramatically in 1959-60 because that was the first year in which the special grants paid to those States in the previous year were included in the base for the purpose of calculating the distribution of funds. In later years, each of these States was 'bought out' of claimancy; and this involved a permanent addition of claimancy grants to tax reimbursement grants with a net result to Victoria's disadvantage.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, there were special additions to other States' grants. South Australia and Tasmania had their railway systems taken over by the Commonwealth with little offsetting adjustment of tax reimbursement grants. In this way, South Australia gained $25m and Tasmania gained $3.3m relative to other States. During the period 1965-75, Queensland had its grants unilaterally increased by $2m a year giving a total permanent addition relative to other States of $20m. New South Wales and Victoria did receive special additions for a limited period but these have now lapsed. Thirdly, there were the effects of the transfers of payroll tax and tertiary education. Victoria has a relatively more highly developed tertiary education system and a relatively greater taxable capacity for payroll tax than most other States. When transfers of responsibilities were made in both those areas, the method of calculation of the accompanying offsets disadvantaged Victoria and New South Wales in relation to the smaller States.

The consequence of these three factors has been that Victoria now receives a significantly lower share of the financial assistance. It has 27.27 per cent of the population-almost identical to what it was in 1958-but receives only 22.65 per cent of the financial assistance grants. This is a drop of almost 4 percentage points since 1958, and that represents a lot of money-about $200m a year. The arguments for Victoria receiving such a low proportion of income tax funds can only be that Victoria has a significantly higher State taxing capacity than other States or that the cost of providing equivalent services is significantly less in Victoria than in other States, or both.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope this puts in perspective some of the nonsense that has been talked about protection in this chamber. Protection is decided on a national basis in the interests of the national economy. None of it goes directly to State governments. I have mentioned the only significant benefit that comes indirectly to State government revenue. I happen to think on economic grounds that tariffs are far too high and that Victorians, far from being advantaged by tariffs, are seriously harmed by them. For tariffs keep key resources in capital and skilled labour locked up in inefficient industries, whereas if tariffs were reduced and the resources released, the magnificent infrastructure of Victoria-a central position, cheap power, good roads, rail and sea communications, a skilled labour force and a sophisticated financial structure-would result in Victoria being much wealthier. If the dead hand of excessive tariffs imposed by the Federal Government in what is thought to be the national interest could be removed, Victoria would benefit enormously. What we are talking about is the revenue of the State governments and payroll tax is the only significant way in which protected industries help State government revenue.

Of the government take from this oil in 1979-80 only $89m went to Victoria and $2,270m went to the Commonwealth.
—And to other States.

—Yes, indirectly to other States. Of course, there are other ways of raising taxation from miners. The Queensland Government has an ingenious method. Rail freight charges for mining projects in Queensland are not set according to a fixed scale but are negotiated separately for each project. The rate consists of three components-capital costs, operating costs and the profit to the State. The rail infrastructure for each project is in effect paid for by the mining company and given to the State Government.

SPEECH.PARA: How does the system work? Under a system developed by the Queensland Treasury in the late 1960s called the 'security deposit' system, the mining company lends the Government the money required to build the rail facilities. The loan is later repaid at the same time and at the same rate as the company pays the Government an additional capital component in the freight rate. The net effect is that the company pays for the construction of the Government's railway. The operating cost component is calculated by the Railways Department in Queensland on a rate per tonne per kilometre. The profit to the State, which is known in the industry as the 'excess rail freight', is calculated by the Queensland Treasury as a flat rate per tonne but in the individual freight rate negotiations the capital component is determined by the infrastructure requirements of the project concerned. Negotiations focus on the operating cost-profit figure but the Queensland Treasury keeps the operating cost, and hence its profit, a closely guarded secret.

Although the exact profit from the freight charged on any project is not known, even by the owner of the project, the 1980 Queensland Budget Papers show that overall rail freights are more profitable to the State Government than mineral royalties. In 1979-80 the Queensland Government raked in $78m in royalties and $108m in excess rail freights from the mining industry. These figures, I am glad to say, are the subject of constant scrutiny by the Commonwealth Grants Commission which has in recent years added a high percentage-80 per cent in 1978-79-of the excess rail freight revenue to the mineral royalty figures for Queensland to make that figure fair in the comparative overall State table. In looking at these two items-payroll tax and mining royalties-and recognising that the other potential areas of State revenue do not vary significantly from State to State, one can see that Victoria is not particularly well off in its revenue raising capacity and is certainly not as well off as Western Australia.

If Victoria is to receive a lower per capita reimbursement of income tax revenue, the only justification must be that it is cheaper to provide services in Victoria than it is to provide equivalent services in other States. But is this true? In 1979-80 Victoria spent 33 per cent of its Budget on education, 12 per cent on hospitals and health, 11 per cent on railways, 9 per cent on debt charges, 5 per cent on police and 3 per cent on welfare. Roads funding, incidentally, is outside all State Budgets. It is provided for in part by Commonwealth grants for roads, which are heavily biased in favour of the less populous States. In addition to the Commonwealth grant, Victoria in 1979-80 spent a further $118m on roads, outside the Budget, from the proceeds of motor taxes and petrol licence fees. All States make similar road provisions outside their Budgets.

Let us look at each of the other principal Budget items to see which are more expensive in larger, more dispersed States compared with a smaller State such as Victoria with a very large urban population. I shall deal with education first. That takes nearly one-third of the Victorian Budget. According to the Schools Commission there is no significant difference between the costs of educating a child in the city and in the country. There are offsetting factors both ways and the end result is very much a line ball in each State. Three quite different factors influence the level of State government expenditure per capita on education. First, there is the ratio of school age population to the total population. Then there is the proportion of the school age population actually attending school. Finally, there is the ratio of enrolments in government schools to total school enrolments. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table setting out these figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you taken into account the higher percentage of school age children in the population of Western Australia?

—That is not quite true, as the honourable senator will see if he examines the table later. I think the significant figure is the ratio of school age population to total population. Western Australia, after Tasmania, has the second highest ratio. How do the other States compare in these categories? New South Wales and Victoria have the lowest ratios of school age population to total population, but New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania have the highest proportions of their school age populations actually attending school. New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland have the highest proportions of school students in non-government schools and South Australia and Tasmania have the highest proportion of school students in government schools. Incidentally, the total number of school age children is decreasing in all States except New South Wales and Western Australia, where there has been a very small increase. I do not think any significant weighting of per capita tax reimbursements is warranted on the grounds of the costs of education.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to hospitals. On a comparative basis Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania have an above average number of public hospitals and government nursing home beds per thousand of population. New South Wales has about the average number but Victoria and South Australia have considerably less than the average. New South Wales and Western Australia have well above the average numbers of private hospital and nursing home beds for every thousand of population and Victoria is approximately 30 per cent below the average.

All these figures do not help us much. They show what the various States have, not what they need. There is no real evidence that hospital running costs are higher in the country than in the city or that particular States are healthier than others. The only obvious differential factor is the number of old people. Old people are the greatest consumers of health care resources and States with greater numbers of old people will inevitably be committed to greater health expenditure. Queensland has the highest number of old people in proportion to total population. It is followed by New South Wales, South Australia, Victoria, Tasmania, and Western Australia, which has the least number of old people in proportion to population. However, the range between the top and the bottom is only 1.61 percentage points, which would not justify a substantial discrimination between States and the order would most certainly not justify discrimination against Victoria and New South Wales in favour of Western Australia and Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you define old people?
—They are people aged over 65 years.
—Not just the way they feel?

—No, it is not on the way they feel. Some honourable senators might be in that category but I do not think we should bias redistribution grants in favour of senators. We might do it for State Premiers. Until the recent decision on the Jamison report, Commonwealth contributions to hospitals-about half their running costs-were made as specific purpose grants. The trouble was that States with the most expensive and inefficient hospital systems-Victoria, according to the Jamison report, has a relatively efficient one-at the commencement of the cost sharing arrangement continued to receive proportionately more funds than States which had attempted to move with the times, to remove wasteful and inefficient services and facilities and to concentrate on providing appropriate services to the community they served. The Jamison commission report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The cost sharing arrangements have rewarded the expensive and punished the efficient and have perpetuated rather than solved some of the main problems in Australia's health system.

The Commonwealth's contribution will in the future be added to general revenue grants to the States and the relativities will be determined by the Grants Commission. This decision is to be warmly welcomed for I am sure that the Commission will evolve a formula based on population, with perhaps some slight weighting for the proportion of old people. This will be fairer to all concerned, and will give a much better deal to Victoria than it gets at present, although for this year it will be operating under the old formula which seriously disadvantages both Queensland and Victoria.

What, then, about railways, whose losses absorb 11 per cent of the Victorian State Budget? Broadly speaking, freight services can sometimes run at a profit; passenger services always run at a thumping loss. Because of the size of Melbourne and Sydney, Victoria and New South Wales are committed to running extensive suburban passenger services and have vast losses as an unavoidable consequence. With regard to freight, Queensland and Western Australia have the highest ratio of route kilometres to population. During the 1970s all States, except Queensland, experienced a decline in the density of goods and livestock traffic as measured by tonnes carried per route kilometre, and density is the key to rail freight profitability. Putting the two together, the problems of lengthy low-density freight routes and loss-making suburban rail networks, it is hard to see why one should subsidise the other.

Then there are police forces-in Victoria, for example, the police force takes 5 per cent of the State Budget. There is strong evidence that there is greater need for police in relation to population in urban centres than there is in the country. In Victoria it is assessed that in cities of 20,000 or larger there is a need for one policeman for every 350 people; in towns of between 6,000 and 20,000 the ratio is one to 530; and in communities of less than 6,000 it is one to 1,000. Although the cost of maintaining a policeman in a rural area is somewhat higher than it is in a capital city, the main cost of law enforcement is salaries. There is no possible reason why Victoria and New South Wales, with their enormous urban populations, should be disadvantaged in police finance in relation to States with dispersed populations.

The Federal Government bears the main responsibility for welfare. The States have a supporting role. In Victoria 3 per cent of the Budget goes on welfare. In this welfare field, the main needs are the great urban areas, far more than in the rural areas. In the welfare field there should, if anything, be a bias in funding towards Victoria and New South Wales.

I have now been through all the major components of the State Budget. It is obvious that on the cost of providing equivalent services there is absolutely no justification for the heavy bias against Victoria in the income tax reimbursement scheme. There is one further issue with which I must deal. It has been claimed that, although Victoria fares badly on the tax reimbursement formula, it is adequately compensated by above average specific purpose grants and works and borrowing programs entitlements. These claims are false. Let us look at each of them in turn. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the States' specific purpose payments and works and borrowing programs.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In neither area, that is, the specific purpose grants and works and borrowing programs, does Victoria get better than its population share. Victoria has 27.3 per cent of the nation's population. It receives 25 per cent of the specific purpose payments and 27.3 per cent-that is, its exact population proportion-for works and borrowing programs. So Victoria just holds its own on works and borrowings, and drops even further behind with its specific purpose payments. So much for those two red herrings. Incidentally, in relation to the works and borrowings program, the only area where Victoria has its fair share, the States have full responsibility for meeting the interest and redemption costs on borrowed funds. Hence the 9 per cent of the State Budget which goes in debt charges.

SPEECH.PARA: I apologise to the Senate for the many financial details I have felt it necessary to use to support my argument. State relativities are a most complex subject and are, as was recognised nearly 50 years ago, quite inappropriate for the Parliament to determine. Nevertheless, it is important that the Senate, which was designed as a States' House, should understand the issues involved. Victoria is not asking for a special deal. It is asking only for justice. I have confidence that the Grants Commission will come up with a fair solution. It is up to us to see that its recommendations are speedily implemented. In the 48 years that the Grants Commission has been in existence, its recommendations have always been accepted and implemented by the Federal Government. So it must be with these recommendations, whether or not they go as far as Victorians would like. Of course we must recognise that if some States get a larger share, others will get a smaller one. With the levelling of per capita incomes and the greatly increased wealth of Queensland and Western Australia, it is inevitable that the loading of income tax reimbursements in their favour will be reduced. For a long time now the main financial burden has been borne by Victoria and New South Wales. In our changing economic environment, the relative status of South Australia and Tasmania has remained roughly unchanged. Queensland and Western Australia will have to shoulder a greater share of the burden. I hope that they will accept their new, more responsible status, with dignity and pride.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the four-way squabble was going on among Government senators while Senator Hamer was speaking, I thought it must have reminded them of recent Government party meetings.
—We are very friendly.

—And the party meetings are not. I speak today about a change to the Export Expansion Grants Act made by Statutory Rule in 1980. The present Export Expansion Grants Scheme arose from a 1977 election promise. It was enacted in 1978 and proclaimed in November of that year. Meat was included as an eligible product for the financial years 1977-78 and 1978-79. It then became and remains ineligible. Grants are determined by increases in the value, not the volume, of eligible products in a grant your vis-a-vis the base period, which is the average value of exports-the base period being a term used in the Act for the financial years 1974-75 to 1976-77.

SPEECH.PARA: The original Act excluded from consideration meat exported to Canada and the United States under quotas granted by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation-the AMLC. The AMLC replaced the Australian Meat Board on 1 December 1977. That fact is highly significant. Quotas granted by the Australian Meat Board were not excluded from consideration when assessing export expansion. All meat, including Australian Meat Board quota meat exported in the base period, and to some extent in the qualifying period, was counted. Comparable exports under quotas granted by the AMLC were not. Thus the base period was inflated relative to the qualifying period, and the assessed export growth in that period reduced accordingly. That was the law until Statutory Rule No. 127 was gazetted on 30 May last year, almost a year, I stress, after meat ceased to be an eligible product.

Statutory Rule 127 removed quotas to the United States and Canada granted by the Australian Meat Board from consideration in assessing export growth and grant entitlement. That rule deflated base period exports and to a much lesser extent the qualifying period in 1977-78 only, and increased the Commonwealth's liability to pay grants because it deflated the base period and therefore inflated the degree of export growth. Those facts, incidentally, can be verified in the report of Estimates Committee H which was tabled in the Senate on 12 May, page 009. I seek leave to incorporate that page in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Senator Walsh asked (p513) whether
1. The making of regulations under Statutory Rule 1980 No 127 made eligible for grants exporters who export under AMB quotas and were previously ineligible?
2. Do the regulations affect the base period exports of meat exporters to North America? and
3. What additional costs were incurred by the changes?
The regulations remove meat sold to USA and Canada under quota allocated by the Australian Meat Board from the calculation of:
(a) base years for the period 1974-75, 1975-76 and 1976-77, and
(b) grant year exports for that part of the grant year 1977-78 in which the Australian Meat Board still existed.

The effect of the regulations means that firms exporting to these and other overseas markets have had their export expansion grants assessed in relation to the increases in exports of those goods which were intended by the Act to be eligible-in the case of (a) ineligble exports are removed from the base year calculation and in the case (b) ineligible exports are removed from the grant year calculation.

Had the regulation not been made to enable the Board to process the claims as intended, the grants would have been lower because the exports of meat to the USA and Canada under AMB quota would have had to been included in the claimant's base year exports and this would not have been offset by the exports of meat to the USA and Canada under AMB quota in the 1977-78 grant year as this related to the first five months of that grant year only.
The additional costs involved as a result of the regulation is not known. They can only be obtained by re-calculating the claims of all the exporters concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same page the Department of Trade and Resources states that the additional costs pursuant to SR127 are not known and could be obtained only by recalculating the claims of all the exporters concerned. Some time ago I was reliably informed that the departmental cost estimate of SR127 was $20m. Of course, the Department of Trade and Resources does not want that cost to be known. That $20m-or whatever the final figure is-is nothing but a gratuitous, retrospective handout. Where were the diligent custodians of taxpayers' money when that $20m was surreptitiously and gratuitously handed out? No wonder a Press statement has not been issued by the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) notifying the public of that statutory rule and its implications.

SPEECH.PARA: Export expansion grants are justified on the grounds that they encourage exports. In some cases they may; in this case they cannot because the rules were changed 11 months after the product in question ceased to be eligible. An export expansion grant for a product such as meat is paid to the owner of the product, who is not necessarily the processor, at the point of export. I understand that the Mitsui company, for example, exports meat; it does not process it. The grant is paid to the owner of the product at the time of export.
