It is arguable whether that export grant completely filters back to the livestock producers who determine the level of production and indirectly the volume of exports. In this case there is no room for argument. Benefits cannot filter retrospectively for livestock sold two and three years before the new rule established an increased grant entitlement. I repeat that Statutory Rule 127 provides a gratuitous, retrospective handout which will cost approximately $20m.

I cannot believe that even this Government is sufficiently negligent with taxpayers' money, even when one considers some of the things that it did last April and before the last election, to throw $20m away in this fashion. This begs the question: Is there an ulterior motive? The fact that no official announcement or explanation of the implications of Statutory Rule 127 has been given suggests that there is. So does the turgid language in which SR127 is written. It was designed to be incomprehensible in the hope that its effects would not be detected. Did the Government succumb to pressure from the potential beneficiaries of the change? It is worth noting that the Export Development Grants Board annual report for 1979-80 lists the following organisations amongst those for whom grants have been paid to that time: Tancred Bros Pty Ltd-a director of which organisation occupies a Liberal Party seat in the House of Representatives-which received $1.72m for the financial year 1977-78; Elders Overseas Trading (Aust) Pty Ltd, which received $1.697m for 1977-78 and 1978-79; and the Anglis group, which received $2.750m for 1978-79. At this stage I do not know whether any of those grants were affected by Statutory Rule 127 since it was gazetted only one month before the closing date for that report. I do know that the export entitlement of those who had previously received grants will be increased because of Statutory Rule 127. In some cases those people who were not previously eligible for grants will become eligible because of Statutory Rule 127.

TALK.START.PARA: —And who will get the money?

—Presumably, among others, Tancred Brothers will get the money, if it has not already received it. I repeat that a director of that company occupies a Liberal Party seat in the House of Representatives. His file in John Fairfax and Sons Ltd is marked 'never to be re-employed'. The reason that it is marked that way is that he was running his own shares when he wrote a financial column. He is a director of one of the firms which will certainly benefit from the change. I am not in a position to say whether that is the reason for the change. Alternatively, was this gratuitous, retrospective handout of $20m to exporters, a pay-off for collaborating in past chicanery organised by the National Country Party and the Department of Trade and Resources, officers of which Department recently, at the direction of their political masters, made secret oral threats of bureaucratic harassment to firms which have been tardy to comply with secret directives to buy commodities which they do not want? To a significant degree we have two tiers of government in Australia. One is public and applies the rule of law and the other rules by secret, arbitrary, ministerial directive transmitted through corrupt National Country Party controlled departments, in particular the Department of Trade and Resources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1980-81 I raise some questions pertaining to South Australia. One relates to the difficulties that miners are having in Coober Pedy because of the very high price that they have to pay for diesel fuel. As a result of this Coober Pedy, which today has a population of some 5,000 people, may virtually have to close down or go out of existence. Because of the high price of fuel and the high cost of transportation into that area some 1,500 people have left Coober Pedy. Some two years ago the price of low grade opal was $60 to $80 per oz; now it brings only $10 per oz. Because of these factors it is very difficult for miners to exist in that town. Low grade opal is what miners call their bread and butter opal. As a result of prices as low as $10 per oz it is impossible to mine profitably. I believe that Chinese buyers have formed a syndicate to keep the price of opal very low. High grade opal still brings a very good price of $500 to $1,500 per oz. But high grade opal is very difficult to find. Sometimes it takes many years for miners to find a parcel of good quality opal.

SPEECH.PARA: Coober Pedy is situated on the Stuart Highway between Port Augusta and Alice Springs. It is 935 kilometres by road from Adelaide. The highway is largely unsealed. As many people know, conditions in Coober Pedy are very harsh. In summer the temperature reaches well over 40 degrees celsius. Most of the people have to live underground because of the extreme heat. Even water for household purposes that on average costs a householder in any of the capital cities $250 a year costs about $1,500 a year in Coober Pedy. The people in the area are unable to have gardens or any of the luxuries that go with an ample water supply in the city areas. Coober Pedy is the largest producer in the world of opal found in the one centre. South Australia produces 80 per cent of the world's opal and Australia produces 95 per cent of the world's opal.

Opal is a precious stone. It is much sought after in many countries. In the past opal has been a valuable income earner for Australia. In 1979, $32.67m worth of opal was produced at Coober Pedy. The capital investment per miner in the area is about $18,000 and total investment for mining equipment amounts to $18.46m. Annual operating costs run at about $3.65m. The operating costs for a miner work out at about $800 a week. The difficulty is that the high cost of fuel has increased transport costs. As I said, a miner's operating costs are about $800 a week. All their equipment runs on diesel. It is becoming impossible for Coober Pedy to exist. In 1974 the price of diesel was $11 for a 44-gallon drum, which is about 200 litres. In 1978 the price was $29.50 a barrel. In 1980 the price rose to $60 a barrel. The price of diesel is still increasing. As I said, because of the high cost of fuel Coober Pedy will go out of existence unless some help is given by the Commonwealth Government.

Coober Pedy is not recognised as a town. It is run by a progress association. The association has done a great job. It takes the place of a normal town council. In the early days the association was responsible for the building of the airfield and most of the roads. It was even responsible for the desalination of the town's water. It is a co-operative affair designed to keep prices down. As I said, water costs a householder in Coober Pedy about $1,500 a year. All the water, which is brackish and is pumped from bores near Coober Pedy, has to be desalinated.

In the past Coober Pedy has been a valuable place. It has played a part in the tourist industry. I believe if help could be given either by the State or Federal governments to overcome the difficulties that the people in this area are experiencing they will be able to survive. The real trouble is that the people of Coober Pedy do not have the finance to enable them to search for new fields. The old fields are not producing as much opal as they used to produce. The people of Coober Pedy cannot search for new fields because of the high cost of fuel. The Federal Government could provide some help through the Bureau of Mineral Resources. The South Australian Department of Mines should be out in the field to help the people of Coober Pedy overcome their problems. The people in the area did have talks with the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, some weeks ago but so far there has been no result.

I have been in contact with the people in the area. I have been to Coober Pedy to see how badly off or how well off they are and to ascertain whether their claims are outrageous. I am convinced that they have a genuine claim and that they are in desperate trouble. Arrangements have been made to seal the runways at Coober Pedy. The construction of a new hospital for the town is about to be commenced. It is vital to South Australia to have a sizeable town in this area. A lot of mineral development is going on in the area. Coober Pedy will certainly go out of existence unless the opal miners stay there. The people are facing many difficulties but they can overcome them if they are given help. They do not want the unemployment benefit. They are not the sort of people who want to go on to the unemployment benefit. They are not trained in any other field of work. If they are forced out of the area all they will be able to do is to go back to Adelaide and apply for the unemployment benefit, which will be of no benefit to anyone. I believe if they were given assistance at this time they certainly would be able to overcome their problems. It is a government responsibility. I think this Government should seriously look at the situation in Coober Pedy.

The miners in the Coober Pedy area use nitrosyl as an explosive which virtually is a nitrogenous fertiliser. Primary producers get a subsidy for using nitrogenous fertilisers but the miners at Coober Pedy do not get any subsidy whatsoever. The explosives are very expensive. In 1974 nitrosyl cost $8.40 for a 40 kilogram bag. In March 1981 it cost $25 a bag. Primary producers do not have to pay anywhere near that price. In 1974 the miners of Coober Pedy were paying $3.90 for a box of 100 detonator caps. Today they are paying $12.95 a box. In 1974 the miners were paying $36.60 for a roll of cordex, the detonating cord. Today they are paying $105 a roll. In 1974 the miners were paying $14.50 for a roll of fuses. Today they are paying $35.60 a roll; and so it goes on. The cost of living in this area is extremely high. Some of the people who have gone on to the unemployment benefit have been mistreated. A year ago a person who held a miners licence could not go on to the unemployment benefit. That situation has now been overcome, but if a person holds a mining lease he cannot go on to the unemployment benefit even if he is not producing one cent of opal from that lease. Some people have gone on unemployment benefit but because of computer processes which show that they are still holding a mining lease they have been taken off unemployment benefit and have had to wait six to eight weeks before receiving it again. The miners, in general, do not want to be unemployed; they do not want the unemployment benefit. They want some practical help from the Government. I believe that the Federal Government and the State Government should liaise so that some sensible solutions can be worked out. The miners do not want a subsidy for ever and a day. They want to be viable, and that is understandable.

There are other problems. Some miners may work for 10 to 12 years before finding a worthwhile parcel of opal. It is true, as I said, that they can go out and get their bread and butter opals and keep themselves viable. This enables them to buy fuel and food and send their children to school and everything else. It virtually does not pay to recover a low grade opal. It is nothing for a sizable parcel of opal to be worth $100,000. There is a discrepancy under the present taxation laws of this country. As I have said, some miners have lived on virtually nothing for 10 years. I know of one miner-he was very honest-who disclosed that he had found a $100,000 opal. He had to pay some $70,000 in provisional tax. He owed several people something like $15,000 and was left with about $15,000. That shows the ridiculous situation.

Primary producers can have their taxation varied over a number of years. I believe the taxation rights of miners should be looked at. I think representatives of government agencies should go to the area and make an honest report. The honourable member for Grey, Mr Wallis, has been up there many times, as have I. I have found the people to be genuine. They are hard working. They have produced many millions of dollars for the economy of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most senators have been up there.

—Yes, they have. It is a crying shame to see this area in which people have worked very hard. They have pressed the Government on other aspects. They have good schools. They have formed school committees and hospital committees in harsh country. They have really combined. I believe that they are doing a great job for Australia. I think the Federal Government should come to their assistance so that the place can remain viable.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I present Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1980-81 which, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1980-81 which I shall introduce shortly, comprises the Additional Estimates for 1980-81. In these Bills, Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made under Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1980-81. The additional appropriations total $520.9m: Of this, $432.6m is sought in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and $88.3m in Appropriation Bill (No. 4).

The additional appropriations sought in the Bills are offset to some extent by savings in appropriations made by Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2), resulting partly from the Government's determined efforts to achieve savings in expenditure wherever possible. These savings, amounting to $147.6m, are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document 'Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations', which has been distributed to honourable senators.

Notwithstanding the additional appropriations now sought, current expectations are that total outlays in 1980-81, including those financed from special appropriations, will be within one per cent of the Budget estimates. This reflects the Government's continued adherence to its policy of maintaining maximum expenditure restraint.

I now outline some of the main areas where the Government has found it necessary to seek additional appropriations in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1980-81. Included in the amount Parliament is now being asked to appropriate is $191.1m to meet increases in award rates and other wage and salary costs since the Budget, consisting of $100.7m civil, and $90.4m defence. Although the overall Budget figuring contained an allowance of $235m for prospective wage and salary rate increases in the Public Service, including defence, that amount was not then appropriated.

Under the 'Administrative expenses' vote, an amount of $3.6m is included for the Attorney-General's Department for payments to private legal practitioners by the Australian Legal Aid Office. This is partly offset by a reduction in the counterpart payments through State legal aid commissions due to delays in the establishment of the Victorian commission. The amount also provides for an overall escalation in payments to private legal practitioners.

Under the Department of Defence an amount of $7.4m is sought to cover the increased cost of fares and vehicle hire, together with a general increase in program activities above that provided for in the Budget. An additional amount of $4.5m included for the Department of Housing and Construction results from a higher than anticipated rate of expenditure on the engagement of private architects, engineers and consultants.

Under the 'Other services' heading, $5.8m is proposed for the Department of Communications mainly for locally produced television programs, originally expected to be covered by revenues from advertising through the multicultural television channels. An amount of $26.2m is required under the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs for employment retraining and assistance. The increased provision comprises $17.7m for new initiatives and increased activity under the National Employment and Training System and $8.5m under the scheme to encourage full time training of apprentices.
A sum of $9m is required under the Department of Industry and Commerce to meet increased costs of maintaining reserve capacity in government factories.

Additional significant 'Other services' provisions include: $16.5m for the Department of Defence to cover increased cost of stores and greater requirements than expected as a result of increased activities; $10.5m for the Department of Defence to meet increased cost of repair and overhaul of aircraft, ships and other equipment; $5.4m for the Department of Education mainly to cover unavoidable increases in running costs for the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority; $8.3m for the Department of Foreign Affairs, principally to cover the increased cost of wheat relating to Australia's commitment under the Food Aid Convention; and $5m under the Department of Science and Technology mainly to meet increased running costs of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Chaney) agreed to:
That consideration of the Bill in the Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for a later hour this day.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by Senator Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first reading of any money Bill, of course, provides honourable senators with the opportunity to discuss a number of matters of public interest. Some matters I wish to discuss tonight are causing a great deal of concern in our community. I refer firstly to the removal of medical benefit payments for supposedly cosmetic surgery. This has caused a lot of confusion not only in the community but also amongst medical practitioners. Let me say immediately that the term 'cosmetic' is something of a misnomer. The word 'cosmetic' in the first place is an emotive one and the implication is that this type of surgery is done only to satisfy the patients' vanity and is therefore totally unnecessary. That is not true. I will admit that some cosmetic or plastic surgery procedures are unnecessary but most procedures are very necessary for the emotional or physical well-being of people involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the biggest problem with the recent decision of the Government to remove a number of items from the medical benefits rebate schedule is that no one knew what was allowable and what was not allowable. We had a situation, as mentioned by Senator Chipp in a question I think on the day that the revised schedule came into effect, in which people were actually in hospital after having arranged to have a particular operation on a particular day but they did not know whether they were covered sufficiently to get the medical rebate. I believe that a number of operations were cancelled virtually at the last minute because people were just not sure whether they were covered. I have to admit that when I make that statement I am going strictly on what other people have told me. I have no evidence of the fact that it did happen but it is quite possible that it did.

The second problem in relation to the rash manner in which the Government introduced this particular measure is that no period of grace was allowed. The decision was announced on 30 March and it came into effect the following day, 1 April. There are still a number of grey areas. I raised a number of these matters at an Estimates committee hearing. I have since received a copy of the Press release of the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) which really has not clarified the situation for me to any great extent. It now appears that the matter is in the hands of the Department of Health in the various States which may have occasion to refer a specific matter to the Minister for clarification. Unfortunately, during the Estimates committee's investigations I referred to the National Health and Medical Research Council when, in fact, of course I meant the committee which reviews the medical benefits schedule. Be that as it may, I still believe that there are too many grey areas.

I raised at the Estimates committee hearing the case of a woman who is 40 years of age and who was severely burnt down one side of her body as a small babe. She has a tremendous amount of scar tissue and she has had no breast development at all on one side. She has already had two breast augmentation operations, the first of which was not at all successful and the second of which was successful only to a certain extent. She was informed within three months of that second operation that she would need another operation. She had planned on having that operation at about this time. But when she contacted her medical practitioner she was advised that she would not be eligible to claim a medical rebate because the operation would now qualify as breast augmentation. When I raised this matter at the Estimates committee I was informed that this particular operation would not be considered in that light and would in actual fact be covered. As her doctor has already tried to clarify the situation with the Department of Health in Western Australia-it informed her that she is not eligible-we will now have to raise the matter directly with the Minister. Perhaps it is fortunate that she is an acquaintance of mine and, therefore, has access to a member of parliament. There are many people in the community who do not have that access and who do not know where to go when these grey areas need to be cleared up. Obviously in this situation her doctor is not aware that she could be covered for rebate and he is apprehensive about performing the operation because it would commit her to tremendous expense in the event that a medical rebate does not apply.

Similarly I should like to refer to the case of a young constituent of mine, a girl of some 17 years of age who, because of a disease she contracted or for some other reason of which I am not aware, suffered a tremendous weight loss. As a result of that immediate and drastic weight loss she has heavy jowls. What she needs is a face lift. According to the Minister's schedule it is classified as cosmetic surgery and cannot be covered. The young girl's mother informed me that the girl is introspective and she will not go out in the daytime. In fact, it is a difficult proposition even to get her out of the house at night. She hides in her room when visitors call and the only place that she seems to visit is the doctor's. She wraps her neck up with a scarf and is extremely embarrassed by her condition. Her doctor has already advised her that she will require at least one facelift. Possibly because of the condition of her jowls she will need two operations.

She will not be covered under this new schedule for either operation unless her doctor decrees that they are medically necessary. Now we have to find a doctor who will in actual fact state that this is so. What this situation will produce in the community is an awareness by some sections that if they have the means to have these operations done-whether or not they may be considered medically necessary-they will be able to have them done. If they are on low incomes and, therefore, do not have the means or the access to information, they are most unlikely to have the operations done. More problems will be created in the community. I need to be able to advise this girl whether she is entitled to a medical benefit rebate. I have endeavoured to clarify the situation with her physician. Her physician tells me that he has contacted the Department of Health in his State and has been advised that this is plain and simple cosmetic surgery. Under the Minister's decree I would assess that this is so. It has to be considered cosmetic surgery but, as the same time, there is a discretion involving the words 'unless it is medically necessary'. The situation will develop in our community that a large number of people will have to seek psychiatric advice-this already occurs in the case of a woman who needs to have an abortion-so that they can have these very necessary operations. This girl's family is on a particularly low income. It is certainly not in a position to pay hundreds of dollars if this is not an allowable deduction.

As I said earlier, there are too many grey areas. The move by the Minister appears to be discriminatory. I hope that it is not, but it appears to be that way. I am moved to ask, for instance, whether any women were on the review committee. Were there any plastic surgeons on the review committee? Was the Australian Society of Plastic Surgeons consulted prior to the removal of those benefits? If it was consulted what were its recommendations? Were those recommendations taken into account? I can only presume, because of my contact with a number of plastic surgeons, they were not consulted. If their Association were consulted, its recommendations were not taken into account.

I have copies of letters from women which were written to plastic surgeons expressing gratitude for cosmetic surgery performed for breast reduction, for instance. That may on the surface appear to be purely cosmetic. I have already given one instance where it is not cosmetic. It was because of psychological disadvantages that this was necessary. Let me assure male senators that women could find over-large breasts a distinct disadvantage which would cause stress, both emotional and physical, and they do suffer physical disabilities directly attributable to being, as one woman put it, top heavy. In fact because it is such an important matter I want to read out both of those letters to honourable senators. I am quite happy to have them in Hansard, but I want honourable senators to recognise that I have removed the names and addresses of the women to preserve their anonymity. In the second instance I also have removed the name of an education centre at which one of these women is having lessons, so that there is no danger of identification or of her privacy being invaded. The name of the plastic surgeon, I believe, is not important because I am sure there would be similar letters on the files of most of the plastic surgeons who work with women throughout the country. The first letter states:
Dear Mr . . . It is almost two years since you performed breast reduction surgery for me and my gratitude continues.

The reason for this note is to say that I am now able to achieve something I was too embarrassed to attempt previously-I am learning to swim at adult classes conducted by the . . . Education Centre and am making good progress.
Thank you for having made this possible.
The second letter, which is rather lengthy but which requires to be read out, states:
Dear Mr . . .

As a result of your understanding and skill I am, for the first time in many years, learning the meaning of living and 'ordinary' everyday life without feeling the sensitivity and sometimes real humiliation suffered so many times during those years. I do not believe that anyone, excepting, of course, a compassionate Plastic Surgeon or another woman (and there are very many of them) could possibly realise to what extent an overlarge bosom can affect the afflicted person psychologically.

At the age of 61 years, I did not arrive lightly at the decision to have the breast reduction operation and vanity certainly did not enter into my thoughts. As you will recall, I left the decision entirely up to you regarding the size, shape et cetera. I had no preconceived ideas of the result: My one hope and desire was for the chance to become a normal looking woman like a lot of other people instead of feeling somewhat of a misfit. I had not been swimming for many years and I did not accept many invitations for dancing-although I was a good swimmer in my earlier years and a pretty fair dancer.

Prior to the operation I often suffered from severe backache and pain over the shoulder and neck region which I understand now was caused through the straps of my bra pulling up the weight. I still bear deep indentations in my shoulders from bra straps and I rather imagine these will be a lasting reminder of my earlier problem. Now I have no backache and no shoulder pains. I walk more confidently and feel I am not so accident prone as I was when I was so top heavy. I had quite a few accidents-I just seemed to fall over if I tripped a little. Once I fractured my kneecap and the surgeon then remarked that I might have been able to save myself if I had been a little less top heavy. I wish other women with my former problem could obtain the relief I have done and I would be only too happy to personally speak with anyone who needed reassurance as to the result of such an operation.

I have an additional problem which, perhaps, some others may not have as I have been a chronic asthmatic for many years and prior to the operation I was on cortisone tablets and an electric machine-in addition to the usual Ventolin and Becotide. I could not walk far without the aid of an inhaler and the strain of breathing was very much aggravated by the weight I had to lift with each breath. Since the breast reduction I am managing to get by with the aid of only the Ventolin and Becotide. I still get asthma but do not get so distressed: After all, I have a few kilos less to hamper me.

I regret that this letter is a lengthy one but I feel so appreciative for your help and your understanding of my feelings, I wanted to convey my gratitude to you. Compassion is what is so badly needed by women in my former predicament and that is what I feel you gave. Please accept the sincere thanks of . . . Yours truly

As I said, those letters express the gratitude of people who see the operation not as cosmetic surgery but as a necessary operation to enable them to live, as one woman expressed it, a normal life and to become a normal human being.

I said earlier that the decision of the Minister appears to be discriminatory. I outline my thoughts on that just a little further. I do not do so intentionally to disturb any members of the Senate, but I tell the Senate that I will speak about some very personal areas of both the female and the male anatomy. It appears that for a women to have breast augmentation and attract the rebate it could be performed only after mastectomy or if there were no breast development at all. Those two areas would be considered medical rather than cosmetic. I have already outlined one instance in which it is not possible because breast augmentation has already been done.

Breast development in males is not normal so I have to ask: Is the rebate applicable to males who are female impersonators or trans-sexuals? I see nothing at all in the Minister's statement to show that that is not so, but if it is, why is it that a man can have a breast augmentation operation and can collect the full medical rebate but a woman can have the operation and not be able to collect any rebate? If a young girl is conscious that her breasts have not developed to the same extent as those of her peers and as a result is too embarrassed to go swimming or to play sport, she has to put up with that disability unless she can pay a fair amount of money. I believe it is approximately $700 or $800. If a male feels inferior because of the lack of normal development of his testicles or if his testicles atrophy because of a disease or injury, he is able to have a prosthetic replacement and his medical benefits rebate is not affected. The two matters are identical. Surely if one is to be considered cosmetic the other also has to be considered cosmetic.

I am given to understand, as a matter of interest, that no more than 100 of those operations are performed in any one year, but surely numbers are not being taken into account. Surely what we are looking at, at the moment anyway, in the Minister's statement is a further disadvantaging of disadvantaged people in the community. There does not appear to me to be any provision for exceptional conditions, although I was assured at the Estimates committee hearing that there is a discretion if an operation is considered medically necessary. We have to ask who makes this determination of whether it is medically necessary. Is it the Department of Health in each State? If so, is it reliant on the determination of one person in that Department whether a matter is medically necessary? Obviously, the departmental advice to remove certain items from the Schedule was given to the Minister as a certain way to save a relatively small amount of money. I think it is approximately $3.4m.

I do not know how one measures money against personal distress, emotional distress or physical distress, but the manner in which these items were to be removed was administratively easy to carry out and to police. That may be so, but are we talking about the policing of regulations or are we talking about human misery and human suffering? From my contact with the Department, as I have already stated, the position appears to be a little confusing. I have some information that leads me to believe patients and doctors who contact the various departmental officers about particular deserving situations have been advised-only over the telephone, of course-that the operations for such deserving cases should be itemised under other, inappropriate item numbers. In other words, it is being suggested to them that the item could be quoted as something other than it is so that the medical benefit can be retained by the patient. That virtually encourages doctors to commit fraud. An ironing out process will have to be conducted in the Health Departments of the States if that is happening. I have no reason to believe that it is not. I have already given an instance in which I was given information that was the complete opposite of what was given to a medical practitioner. Both inquiries were made of the same department, in the same State.

Plastic surgeons have always agreed that a number of operations are most commonly patient-initiated and undertaken mainly for aesthetic reasons, but not all such procedures are in that category. I apologise to anyone with a medical background who may be offended at the way in which I use or pronounce these terms but there is, for instance, bilateral melanoplasty, bilateral blepharoplasty, and bilateral augmentation mammoplasty, to which I have already referred. For those who are not already aware of the fact, that is breast augmentation.

I believe that any health scheme which is based on insurance should allow patients rebates for all recognised surgical procedures which are medically necessary. What one needs to know is who determines what is medically necessary. If a doctor determines that it is necessary for a woman to have breast augmentation and goes ahead with the operation, the woman could then be committed to pay a very large sum of money because the department will not allow a medical rebate for the operation. Face lifts perhaps fall into a slightly different category because a number of men and women in the community have become accustomed to their friends and relatives having face lifts-mostly, I would say, for purely cosmetic purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to have one but it would cost me half a million votes.

—As long as the honourable senator is against the medical rebates proposals that have been put before the Senate he does not need a face lift. However, there are situations in which people have been left with scarring of the facial tissues because of the prolonged presence of acne, which can become unsightly. Others have come to Australia from countries in which smallpox has been prevalent. Sometimes they suffer from a great degree of facial scarring. For them the only solution is to have a face lift. Paralysis of the muscles of expression can occur on one side of the face, particularly after a stroke. In those cases a partial face lift is necessary to restore those muscles to a seemingly normal position so that the symmetry of the face is closer to normal. Lifting muscles may also assist speaking and chewing. The determination of the Minister seems to be that such an operation would constitute a face lift. We return to the question of who is to determine whether it is medically necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Particular mention is made of the reduction of eyelids. I suggest that in a number of situations such an operation would be medically necessary, but how does one determine if this is so? Are we to have doctors take before and after photographs to prove that a medical rebate is justified? I suggest that very few honourable senators have not seen, particularly in older people, marked sagging of the skin around the eyelids. I have seen cases in which the vision has been completely obscured because of excess skin on the upper lid. If an operation were medically necessary surely a medical rebate should be given. The Minister's statement is so narrow in effect that one would not know that whether it would be.

The Minister referred particularly to cases of hair transplants. I suggest that a few honourable senators might be drastically in need of that operation. I would not suggest that Senator O'Byrne would be drastically in need of it. He might be regarded as being mildly in need of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He just has a long face.

—His forehead is growing, his hair is not receding. The Minister in charge of the House, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), is not quite at that stage either, but I imagine that it will not be long before he is. Under normal circumstances, it is an operation that is carried out on men. Are we simply to say: 'If you need a hair transplant you will have to establish that it is medically necessary'? I suggest that in a number of cases it would be. People who have been burnt around the head may carry excessive scar tissue. Others may have taken drugs under prescription and not been able to tolerate them, with the result that baldness has occurred. Are we to say to these people: 'You are not entitled to a rebate'? That is what the Minister has said.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that the Minister's decision would also disadvantage pensioner patients especially. It may save the taxpayers' money but one questions whether a small saving is necessary or beneficial when compared with the amount of well-being that would be felt by the community if this were not such a grey area. I continue to use that term because I do not understand who is to determine what is medically necessary. Obviously, the doctor will not. I have already given instances in which doctors have contacted the Health Department in a number of States and have been given information different from the information I was given. I was told that it was quite acceptable for a woman to have breast augmentation because of the presence of excessive scar tissue following burning. Her surgeon was told that since it was breast augmentation it was not a medically rebatable item. This is an extremely grey area. No one seems to know, least of all, I suggest, the plastic surgeons. They do not know whether they can say: 'Go ahead and have this operation; it is medically rebatable'. They just do not know, as we do not know.

I suggest that it would have been possible to make such a determination if people were not prevented from insuring themselves for that type of surgery. Information before me indicates that the Australian Society of Plastics Surgeons agrees that patients could be expected to pay more for certain operations which may be patient-initiated even though they be medically necessary, but it does not accept that insurance should not be available. At the moment insurance is not available for this type of operation because it is considered not medically necessary. I understand that the Society suggested to the Government that cosmetic surgery be included in the top bracket of medical insurance only and that contributions be made for at least two years before claims were paid. That recommendations of the Australian Society of Plastic Surgeons was not taken up by the Minister's review committee.

One of the Society's major worries must be the effect on standards of patient care, because it is certain that doctors will continue to perform aesthetic surgery. The economics of such operations will be such that those performing them could be forced to work in much poorer facilities. We could have a situation in which certain operations would be done under local anaesthesia virtually in doctors' surgeries, when they should be done in properly medically equipped hospitals or clinics. Such surgery is subject to the usual complications of haemorrhage and infection. We may even see the development of lay clinics in which this type of surgery will be done by people who are not equipped to perform it. We will perhaps find underqualified medical people undertaking a great deal of work which should be performed by qualified medical practitioners. I think we can look forward to the development of beauty clinics where people can have a face lift if they are prepared to accept that the person who will do the operation is not necessarily medically qualified.

I want to raise also in this first reading debate the problem that I see developing with regard to women's refuges. It was not my intention to speak only on matters related to women, but these are two areas about which I feel most strongly. The situation with regard to women's refuges in Western Australia is at the moment at crisis point. Honourable senators might remember that I raised the issue of women's refuges on 29 May 1979 as a matter of urgency. At that time I moved that the following was a matter of urgency:
The need for guaranteed, continued and adequate Federal Government funding for women's refuges throughout Australia.

It is interesting to note that the Government did not oppose that matter of urgency. It expressed agreement with the views I put forward. I raise the matter now because I am concerned that the crisis in Western Australia is being heightened by State Government policy. I begin by reminding honourable senators that the first women's refuges in Australia were established by women's groups in response to the desperate need they saw in the community for women and their children to have a haven at times of emotional stress and at times when it was perhaps necessary for them to escape a situation made unbearable by physical abuse, by drunkenness, by financial oppression or even by mental oppression in their domestic situations.

I do not think it necessary for me to spend a great deal of time in this place convincing honourable senators of the genuine need that Australia's 97 women's refuges fulfil at this moment. But clearly there is a great deal of catching up to do. That is reflected by the increasing number of refuges that have been set up by the number of women and children who avail themselves of the service of those refuges. There is no question that there is a need. More than 1,460 women and 2,116 children were accommodated in women's refuges through Western Australia in 1980. Yet those figures belie the fact that many homeless women and their children are turned away not just every week but, in some instances, every night because of lack of accommodation at refuges. I can tell honourable senators, as an instance, that in March of this year 21 families were turned away in one month from the Warrawee refuge in Western Australia. Those 21 families included 50 children. Ave Maria House, which is run by the Daughters of Charity, turned away 288 women and 386 children in the period from 1 December 1979 to 30 November 1980. Because priority is given to women with small children, it is usually single and middle aged women who are turned away. I will return in a moment to look at that group.

I recognise that the Federal Government tends to acknowledge the plight of women and their children who are forced to leave their homes. It is unfortunate, I suppose, that many of those decisions to leave occur in the dead of night when the women are least able to turn to friends, family or relatives who may be able to help them. But it is not a need that the State Government of Western Australia apparently recognises. Honourable senators will be aware that the Western Australian Government and the Queensland Government are the only two State governments which do not totally fund women's refuges with the assistance of the 75 per cent paid by the Federal Government. In New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and, I believe, even in the Northern Territory, where Federal Government funding is 75 per cent, the 25 per cent is funded by State government grants. This is not the case in Queensland. In fact we have seen in this very chamber a situation, after Queensland only two years ago was given a sum of money to fund two women's refuges, in which it was necessary for deliberations to be made by the Government to give a direct grant because the Government of Queensland had refused to hand over money which was earmarked for that specific purpose.

In Western Australia the situation is that the State Government makes up only 12.5 per cent and it is up to the refuges to make up the other 12.5 per cent. Most of them-there are a couple of exceptions-make up that 12.5 per cent by the back paying of wages paid to their staff. The two exceptions are two refuges which the local councils aid by donating the actual 12.5 per cent. I would not like to think that the Federal Government was suggesting that it would be necessary for refuges to resort to lamington drives, cake stalls and that kind of thing to find the additional amounts of money. When we stop to think of the way in which women's refuges go about their affairs, the need that they fulfil in society and the amount of time spent by the women who run the refuges, we can understand that there is not a great deal of time left for fund raising. In fact they have to go begging to get the amount that is necessary for them to continue. As I said, in Western Australia the State Government makes up the 12.5 per cent, but it is still up to the refuges to make up the other 12.5 per cent. I wonder what the attitude of the Western Australian Government will be now that the Federal Government has handed to the States responsibility for funding women's refuges. On Tuesday of this week Senator Ryan directed a question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who represents the Minister for Health in this chamber. She asked:

I understand that as a result of the recently announced changes to the health care system the funding for women's refuges will be transferred to the States. Will this funding be in the form of an earmarked component of general revenue grants to the States? If not, how does the Government intend to ensure that women's refuges, especially in such States as Queensland and Western Australia, continue to receive an adequate level of funding or, indeed, any funding at all?
The Minister replied:

It is my understanding that the funds to be set aside for the purposes set out in the new health arrangements will be identified initially as being that block of funds which will cover health, the Community Health Program and the School Dental Scheme. They will eventually be absorbed into general revenue grants. I understand that it will then be for each State to examine its own priorities in relation to the particular program which interests the honourable senator. I suggest that, as a senator from New South Wales, I will be as concerned to see the response from the Government of New South Wales as Senator Ryan is concerned to see the response of any other State government. I think it will be for each State government to examine its priorities. I just observe that some years ago I assisted in setting up one of the women's refuges. I, as much as any other senator, would not like to see the program founder. It will become a matter for the States to decide in the light of their own programs and priorities.
Senator Ryan asked a supplementary question in these terms:
Am I to understand the Minister to have stated that there will be no earmarking or any other specific indication that any part of the health grant will be for women's refuges?
The Minister, Senator Peter Baume, then said:

I have already said that there will be earmarking of the total amount of money, at least initially. There will be no specific component for women's refuges within that total earmarked amount. Anyone examining what the States are doing will know the global amount of money with which they are working and their capacity to allow for women's refuges within that amount of money if they so wish.

It is those last four words that concern me because it could well be-I think in Western Australia we will so find-that it does not suit the wishes of the State Government to fund women's refuges. As I have already made quite clear by the figures I have provided to the Senate, the refuges are often full. In fact, they are overflowing. I have visited refuges when they have had mattresses in the passageways. They have had bodies-that is live bodies-lying on mattresses virtually in the kitchen of a house because there is nowhere else for them to go and they do not want to turn another family away, particularly in the middle of the night, so they make whatever arrangements are necessary. I presume one has to accept that a blind eye is turned to that situation by the various health inspectors from the departments.

As I have said, we see the refuges providing a tremendous amount of the emotional support needed when a family breaks up. We have seen the tremendous support of the people who work in these refuges. If there are any members in this chamber who have not visited a women's refuge I assure them that that is one thing they should do on a fairly regular basis. They should see the amount of support and encouragement that is given to women and children who arrive at refuges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know a lot of them will not let male senators or male members of parliament in?
—I am rather disturbed to hear the honourable senator say that.
—I am a great supporter of what you are saying but it is unfortunate that a lot of them do not let men in.

—Yes, I agree it is unfortunate. I think there is a particular reason for that. I am sure the honourable senator can understand that the refuges would feel some apprehension as they are strictly women's homes. I suggest that as I have been refused permision to visit a men's hostel we might find ourselves in the same boat. I am sure I was refused permission purely on the grounds of my sex. I find that a little disturbing too. I am sure that there would be a number of refuges in Victoria which would welcome Senator Chipp going to them to see the situation that exists there.

SPEECH.PARA: I will just illustrate the situation that pertains in Western Australia by referring to the Lucy Saw Centre. This refuge, in its 1980-81 Budget allocation, received $30,000 from the Federal Government; that is, 75 per cent of its total funding. It received $5,000 from the State Government-its 12 1/2 per cent. Therefore, the refuge is bound to finding a further $5,000. There is no way that it can avoid having to find that $5,000 because its entire budget has been based on what the Federal Government is prepared to give it. The refuge, like all refuges, receives its funding in arrears. Therefore it has to make its own 12 1/2 per cent contribution available before both the Federal and State government funding is available; it has to find money before it can get any money at all. It has to find 12 1/2 per cent of the total amount of funding it is going to get so that it can finance its operations until it gets its initial funding and so that it can attend to the needs of people. The Lucy Saw refuge predicts that for the 1981-82 Budget period it will need to find around $7,000.

I have already told honourable senators how the refuges find that 12 1/2 per cent. They back donate the pay of the staff who service the needs of the people who use the refuges. We are in a real catch-22 situation. The fact that the refuge now has to find an extra $2,000 more than last year will put an even greater strain on the refuge. It is putting an even greater strain on the people who see the need for the refuge. They have only so many hours in a day in which they can service the needs of the community in that situation. They have only so many days in a week and so many weeks in a year in which they can be prepared to work for less remuneration than they are entitled to so that they can finance the operations they are running on behalf of people.

The Lucy Saw Centre is in a depressed, low income, high unemployment area in Kwinana. The Minister at the table who is from Western Australia will be aware of just what I mean when I say 'in a depressed, low income, high unemployment area'. Fund raising is extremely difficult. Refuge workers and volunteers spend all day at stalls plus the time and money needed to make cakes and other items to be sold. On some occasions they raise a mere $140 or $150. It takes an awful lot of lamington drives, cake stalls and pot plant sales to make enough lots of $140 or $150 to get $7,000 for the funding of a refuge. Honourable senators can imagine how many raffles would be needed for them to make $1,000 profit.

The Nardine women's refuge-I have raised the subject of Nardine in this place on a number of occasions-participates in an annual street appeal with other agencies and it raises approximately $800. That does not even cover one month's operating costs; that is, Nardine's 12 1/2 per cent share of the operating costs. Local organisations cannot provide help indefinitely and, understandably, organisations such as Rotary and Apex feel that they should not have to be called on year after year to support the refuges financially. I am not saying-I want to make it quite clear-that Rotary, Apex, Lions or any of those other community service organisations do not like to be called on for funds on an annual basis. But they have an awful lot of work to do in our community, and they do it very well. I can recognise the difficulty they would have in having a constant appeal for assistance from the same organisation, albeit that the organisation is in their area and is a very worthy cause. I can still recognise the dilemma they are placed in if they have a constant begging for funds from one organisation when there are so many they have to service.

Workers at Nardine have explained to me that most organisations and individuals that make donations do so in the form of a specific item or a service. For instance, if a service organisation is prepared to donate toys for the entertainment of children, if it is prepared to donate the time for a clean-up of the yard or if it is prepared to donate the time and the equipment needed to paint the refuge, that is fine. But they do not necessarily have the funds to contribute and it is money that is vitally necessary in the running of the refuges. The money just cannot be raised because the burden on the people's time, as I have already said, is so great. The staff have already committed themselves to the work that they are doing in the community. They are committing themselves even further by back-paying their income. They pay in that way just to keep the refuge solvent. It does not necessarily mean that they have everything in the refuge that they need. They still rely on charitable organisations to provide them with the necessary equipment such as beds, linen, mattresses, brooms, brushes, cleaning equipment and everything else.

The low wages paid to the refuge staff are limited according to what the members of the committee at each of the refuges consider they are capable of raising as their 12 1/2 per cent. That suggests an even more callous attitude of the State Government in Western Australia. It is clearly in the interest of the State Government to keep funding at 12 1/2 per cent because its contribution to the running costs and wages paid at refuges is then minimised. Clearly a refuge could not afford to pay award rates to its workers. Yet, people in any industry would be horrified if they were asked to accept less than award rates or award conditions. Yet here we have a situation in which refuges cannot afford to pay award rates.

I have spoken to refuge workers and co-ordinators and it has been made clear to me that wages-that is, fair and decent wages-are not the overriding consideration; it is the amount of time involved and the need to supply a service to the people who they are there to service. To a large extent the refuges rely on voluntary assistance. When one talks to the organisers and the administrators of the refuges it is interesting to find just how many people who have used the service of a refuge come back to assist in the running of the refuge at a later time because they recognise the need and the limitations. They all come back in an unpaid, voluntary capacity. As I have said, I am most concerned that the Federal Government has abrogated its responsibility by handing over the responsibility for the funding of refuges to State governments. I am even more disturbed at the Minister's response to Senator Ryan's question. He stated:
Anyone examining what the States are doing will know the global amount of money with which they are working and their capacity to allow--
The operative word is 'allow'-
for women's refuges within that amount of money if they so wish.
They were the Minister's words. I repeat:
. . . their capacity to allow for women's refuges within that amount of money if they so wish.

I suggest that there is a great deal of concern in Western Australia, particularly among the workers in the refuges, who are worried that the Western Australian Government may not so wish. It may not have this matter on the top of its priority list where it should be. The Government may not even see it as a need. A situation is developing in Western Australia which disturbs me greatly. I refer to the attitude of the Court Government to the needs of people in the community. I beg the Minister's pardon. Did I miss an interjection?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, just a silent prayer.

—Just a silent prayer. I have another eight minutes in which to speak. I might be able to see out that period. I hope no one is in a hurry. I believe what I am speaking about is of great concern. We had a situation in which all members of this chamber, and possibly members in the other place, received letters from the women's refuge co-operative in Victoria. The refuges were concerned that their addresses had to be disclosed to Federal Government departments and if it were not they would be in danger of losing their funding. I question what will happen to that exercise. The Victorian State Government was quite happy for the address to remain undisclosed. I believe the system which works in Victoria should be working in all States. It is interesting that there have been relatively fewer violent incidents in Victoria compared with those in other States. There have certainly been such incidents in Western Australia. I refer to the degree of violence that is exhibited at women's refuges, perhaps by an irate husband whose wife has had to leave home, possibly because of his violence or alcoholism or her financial deprivation. She has left and taken the children with her and he has suspected that she has gone to a women's refuge. I do not think there is one refuge in Western Australia that has not been attacked at some time. We have had situations in which men have fired rifles in the street, possibly not with the intention of injuring anybody, but certainly expressing a warning. We have had rocks thrown through refuge windows. We have had a number of doors broken down and fences broken.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think I know of any one case in Victoria in which this has happened. Such incidents do not occur there because the addresses of refuges are not disclosed. If a woman needs to go to a refuge she telephones the one central number. If she does not have transport she can be collected and taken to a refuge. If she lives in the western suburbs the possibility is that she will be sent to a refuge in the northern, eastern or southern suburbs. She will not necessarily be sent to a refuge in her own area. I think that is a good thing. If all States worked on that basis I would be much happier and I am sure that the refuges would be also. We had a situation in which the Federal Government had determined that the addresses of refuges had to be known or funding would be discontinued. The Minister claimed that this action was necessary. I heard a senator say at an Estimates committee hearing last week that in her opinion it was necessary for these places-these were her words, not mine-to be available for inspection by the various authorities. One questions why that is so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Senator Walters said it. Did not Senator Chipp expect that it would be Senator Walters?
—Senator Chipp, that answer must come as a great surprise to you.

—I can assure Senator Puplick that it is no great surprise to anybody in this chamber. I can assure him that it is a fact. It is recorded in the Senate Estimates committee Hansard. Senator Walters said that she felt that it was necessary for these refuges to come under some degree of inspection; to justify their existence virtually, and that otherwise they should not receive any funding. I suggest that this is not the situation that we are talking about. We are talking about protecting the anonymity of people who are in desperate need when they leave home. In most instances they do not want their family to know where they are. They certainly do not want a violent husband to know where they and their children are. I wonder what the Victorian Government's attitude will be now. The Federal Government has said: 'Here is the money. If you so wish you can fund the refuges'. The Victorian Government has already indicated that it does not want to know the addresses of these refuges because it believes they are under enough inspection as it is. One presumes health inspectors go out occasionally to exercise their right to examine the premises.

SPEECH.PARA: What will happen in Western Australia? I have expressed my concern. I am sure that the Minister recognises that I have real reason to be concerned. Funding of women's refuges has never been high on the priority list of the Western Australian Government. Let me assure the Senate that irrespective of what that Government has told the women's refuges in Western Australia, if there were an expression of concern the refuges would not have the problem that they have at the moment in obtaining emergency or relief housing-half-way housing-for women whose need for the refuge is perhaps over but who are not yet in a position to return to the full community. They need a half-way house. If this matter were high on the list of the Western Australian Government's priorities a recommendation would be made at State government level that emergency housing be made available through the State Housing Commission. This has not been done in Western Australia. The Federal Minister for Housing and Construction, Tom McVeigh, has told us that if this matter has a high enough priority such housing would be provided. It is obvious that in Western Australia it does not have a high enough priority.

Under normal circumstances a member of parliament has to make representation to the State Housing Commission to obtain even emergency housing for a constituent. I am speaking of such an emergency in which a woman with three, or perhaps four children, has absolutely nowhere to go. The refuge can no longer keep her because she has been there for the maximum length of time and it needs the space that she and her children are occupying for other needy families. Such women cannot get emergency housing because emergency housing is not available. It is not available because it is not at the top, or even half way up, the priority list, of the Western Australian Government. There is a real and pressing need in Western Australia for continued funding of women's refuges. I do not believe we will get it now that the Federal Government has abrogated its responsibility in the area of health care of women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for long. I am not overexcited by the swelling numbers of senators on the benches in this place at the moment, but I will take the opportunity of putting on the record something which I hope some students, some people who are interested in social reform, will read and debate. I wish very briefly to discuss the question of alcohol and its relationship with the road toll and the kind of insanity with which we persist in this country. I begin by saying that expenditure on health now constitutes 8 per cent of national income and of that amount about 60 per cent is spent on hospitals and other health care institutions. That assumes in terms of dollars that 8 per cent of gross domestic product is $9,105.4m. Sixty per cent of that amount would be about $5,400m, that is, $5.4 billion. We are talking about a lot of money out of the taxpayers' pockets being spent on hospitals. Hospital authorities reveal that approximately 14 per cent of patients entering mental health institutions are admitted with a diagnosis of alcoholism or alcoholic psychosis.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter I want to concentrate on mostly this evening is the funding of the National Health and Medical Research Council that 'not less than 10 per cent of admissions to public hospitals are substantially due to alcohol'. Taking 10 per cent of $5,400m, that would mean that at the very minimum alcohol related admissions to hospital are costing the community $540m. This figure seems to have a familiar ring. That is about the amount of money that the razor gang has just allegedly saved the taxpayers. All I am talking about is the admissions to public hospitals that the National Health and Medical Research Council attributes directly to alcohol. That does not include the hundreds and thousands of other costs to national health that alcohol produces.

I wonder why we persist with the insanity of allowing this drug, alcohol, to be advertised. It passes my comprehension, when we have evidence that, in terms of hospitals alone, it is costing $540m a year. That is without taking account of the associated agony, suffering and heartbreak. I am informed that alcohol is now the third largest killer of the human race, and yet we still allow it to be advertised. Before I pose as a hypocrite, although in recent times I have become a reformed character in terms of drug intake-I have given up smoking, I have given up coffee, I have given up sugar and I have essentially give up drinking except for--

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you have found something good to replace them.

—Senator Puplick may rest assured of that. He can back that one right in. I confess to having a nightcap or two before retiring. I am not a teetotaller and I do not speak from the moral point of view on this question of abuse of alcohol. But we in this Federal Parliament still allow the incredibly wealthy producers and marketers of alcohol to inculcate into our young people, into our car drivers, the theory that there is no way that they can have a good time at the party they are going to unless they have some bubbly or some social lubricant which will get them going. Millions of dollars are spent to advertise in glorious living technicolour in our lounge rooms that alcohol is a necessary ingredient to have a good time when young people go out. If we continue to permit such advertising, let every honourable senator have it on his or her conscience. But with one stroke of the legislative pen we in the National Parliament could exercise the necessary control over advertising in the electronic media. I would suggest that if a private members Bill were to be introduced into this place seeking to place a ban on the advertising of alcohol in the media a majority of senators would not support it.
—We would not have the courage.

—The majority would not have the courage. I will have the luxury of testing the Senate on that after 30 June. Let us have a look at the figures for the road toll. In 1979, 3,508 people were killed on Australian roads. In 1980, 3,278 people were killed on Australian roads. People suffering injuries requiring surgical or medical treatment numbered 92,000 in 1979. If we heard of some sort of Subiaco Ripper going around killing people and he had killed 50 people in a year, that would be page one national headlines perpetually. And yet in 1979 we allowed 3,278 Australians to be killed on our roads, and 90,000-odd to be maimed.
—And largely as a result of alcohol.

—I thank Senator Coleman for her assistance. That happened largely as a result of alcohol. It has been estimated that 50 per cent of those deaths are due to some extent to alcohol. State governments have introduced a number of measures designed to counter the alcohol-induced component of the road toll. These include the breathalyser, the random breath tests, and interestingly enough, the State which appears to have had the most success is the strictest State-that is, Victoria, my own State. I simply offer that as a statistical fact.

SPEECH.PARA: Why I say it is an insanity to continue to allow the advertising of alcohol is that the insanity was brought home to me recently. I was with my wife at a function of medical superintendents of hospitals at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne. There were about 150 medical superintendents and their wives in attendance. I had finished my speech and I had to leave for another engagement. It was a Friday evening and the resident medical superintendent said: 'Senator, I will show you the quick way out to your car', and he took me through the casualty ward. This was about 9.45 on a Friday night. He said: 'See, it is almost empty'. And it was. There was some fellow there with a little cut on his hand. The medical superintendent said: 'One hour from now you will not be able to move in this place. There will be broken bones, deaths, and blood everywhere. Every single one who comes in here after 11 o'clock tonight will be the victim of alcohol induced fights or stabbings at so-called parties, or road accidents or whatever'.

Yet we allow this to go on. We know that strictures help in this regard. Victoria has had success in reducing the road toll, particularly alcohol related or alcohol induced accidents, by the strictness of its rules and laws regarding alcohol. They are not pleasant. A great number of people would like to have four or five beers with the boys before they go home but do not because if they are caught with a blood alcohol level over 0.05 it is a serious offence. But is that sacrifice not worthwhile to save people from getting killed or maimed? Victoria's road toll peaked in 1970 at 1061. With the assistance of compulsory seat belt laws introduced in 1971, breathalysers introduced in 1971 and random breath testing introduced in 1976, the 1980 figure has been reduced from 1,061 to 663. I commend the Victorian Government for its courage in introducing those reforms.

Might I attack those airy-fairy people who are so-called non-compulsionists and say: 'I will not agree to breathalysers or random breath tests, because I am against compulsion'. I find those people very tiresome, because they have agreed and conformed to all forms of compulsion, to traffic lights, to inspection of food and whatever; but when any new initiative is taken in relation to the road toll, they seem to resist it. I would not find compulsion in this area incompatible with my beliefs as a liberal-and I mean a true liberal of the philosophy of John Stuart Mill. I would easily agree philosophically that the Government has a right to interfere in the private affairs of human beings if that interference can save people from doing harm to a society. My apologies go to Mill for paraphrasing what he said. I repeat that it is clear insanity to allow drunken drivers to continue wreaking havoc on our roads.

Now I would like to be controversial. This is not Australian Democrats policy. This is an injection into the record of the Senate which I hope may be taken up and debated in thinking places around the community. I express a personal view. I believe that we should look at the Swedish example, which has proved extraordinarily effective. To begin with, no Swede may be awarded a driving licence unless he has a reputation for having temperate habits. So no person with a reputation for drunkenness or other intemperate behaviour has a chance of getting a licence in the first place. When someone applies for a licence the local police automatically check their records and those of the local social welfare authority before proceeding to the actual driving test. Honourable senators might say that that is added bureaucracy, added opportunities for graft and corruption. They are the thoughts which flash to one's mind. I am prepared to accept those sorts of invasions on my privacy if the results of the Swedish strictures that I will cite in a moment save lives and save people getting maimed.

In Sweden, having gained a licence, a person may then lose it without having committed any traffic offence if the authorities discover he is leading an insober way of life or if he is found drunk in public. Driving with a blood alcohol content of more than 0.15-can I get some assistance; I think that would be about 12 beers--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is more than that. You wouldn't be making this speech with such clarity.

—I thank Senator Grimes for his assistance. Driving with a blood alcohol content of more than 0.15, or after consuming 15 beers, will always result in a one or two month prison sentence; the maximum is one year. There is no option when a person is found to be in charge of a vehicle with a blood alcohol content of more than 0.15-he goes to gaol for up to a year, regardless of the offender's standing in society. It does not matter what standing in society a person has, the penalty for such an offence is up to a year's gaol. This is termed first degree drunken driving and can also earn a licence disqualification of about two years. A blood alcohol content of between 0.05 and 0.15 will normally be punished by a heavy fine of up to $14,000. This maximum penalty has been applied in many cases. Licence disqualification of about 1 1/2 years is constant.

SPEECH.PARA: But the Swedes go even further. They place the responsibility on the supplier of alcohol, namely, the hotelier, the restauranteur and even the private host. Honourable senators who have been a guest in the home of a Swede will know that the host asks: Did you come here by taxi or did you bring your own vehicle? If a person arrived in his or her own vehicle there is no way that a responsible Swedish host will serve even a sherry or a glass of wine because of the strictness with which this law is enforced in Sweden. These measures are widely accepted by the Swedish population and there is a general disinclination to drink heavily at parties and in hotels.

What are the results? Road fatalities in Sweden in 1979 at 783 were nearly 100 fewer than the number in the preceding year and represent the lowest death toll on Swedish roads since 1956, in spite of a trebling of the number of cars to some 2 million over the intervening 24 years. So in 24 years the number of cars has trebled but there has been a diminution of the order I have described in the number of road deaths. In 1980, 712 persons were killed in traffic accidents in Sweden. That was 71 fatalities less than in 1979 and the lowest figure on record since 1952. My source is the Swedish International Press Bureau. So with a population of about 9 million people Sweden has a road toll of 712, while with a population of about 14 million people Australia has a road toll of 3,300. Australia has 4 1/2 times the number of road deaths that Sweden has, yet Sweden has a population of less than nine million people. We should be fair dinkum about people dying, killing and maiming each other on Australian roads. The tragedy is, as with any other social problem, that scarcely an honourable senator-I am not being critical of other honourable senators or members of parliament-becomes interested to this degree until the problem has struck home to him or her, with a loved one or a family friend suffering a road fatality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't Senator Baume's committee in fact recommend this course of action some years ago?
—I am not aware of that but I thank Senator Puplick for his interjection. I know that it recommended more strict policing of this problem. I did not know that it went as far as the Swedes do.
—Prohibition of advertising.

—If it did that, so be it. I am deeply grateful to Senator Puplick for his interjection. I think it strengthens my point if that committee made recommendations on that and other matters and neither House of this Parliament has bothered to do anything about them. I sincerely hope that my small contribution to the debate tonight will renew debate on this tragic affair.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to enact the excise tariff alternations made by Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1980) and Nos. 1 and 2 (1981). Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1980) were validated by the Excise Tariff Validation Act 1980. They altered the excise duty on stabilised crude petroleum oil from $140.11 to $157.21 per kilolitre and on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas from $41.65 to $43.48 per kilolitre. The alterations operated from 1 July 1980. Excise Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1981) were moved in the House on 3 March 1981. They further altered the excise duty on stabilised crude petroleum oil from $157.21 to $174.08 a kilolitre and on naturally occurring LPG from $43.48 to $36.67 per kilolitre. These alterations operated from 1 January 1981. The alterations followed determinations of new import parity prices for crude oil and the setting of new wholesale prices for naturally occurring LPG by me.

Government policy in relation to crude oil is that all Australian produced crude is sold to refineries at import parity prices. These are based on the official price of Saudi Arabian light market crude. This policy is designed to maintain an adequate supply of liquid fuels over the longer term by encouraging conservation. At the same time it is intended to provide an incentive for exploration and development of Australian energy resources.
