Government policy on naturally occurring LPG is to link the wholesale price of this gas to the price of Australian crude oil. The wholesale price of this gas increases by the same percentage as any increase in the price of that crude oil. However, there is one overriding qualification. If world price trends result in the export value of LPG becoming lower than the domestic price then a price based on the export value will become the basic price for domestic purposes. This policy is designed to encourage use of LPG as an alternative fuel, thus reducing Australia's dependence on imported crude oil. The rate of excise duty on naturally occurring LPG is set at 60 per cent of the average wholesale price for both domestic and export markets in excess of $147 per tonne. Because of a decrease in export values over the six-month period ending on 30 November 1980 the rate of excise duty was reduced by $6.81 a kilolitre from 1 January 1981.

Excise Tariff Proposals No. 2 (1981) were also moved in the other place on 3 March 1981. They created a new excise tariff item for mixtures of fuel ethanol and petrol. This new item provides the administrative basis for the excise treatment of ethanol-petrol mixtures as a transport fuel in its own right. Previously, the components of such mixtures had to be separately entered for excise tariff purposes. It is Government policy that the ethanol component of such mixtures be duty free. This has the objective of also encouraging the production and use of this product as an alternative fuel. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly in support of the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1981. The situation in relation to pig meat is that production exceeds consumption and there appears to be a degree of build-up in stocks. I am also concerned about the plight of the smaller pig producer in Australia who is faced with increasing pressure on account of increases in the price of wheat and diminishing returns for his product. Certainly people who have spent high capital sums on piggeries are facing a major problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The other major problem that they are facing is that on the mainland we have seen the establishment of very large piggeries which are financed largely by transnational companies. Many of our local producers are concerned that these transnational companies can deliberately keep prices down for a sufficient period to force many of those small producers out of business with a consequent loss of livelihood. So the small pig producers are faced with the high cost of wheat; and in Tasmania they have difficulties because of a need to rely on limited shipping from the mainland. This adds substantially to their problems.

The handling of wheat in Tasmania also causes difficulty as the Australian Wheat Board hands over a degree of responsibility to the Tasmanian Grain Elevators Board. Many of the producers in the northern part of the State are required to provide security if they want supplies quickly. The normal procedure is that they send their cheque to Hobart and an order is sent out; one copy goes to the Grain Elevators Board and another to the producer. It is only on the production of that document from Hobart that producers can pick up wheat. This means producers have to have substantial storage of wheat supplies which adds considerably to their costs of stockholding and therefore their investment in stock is considerably higher than it should be.

Another problem that producers face is the fact that the price of the meatmeal does tend to vary quite considerably. It is very difficult for producers to chart movements in the price of meatmeal. The producers feel that to some extent the problem has been exacerbated by the demand situation in Japan which is difficult to predict. Japan's entry into the market appears to follow a pattern. If Japan is short of fish protein from Peru the Japanese will suddenly come into the Australian market to seek supplies. This is a further difficulty that the producers are faced with at the present time.

The producers also feel that in relation to the need to promote their products further they are in a catch-22 situation. The authorities say 'you must advertise to sell your product' but if we look at the statistics we find that basically consumption of pig meat a head has varied somewhat over the years. For example, in 1974-75 the apparent consumption of pig meat a head was 5.1 kilograms. In 1979-80 it was 4.9 kilograms, which admittedly was a substantial rise on the consumption figure for 1978-79. The same sorts of advisers go around to the poultry producers and say: 'To sell your product you must produce more poultry'. Who really is benefiting? Many of the smaller producers believe it is merely the advertising people who are the main recipients in this sort of situation. The producers believe that they are in a catch-22 situation because they cannot afford not to advertise and to take the risk. Some of them believe they have to go along with the advice they receive. There is another problem facing the producers in that if they promote their product there is the problem of not being able to supply the quantity promoted.

I leave it at that to indicate the problems facing the small producers, particularly in a small State such as Tasmania, at the present time. These problems include the low prices they are getting for their product, the high costs of production and the entry of transnationals with vast piggeries on the mainland where they can sell large quantities to supermarkets and probably are able to buy at a better price. I would like to take this opportunity of thanking Senator Chipp who spoke on the previous Bill-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Please keep your remarks to this Bill.
—I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Pig Slaughter Levy Act 1971 to raise the maximum permissible rate of levy for promotion purposes from 20c to $1 per pig. The amendment relates only to the maximum rate of levy, not to the operative rate of levy paid by producers which is set by regulation. A levy has been paid by pig producers since 1975 to provide funds for the promotion of pig meat. Promotion is funded entirely by the industry, and expenditure has been increasing because of expanding activities at wholesale, retail and consumer levels and because of rising media costs. The request for an increase in the maximum rate of levy has been made by the national body of the pig industry, the Australian Commercial Pig Producers Federation. The Federation has sought the amendment as increases in the operative rate have taken the levy to 20c, which is the maximum currently permitted under the Act. Without this amendment there is no scope to raise the levy further and expand promotion expenditure in the future. Any subsequent increase to the operative rate requires a recommendation from the Pig Meat Promotion Committee to the Minister. The Committee consults with the industry before making its recommendation to the Minister for Primary Industry. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 May on motion by Senator Durack:

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has been conducting an inquiry into matters related to the Australian Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. This inquiry is in pursuance of the Committee's reference from the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: The continuing oversight of the financial and administrative affairs or undertakings of Commonwealth statutory authorities, and other bodies which the Commonwealth owns or controls wholly or substantially, and of the appropriateness and significance of their practice in accounting to the Parliament.

In the course of the inquiry evidence was given, on oath, relating to certain trading arrangements in large quantities of skim milk powder and suggesting that these arrangements were in breach of Australia's obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Relevant to this were questions relating to the knowledge and actions of the Government at various stages of these arrangements. Evidence was given, on oath, as to the meetings between the then chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation and the then Minister for Primary Industry, the Right Honourable Ian Sinclair.

The Committee decided to write to the former Minister, now the Minister for Communications, inviting him to put in writing his recollection of the relevant events. The Minister's reply was, in certain important respects, in direct conflict with that of the former chairman.

The Committee also decided to ask the responsible officer of the Department of Primary Industry questions in relation to this matter. The evidence, given on oath, was somewhat equivocal. The Committee found itself confronted with a dilemma in relation to this evidence-part of which was on oath and a part of which was not. It was decided that in fairness we would write to the Minister inviting him to provide his evidence in the form of a statutory declaration. Had this course been followed it would have meant that all the evidence then had the same basic evidentiary value.

At no stage did the Committee seek to have the Minister appear before the Committee, although we would have been happy to arrange this had the Minister sought the opportunity to make a direct denial on oath. Our letter to the Minister stated that we were inviting him to place his evidence in the form of a statutory declaration 'in the interests of justice'. The Minister declined to accept the invitation but rather chose to take the alternative course of making, by way of personal explanation, a formal statement to the House of Representatives. This statement said:
The Sydney Morning Herald of 4 May made the following comment:
Mr Ian Sinclair is refusing to put on oath his denial that he knew Australia continued to breach an international trade agreement by selling cheap milk powder.

On 27 February 1981 I received a letter from Senator Peter Rae, Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, in which he set down particulars of some evidence received by that Committee and asked for my comments on it. I responded to that letter on 16 March and then on 22 April 1981. I further responded in the following way:
Dear Senator Rae,
The letter under your hand as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations dated 25 March 1981, has been received.
My response to your earlier correspondence of 16 March 1981, was written as a Minister in accordance with the several Oaths taken relating to that office.
My comments were based on my own recollection and supported by Departmental records and my Ministerial diaries.

In my letter of 16 March 1981 I set down in considerable detail my response to Senator Rae's letter which was dated 27 February 1981. As my letter stated, the detail was in accordance with my own recollection and was written as a Minister of the Crown. I have now received a further letter from Senator Rae dated 6 May 1981 in which he comments, inter alia:
Nevertheless, we are left with the dilemma that sworn evidence was given to the Committee which is contradicted only by an unsworn letter from you.

In your letter dated 22 April 1981 you stated the written evidence you gave to the Committee by letter dated 16 March 1981 was given as a 'Minister in accordance with the several Oaths taken relating to that office'.
From our examination of the oaths taken by Ministers we are unable to see any declaration that would place written evidence given by a Minister on the same basis as sworn evidence.

I do not believe it appropriate that a Member of this House should appear and give sworn evidence before a committee of the other House. Therefore, I make this statement with respect to the evidence that I have tendered to that Committee in the Parliament and, of course, in accordance with my responsibilities to this Parliament. I believe that is the correct and proper form by which I can respond to the honourable senator. I assert to that honourable gentleman and to the members of the Senate Committee that I believe the evidence given to them is totally correct and has the substance of my being a Minister and giving it in this place. I do not believe there is any reason for a statutory declaration to be given to confirm formal correspondence entered into by me as a Minister in this place.

That statement, though not on oath, was made by a Minister to his House of Parliament. However, the statement was not in relation to his present ministerial responsibility for which he is accountable to the Parliament. Reference was made by the Minister to his oaths as a Minister and member of the Executive Council. Examination of those oaths shows that they do not bear in any way on the matter of the obligation to make truthful statements; nor do they provide any sanction for breach.

However, the Committee recognises that there is a long-standing convention relating to ministerial responsibility to the Parliament. The Minister made a clear and unequivocal statement to the House of Representatives confirming his belief in the statements made in his letter. There is no doubt that the House of Representatives can treat as a contempt a false statement made to it by a Minister in relation to his area of ministerial responsibility. The extent to which the convention extends beyond that is unclear to us. The Committee is now in the position where it must deliberate on what conclusions it draws in its report on the matters in dispute. It is up to the Committee to compare the evidentiary value of the conflicting points and to make findings accordingly.

I mentioned earlier the uncertain position in regard to the responsibility of a Minister to the Parliament. So far as the Committee is able to ascertain, there is no clear definition of what this responsibility entails and of what the precise relationship is between the Parliament, a parliamentary committee and the Executive. The Committee does not intend to pursue this matter in the context of its inquiry into the Australian Dairy Corporation on which I have made this statement today. However, the Committee considers the problem so important to the whole role of the Parliament, the Executive and the committee system, including joint and statutory committees, that we should draw this to the attention of the Senate. We have also decided to commission a legal opinion on the matter from a suitable senior counsel and will report separately to the Senate at a later stage. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make this statement on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Rae has covered the relevant points fairly comprehensively. Although I am not a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I was present at most of the Committee's public hearings. I must endorse the general comments that Senator Rae made about the one retired officer and the one serving officer of the Department of Primary Industry who appeared before the Committee. I think it would be fair to say that Mr O'Bryan's evidence was extremely vague and that the second officer prevaricated in replying to a number of direct questions. This, of course, left the Committee with the problem that Senator Rae has outlined, namely, that evidence had been given on oath by the former Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation and the Minister reponsible at the time had declined an invitation to give evidence of equal status, claiming, in the first instance, that his oath of ministerial and Executive Council office pre-empted the need for any other oaths, which, as Senator Rae has said and as the Committee concluded, is not correct in that the Executive Council and ministerial oath of Office refers to diligence and secrecy only. There is no mention of guarantees to tell the truth; nor, of course, is there any penal sanction for failure to do so, as there is with a statutory declaration or with evidence given on oath. In the second instance, the Minister responsible at the time claimed that it was not appropriate for a Minister to appear before a Senate committee in this way. This leads me, Mr President, to the point to which I wish to draw your attention in particular, and that is the question which I asked yesterday and in which I essentially asked three things. I asked whether you agreed with the statement in the fifth edition of the Odgers's Australian Senate Practice which says that the Executive Government enjoys no privilege which puts it above Parliament. I then referred you to Standing Order 360 of the House of Representatives. Finally, I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you agree that a Minister should or can refuse to appear? If so, on what grounds?

With respect, Mr President, your reply dealt with only the first two of those questions. You said that you did agree with Odgers but that you did not believe it was appropriate for you to interpret the Standing Orders of the House of Representatives. Your reply did not touch upon the final question which I asked yesterday, which was:
Do you agree that a Minister should or can refuse to appear?
That is, before a Senate committee-
If so, on what grounds?

I certainly would appreciate it, Mr President, if you could see fit at some time in the future to put on the record your response to those questions. I note Senator Rae's comment that the Committee has sought a legal opinion on the problem raised by Mr Sinclair's refusal to appear before the Senate Committee and I agree with the Committee's action in so doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Rae's statement on this matter was a carefully worded one and I simply indicate that it does represent the views of all members of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. The position reached by the Committee was essentially a bipartisan one reached on the basis of discussion and consensus. There is no question of any difference of opinion between members of the Committee as to the proper course now to be followed. I should like to summarise briefly where we are at as a result of the Committee's deliberations and Senator Rae's statement tonight. The position is simply this: The statement of the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) to the House of Representatives is regarded by Committee members as a serious one insofar as it represents an explicit commitment by the Minister to the truth of the proposition he was asserting in the letter given previously to the Committee. It is regarded as so serious indeed, as Senator Rae has indicated, that it would in fact be a contempt of the House were that to amount to a deliberate misleading of the House-indeed, contrary to what my colleague Senator Walsh has said, a contempt punishable by a term of imprisonment by direction of the House should the House be so minded to apply it.
—I referred to the oath of office.

—Indeed, I understand the difference Senator Walsh is making, to the extent that it is a question of the oath of office bearing upon it. That does not bear upon it. To the extent that it is a solemn and deliberate statement being made to the House, for that statement to be an untruth would amount to a contempt punishable as a matter of parliamentary common law by a term of imprisonment, among other things, at the pleasure of the House. That is the first point I wish to make. The Committee regarded the undertaking or the statement made by the Minister as a very serious one and, as such, having considerable evidentiary weight.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point made by the Committee, and I think by Senator Rae in his comments tonight, was that it now remains for the Committee's deliberation and determination as to what respective weight is now to be given, on the one hand, to Mr Webster's statement on oath and, on the other hand, to Mr Sinclair's statement made in a solemn and deliberative fashion to the House of Representatives. It is simply not possible nor would it be in any way proper to speculate as to the outcome of the Committee's deliberations on this matter and as to whether there will be an outcome. I simply make the point, in confirmation of what Senator Rae has said, that this is a matter which the Committee will now have to consider further.

The third point that was made by Senator Rae-I think it bears repetition, to make it absolutely clear that this position was reached on a bipartisan basis by the Committee as a whole-was that the Committee does not propose to pursue the question of Mr Sinclair's giving evidence to the Committee through the possible existing forms and procedures in legal avenues open to it in respect of this matter. However, the Committee does take the view that the issues raised by this matter are so serious, concerning as they do the whole question of the relationship between the two Houses and in particular the relationship between the Executive arm of government and ourselves as legislators, that they do bear very close and careful consideration. It is in that context that the Committee does propose to seek a formal legal opinion as to the strictly legal matters involved in this kind of case-not this case but this kind of case-in order to consider further whether there might be some clarification for the future when questions like this arise. I simply repeat that the Committee's response on this matter-it is a very difficult and sensitive matter-is one that has been the product of unanimous agreement within the Committee and not in any way the product of partisan actions from either side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table additional information received by Estimates Committee A and seek leave for it to be incorporated in the Hansard record of the Committee's proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has been considering the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981 in relation to the Committee's principles (B) and (D), that is, as to whether it might trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties and whether it contains matters more appropriate for parliamentary enactment.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may recall that, on Thursday, 30 April 1981, I made a statement to the Senate in which I indicated that the Committee would be asking the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) to respond urgently to certain matters to be put to him. Under its principle (D), the Committee also sought the views of the ACT House of Assembly and the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, in accordance with the Committee's intention expressed in its sixty-fourth report. I would like to thank the Minister, the Joint Committee and the House of Assembly, for responding so promptly. I mention here that both the Joint Committee and the House of Assembly in their responses opined that ordinances of this nature should be considered by the Assembly before they are made.

The Committee also sought advice on the consequences for accused persons of the disallowance of an ordinance in force at the time prosecutions are launched. The advice is that disallowance would not, in law, have the effect of halting such prosecutions. The Committee considered substantial private representations and material relating to the introduction of a code covering the law relating to parades, processions and assemblies generally, in the Australian Capital Territory. Following discussions which I had with the Minister for the Capital Territory, the Committee considered at this morning's meeting a letter from the Minister giving certain assurances in relation to the Ordinance. I seek leave to have the Minister's letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for the Capital Territory Parliament House Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
13 May 1981 Senator A. W. R. Lewis
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
The Senate
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Lewis,
I refer to my letter to you dated 6 May 1981, your response dated 11 May 1981 and our subsequent discussion with reference to the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981.
I confirm my opinion that it is desirable that there should be a Code covering the law relating to parades, processions and assemblies, generally, in the Australian Capital Territory.

In support, attention is drawn to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights ratified by Australia on 13 August 1980, Article 21 of which expressly refers to the recognition of the right of peaceful assembly.
You will appreciate that due to the extreme urgency of the situation, the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981, which your Committee has under consideration, relates specifically to Anzac Day only.

I am more than happy to give your Committee an undertaking that it is my intention to give instructions for the preparation of a general Ordinance, in effect setting out a Code covering the law relating to parades, processions and assemblies, generally, in the Australian Capital Territory. This will be done as expeditiously as possible, and I further indicate that it is my intention to refer the proposed Ordinance to the House of Assembly and also to your Committee.

I have carefully noted suggestions as to possible amendments of the form of words used in the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981. For my own part I would have no objection whatsoever to these suggestions receiving every consideration by the Parliamentary draftsman. In this regard, of course, you will appreciate that the ultimate responsibility for drafting the proposed Ordinance rests, not with my Department, but with the Attorney-General's Department.

For my own part, as I mentioned to you, I can see no objection, in the general Ordinance, to a substitution of the words 'causes a disturbance at' for the word 'disturbs' which presently appears in Section 23A (3) (a) and (b) in the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981.
The proposed general Ordinance would, upon coming into effect, replace the specific Ordinance which relates solely to Anzac Day.
As to any other suggested amendments, and the specific wording of Section 23A (3) (c), as I told you, I unequivocally reserve my position.

In conclusion, I confirm that pending the making of the proposed general Ordinance, by His Excellency the Governor-General, the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981 will continue to operate with full force and effect.
I would like to place on record my appreciation of the spirit of co-operation which has prevailed during your deliberations and our discussions on this important matter.
Kind regards, Yours sincerely,
MICHAEL HODGMAN Minister for the Capital Territory

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The crux of the letter is the Minister's endorsement of the suggestion that a code covering parades, processions and assemblies be introduced, The Minister undertook to give instructions for the preparation of a general ordinance as expeditiously as possible and agreed to refer the proposed ordinance to this Committee and to the House of Assembly. This will enable the House of Assembly to consider the code before it is made. The Committee, having considered the letter, sought a further assurance from the Minister that the proposed general ordinance would be made prior to Anzac Day 1982. The Minister gave the requested assurance, in a letter of today's date which I also seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for the Capital Territory Parliament House Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Senator A. W. R. Lewis,
Chairman,
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances,
The Senate,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Lewis,
Further to our discussions this morning I hereby confirm my undertaking that the proposed general Ordinance, referred to in my letter of 13 May, will be made prior to Anzac Day 1982.
Kind regards.
Yours sincerely, MICHAEL HODGMAN Minister for the Capital Territory

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Committee, on the clear understanding that the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981 will not operate in 1982, has decided to take no further action in relation to the Ordinance. It accepts the undertakings given by the Minister and looks forward to considering the proposed general ordinance. In conclusion, the Committee endorses the Minister's appreciation of the spirit of co-operation which has prevailed during deliberations and discussions on this important matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In speaking to this motion I make it very clear to Senator Chipp that in fact Senator Lewis expressed to the chamber the view of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. It is based on a very clear undertaking by the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) that the Anzac Day ordinance, if I may refer to it by that short title, will not be operative on Anzac Day 1982. The reason is that the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance, amongst all other laws dealing with the right of assembly in the Australian Capital Territory, will be reviewed and recast in the production of a new general ordinance dealing with the rights of assembly in the Austraian Capital Territory. In a second letter which was received from the Minister at 11 a.m. today he has given an undertaking that that new general ordinance will be in place by Anzac Day 1982. Therefore, this very specific ordinance will be withdrawn, swallowed up and cast aside in the production of a new general ordinance. So we are proceeding on the very clear undertaking by the Minister that the specific ordinance, the subject to the Committee's consideration, will not be operative on Anzac Day 1982. Of course, it cannot be operative at any time before that because it is specifically related to Anzac Days.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the offences that it creates remain until the change.

—Even if the Senate were to disallow the Ordinance tonight, the prosecutions could continue. There is no legal impediment to the continuation of those prosecutions even if the Senate disallows the Ordinance. I will put a further argument very briefly in a moment that whilst there is no legal impediment to the continuance of those prosecutions, given the circumstances of the settlement which was reached, there is a political impediment which should be acknowledged by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: A further consideration was the fact that the recasting will be taken under the guiding criteria of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That is something which at least will give us some touchstone in the consideration of this matter. The consideration of the matter will occur in an unprecedented way. The Minister has undertaken that the consideration of his draft general ordinance will be put not only to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly for its advice but also to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee in an unprecedented way to enable it to have some say in the creation of the new ordinance. But, of course, that examination of the ordinance will in no way impair the integrity of the Committee or the Senate in reviewing the ordinance as finally passed into law before Anzac Day 1982. Then we will be able once again to disallow any provision within it which is obnoxious to the civil liberties of people within the Australian Capital Territory. It is simply on that basis that the Committee found the settlement acceptable.

I return to the point raised by Senator Chipp, namely, that there is no legal impediment to the prosecutions going ahead, whether or not the Senate should disallow the ordinance. I believe that nevertheless there is a very real political impediment to the prosecutions going ahead in light of the Minister's expressed desire that the totality of laws relating to peaceful assembly in the Australian Capital Territory, including of course the very ordinance which has been the subject of our concern and the initiating force in the recasting of all these laws, should be recast.

Finally, I make a plea for an acknowledgment that the people concerned in the proceedings may become subject to conviction on the basis of a law which will be swallowed up by the creation of a general ordinance based more clearly on internationally recognised principles and principles which are seen by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee to be apt. On that basis, having explained the course of deliberations within the Committee, I leave the matter but make a plea that, since the law is to be recast, discretion be exercised so that the prosecutions do not proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the motion to take note of the paper I generally would agree with what has been said both by the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, Senator Lewis, and by Senator Tate. I believe that what is proposed by the determinations of the Committee and of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) is on the whole a sound way of resolving this matter. There has been a fair amount of public controversy about an Australian Capital Territory ordinance which came into effect very shortly before Anzac Day. There has been a considerable amount of dispute as to what were the facts and what was the situation that occurred in Canberra on that day. I certainly do not intend to advance into that area because those are matters which presently are before courts and are not matters which I think we should analyse. I do not think I am in a position to know the precise facts concerning what took place on that day. That is probably not the area with which we are concerned at the moment.
—And carefully not mentioned in my report.
—And, as Senator Lewis points out, the Committee was careful not to mention it in its report so as to avoid any prejudice or mentioning matters which are sub judice.
—Prosecution is an Executive matter. It is in the hands of the Executive to withdraw those prosecutions.
—Of course it is.
—You ought to address yourself to that question.

—I should not address myself to that question. Whatever evidence the Executive has and whatever evidence has been put before the court is a matter for the Executive and the court. It is not a matter for the Senate to judge or pre-judge. I believe that what we are concerned with is an ordinance which deals with a segment of the law in regard to assemblies in this country. It is a pity that we have tackled only a very small part of that. The evidence and the advice which the Committee has received is to the effect that even in the event of disallowance of the ordinance prosecution of an offence committed on Anzac Day can proceed. If in fact we were to disallow it, it would not affect the situation as at that time and a court could proceed with such prosecutions.
—It would then proceed in defiance of the will of Parliament.

—No, it would not be in defiance of the will of Parliament. If Parliament disallowed, which is not the recommendation of this Committee-and this has happened on previous occasions-up to the date of disallowance that law is in effect and applies. In fact, any offence under such law has taken place before disallowance.
—That is questionable though, surely.
—I must say that frankly I was doubtful--
—It ought to be questionable. Let us put it in question.

—I have doubts as to whether that was the situation, but the Committee has been advised, and I understand that the Attorney-General's Department is of the same opinion, that that is the situation in law. Maybe we ought to change that, but it seems that disallowance or non-disallowance will not affect the right to proceed with prosecutions presently in progress. That is a matter that perhaps we can look at. In fact, the Committee has asked for further advice from the Attorney-General on that general matter, not just in relation to the present matter but in relation to the future.
—To change it generally.

—Yes, generally. What has come out of this exercise is an undertaking by the Minister, as he says, to prepare a general code relating to the law in respect of parades, processions and assemblies and that this should subsume the entire law in regard to the ordinance in question before next Anzac Day. In other words, there should be a law which relates generally to assemblies. I remind members of the Senate that we recently agreed to ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That came into force, so far as we are concerned, on 13 November 1980, having been ratified on 13 August 1980. Article 21 of that Covenant provides:

SPEECH.PARA: The right of peaceful assembly shall be recognised. No restrictions may be placed on the exercise of this right other than those imposed in conformity with the law and which are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security or public safety, public order . . ., the protection of public health or morals or the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.

TALK.START.PARA: —That contains a reasonable handful of gateways.

—Yes. The honourable senator knows my view on the subject. There are restrictions and limitations on that law which have been agreed to by international bodies. They are gateways which one can provide. I hope that we will not employ those particular gateways.
—Has not the Minister abrogated that very principle we have ratified, in making the ordinance?

—He has made a law in regard to peaceful assembly in a specific instance. It is a law and ordinance which relates to Anzac Day only. I believe it is highly undesirable to make laws with respect to a particular occasion. We should have a law which covers most cases of assembly. There is really no right of public assembly in the Australian Capital Territory. In the very area in which we have control we have not an appropriate law with regard to assembly. In some States, for instance the State of South Australia, we have a much better law because it provides for notification of the desire to have an assembly. Then, if the police object, one can have a court hearing before the event as to whether it is proper in the circumstances that the assembly take place.

SPEECH.PARA: In New South Wales there is a civil law which has many desirable features. I hope that the code which the Minister brings down will be one which will provide quite reasonably that the parties' interests shall be determined beforehand. If there is to be an assembly or if they want to join an assembly, and there is objection, they can go before a court and argue whether it is reasonable. Then we will not have a situation in which people will do something which will interrupt an assembly and in which everything is done by stealth. In fact, the matter will be determined beforehand.

Under Article 40 of the Covenant that we have now ratified, we have an obligation within one year to report on the steps that we have taken to carry out the terms of the Covenant in Australia. It will be very useful if we can show that in the Australian Capital Territory, where we have control, we have set an example in regard to rights of assembly whereby those terms are properly carried out.

I refer honourable senators to an article written by Robin Handley in the latest issue of the Legal Service Bulletin entitled 'Assembly Laws and the Civil Rights Covenant'. The burden of that whole article, which was written before this matter arose in the Australian Capital Territory, was that we ought to be undertaking an assembly law which would be generally applicable to all cases of assembly in the Territory. Therefore, I see this whole incident as providing an opportunity to improve the state of law and to set out a code for the Australian Capital Territory which I hope would be usefully followed in a number of States of the Commonwealth-I believe I need not name them-in compliance with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

Therefore, I believe the Minister has acted wisely in regard to the proposals that he has made to the Committee. He has given an undertaking that before next Anzac Day we will have subsumed that particular law and will have a code in respect of assembly and procession in this Territory. I believe the indications that have been given in the Minister's decision are wise and that we should support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which was brought down tonight by its Chairman, Senator Lewis. I must say at the outset that I acknowledge the care and attention that the Committee has given to the examination of the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance introduced by the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) with regard to the Anzac Day ceremony, but I must say also that I am in no way satisfied by the conclusions that the Committee has reached. I will not traverse the ground that I traversed when I raised my objections to the Ordinance in this place on a previous occasion. I will simply confine my remarks to the report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: From that report I infer certain things: Firstly, the Ordinance did offend the Committee, in that it did trespass unduly on personal liberties and civil rights. Secondly, the Minister was at fault in failing to consult the House of Assembly, and that that failure to consult was directly contrary to the intention expressed by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee in its sixty-fourth report. I point out to Senator Missen that I infer that, by the undertaking the Minister has now made to enter upon consultation exercises in preparing the ordinance which he has foreshadowed, he has implied that that is what he ought to have done in the first place with the Ordinance before us. So in that respect also the Ordinance is unsatisfactory. There was no consultation with the locally elected body and it is the view of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee that there ought to be such consultation. Thirdly, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee concludes that the prosecutions will continue, despite the fact that they have been made under an ordinance which, firstly, fails properly to protect civil liberties and, secondly, was made without consultation with the local assembly.

I must say at this stage, speaking now as a senator for the Australian Capital Territory, that I find it entirely unsatisfactory that a large number, some 57 or so, of my constituents, are currently charged with a criminal offence under an ordinance which the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee itself admits was unsatisfactory on two cardinal points. Therefore, it is my view that the Ordinance should not be endorsed.

Let us examine the deal that the Minister has offered the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I have examined the correspondence between the Minister and the Committee. The Minister has stated that he will bring in a new ordinance which will deal with the entire matter of assemblies and demonstrations and the public's right to enjoy peaceful assembly in accordance with an international convention which has been described in some detail this evening by Senator Missen. That is all very well. I await the introduction of that ordinance with interest. I am gratified to note that the Minister has given the following undertakings in respect of that ordinance: That he will consult the locally elected body, the House of Assembly; that he will in fact seek the views of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee; that he will go through proper consultative procedures when he brings in the ordinance; and that he will have regard to an international convention.

That is all very satisfactory as far as it goes, but it is for the future. It is an undertaking that the Minister has given with regard to bringing down an ordinance in the future. What he says with regard to the present Ordinance which, on the admission of the Committee is so unsatisfactory, is that that Ordinance must stay in effect until the new ordinance is ready. The Committee states that that will be before next Anzac Day so it is acceptable, but I do not see how the Minister can actually guarantee that the ordinance will be--

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens if that Minister is not here on 25 April next year?

—By interjection, Senator Primmer has raised one problem with that undertaking-that the Minister may not be the responsible Minister on Anzac Day next year-but there are other reservations that one could raise. By committing himself to allowing the proposed new ordinance to go through consultation procedures, he is committing himself to a course in relation to which he cannot make guarantees. The ordinance that he drafts may be unacceptable to the House of Assembly or to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. What will he do in that case? Will he insist on the ordinance despite its being unsuitable and, therefore, contradict his newly-acquired sense of consultation and propriety, or will he maintain that consultation until a satisfactory ordinance is brought down well beyond the date of the next Anzac Day procession? It is just not satisfactory to say: 'We will keep this acknowledged bad ordinance on the books until we have the new ordinance'.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that if the ordinance is unsatisfactory, as it clearly is, there is no case for its being endorsed by the Senate. I do not believe there is a case for an ordinance which is unsatisfactory in the ways I have enumerated, and which the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has admitted is unsatisfactory, being allowed to go unchallenged by the Senate. I remind honourable senators that we have a very special responsibility with regard to the Australian Capital Territory. In the Australian Capital Territory there is no legally elected body with the power to make laws. Therefore, laws are made by way of delegated legislation, the power being delegated by this Parliament. Senator Cavanagh, who is something of an expert on these matters, explained to us on a previous occasion the complexities and difficulties that arise with regard to delegated legislation. When it comes to laws which create criminal offences under which my constituents can be charged, fined and gaoled, the Senate has the final say. Therefore, when we have such an unsatisfactory ordinance I think it is quite inappropriate that it should go unchallenged by the Senate even if the Regulations and Ordinances Committee has reached agreement with the Minister.

Clearly a compromise has been reached between the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the Minister, but I am not at all satisfied with that. It seems to me that the Minister, Mr Hodgman, is now trying to have it both ways. He introduced an ordinance which offended many people for many reasons in order to please a certain sector of the community. If we allow this matter to end here tonight without further action, we will be able to go to the people who were agitating for the ordinance, the Returned Services League, and say: 'The ordinance will stay on the books. There was nothing wrong with it. It was perfectly all right and there will be another one to take its place'. Then he can go to the people who are concerned about civil liberty issues and who do not believe 60 of my constituents ought to be charged with offences created by an ordinance of this kind and say: 'I have taken note of all your civil liberties arguments and I am going to do something about it'. The Minister is trying to have it both ways and I do not think that is proper or just. I do not think the Senate should acquiesce in this.

At this stage I would like to register my acknowledgment of the work that has been done by the Committee but my dissatisfaction with its final conclusion. I foreshadow my wish to take further action in respect of this ordinance, but I wish to take that further action after consulting with other honourable senators in this plce, with my colleagues, with the Australian Democrats and with Liberal and National Country Party senators who may feel, as I do, that the situation has not been satisfactorily resolved. Of course, I want to consult also the people who are affected by all this-my constituents. I am dissatisfied with the conclusions of the Committee and, after consultation, I will seek to take further action in respect of this unsatisfactory ordinance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I want to say a few words about this matter as there is some doubt as to whether my attitude on one question seems to be the reverse of my attitude on this question. The first thing to remember on this question is that it is the right of any honourable senator to move to disallow a regulation. That is not the prerogative of the Committee alone. I think this regulation offends against the civil rights of the individual. I think any law which attracts breaches by a large number of normally law-abiding citizens is not a good law. I think a law which creates such large scale breaches is so important that it should be an Act of parliament rather than a regulation. But this question does not concern the Regulations and Ordinance Committee deciding anything. What Senator Ryan said is correct-the Parliament gives a Minister the power to make a valid law.

SPEECH.PARA: When the report from the Commonwealth Conference of Delegated Legislation Committees was brought down here I mentioned that and mentioned looking at approval of regulations and not at their disallowance. The system I mentioned would make any regulation ineffective until such time as the Parliament had had an opportunity to look at it. As I said when discussing this matter on the night on which that report was brought down, the difficulty with that is that an urgent regulation could not be brought into operation when the Parliament was in recess. During the whole time that I have been a member of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee the Committee, whenever possible, has sought to obtain remedial action in respect of an offensive regulation, rather than to move for disallowance. On numerous occasions motions for disallowance before the Parliament have been withdrawn on a Minister's assurance that he would alter the regulation. On this occasion we are faced with a regulation which was apparently properly made and enforced because of our neglect in the past to make it impossible to enforce such a regulation until the Parliament had perused it by giving power to a Minister to make a law.

Because the members of the Committee are not inhuman and are concerned that when someone offends against such a law a penalty should be imposed, we considered the effect that disallowance would have on future prosecutions. There was some disagreement. The Committee sought advice from its own legal counsel. As a result of that advice the Committee formed the opinion that whether or not the Senate moves for disallowance would have no effect on the court's decision. The regulation was law when the offences occurred, even if we subsequently moved to disallow it.

Senator Evans's concern is that the regulation should be withdrawn. I agree with that. The regulation is wrong. The Committee is of the opinion that there should not be a special law for Anzac Day if there is not one for, say, a Labor Day procession. Why should there be particular laws for particular occasions? If there is a need for such a law, consideration should be given to placing a special provision in the law. What the Minister wrote to the Committee was written at the suggestion of the Committee. It was not the Minister's formula. The Committee asked how we could get over this problem. The Committee suggested that there should be one law covering all demonstrations and he said: 'What if this one exists until the next one comes in? It will be 12 months before the regulation would have another application'. The Committee's attitude was that the Minister would bring in another regulation before next Anzac Day and that those who have been prosecuted under this regulation, if the prosecutions continue, will have to submit to trial.

Many legal questions can be argued. We can consider whether the law was properly enforceable at the time and whether there was actually any breach of law. But that is a question for the courts. We know that no one else can be affected until such time as a new ordinance is brought in. We have looked at the Ordinance to see whether it complies with our regulations. The question has arisen as to whether the Ordinance is in breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I consider that it is. It is our responsibility to point that out, and we are doing so. The Parliament has to have the power to do so. If we are firmly of the belief that the law is in contravention of an international obligation and if the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has discovered that that is so or agrees with what I have said, he surely cannot proceed with the prosecutions when the occasion arises. I hope that he will not do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a former member of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I do not, for a moment, underestimate the difficulty or sensitivity of the task confronting that Committee in dealing with matters of this kind and in particular a matter such as this which is capable of arousing great passions in different sections of the community. At the same time, it was with profound regret that I heard the Committee's apparently unanimous report in this chamber tonight. Let me explain why. Everyone seems to agree that the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981 is objectionable, that it unduly trespasses on the rights and liberties of the subject and that, as it presently stands, it offends even the most literal and wide reaching reading of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That seems unquestionably to be the view of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), at least to the extent to which he has responded to the representations, of the Committee. It is undoubtedly the view of the Committee itself. It seems to be the view of Senator Lewis and other members of the Committee who have spoken tonight. Certainly it is the view of myself and others on this side of the chamber who have spoken. Nobody has come out of the woodwork to defend this Ordinance, for the reason that it is indefensible.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is the Ordinance indefensible? Let us remind ourselves of some of its terms. Of course, it might be ligitimate to have something on the books prohibiting disruption, physical disturbance, violence and offensive demonstrations on an occasion as solemn and dignified as Anzac Day. Almost a dozen provisions are on the statute books already to deal with that kind of conduct. What the 60 women nearly overwhelmingly were charged with was not an offence against that sort of provision in the Ordinance. They were not charged with disruptive behaviour, violent behaviour or anything that could be described as offensive behaviour according to the normally understood standards and conventions that apply in the common law and the statute law. They were charged with offending against the provisions of the Ordinance.

Let the Committee members-Senator Missen, Senator Lewis and others who have spoken-be reminded of the terms of this Ordinance. A person can be convicted under this Ordinance for refusing to obey the direction of a police officer which is based on the belief of that police officer as to the likelihood of the person committing the following offence, namely, engaging in conduct which is likely to cause offence or insult to persons taking part in such a parade or ceremony. How many instances removed from objective reality is that? How many subjective opinions are compounded one upon the other? We are talking about the likelihood of the possibility of a person engaging in a form of conduct which is, not likely to physically disrupt the demonstration, but likely to give offence or insult to someone participating in the parade. I find this contemptible. The provision is far reaching, over-broad and impossibly vague. It goes beyond anything that exists in the law, and these women have been charged under that provision. Overwhelmingly, they were peaceably wanting to participate in the Anzac Day ceremonies to make a dignified point about women being raped in war. They wanted to do so in a way which, however inoffensive physically it may have been, was bound to offend the insensitivities of some shellback conservatives who took a different view about what Anzac Day was about. That is the kind of offence we are talking about. That is what is offensive about this Ordinance. Let us remember that in everything we say. It appears that the Minister has accepted this fact. The Committee and everyone else seem to accept that the law is over-broad, vague and offensive in this way.

What is the matter with the proposal that has been put forward by the Committee? Probably, nothing is the matter with it if we look at it on the face of the law. An undertaking has been given to get rid of these offensive provisions and to look at the whole context of the street offence law by the time of the next Anzac Day. So far, so good. If nobody had been prosecuted under the existing law I, for one, would say: 'Well and good; that is a reasonable compromise'. The reality is that 64 people are presently awaiting prosecution under the operation of this law. What has been brought forward by the Committee may be a satisfactory solution for everyone else, but it is not a satisfactory solution for any of the people who are awaiting prosecution and are overwhelmingly likely to be convicted on the literal text of the law as it stands at the moment.

Mr Hodgman has tonight put on record his reaction to Senator Tate's suggestion, made earlier in the debate, that maybe the Executive should have a second look at these prosecutions, that maybe the Executive should withdraw them in the interests of fairness and justice all round. Do honourable senators know Mr Hodgman's reaction that he put on record tonight? I was informed a few minutes ago that Mr Hodgman has gone on record as saying that Senator Tate and anyone else who suggests that the prosecutions ought to be withdrawn by the Executive because of the offensiveness of this legislation are kidding themselves. Mr Hodgman says that he will never interfere with the due process of the law. Mr Hodgman has put on record also tonight, I understand, his view on the legitimacy of the law as it stands. Whatever he might have sought to convey to the Committee in the language of his letter, he apparently has also gone on record tonight-I was informed of this a few minutes ago-as saying the following: 'I could not tolerate a situation where incompatible groups would use Anzac Day to push their own particular point of view. Nothing has changed'. That is the attitude of this Minister to this legislation. It shows that he will say one thing to the Committee to buy a particular package which gets him off the hook and to remove embarrassment from himself and then smugly turn around after the event and say the contrary. This indicates, specifically, that he is not prepared to exercise the kind of Executive discretion unequivocally open to him at the moment to arrange for the prosecutions to be withdrawn.

Where do we go from here? Some people will say, in response to this sort of situation, that maybe it is no business of the Parliament to comment, that maybe it is no business of the Senate as a whole or any individual senator to express an opinion that maybe in all the circumstances, given the manifest offensiveness of this law, the prosecutions ought to be withdrawn so that we can go back to day one. Maybe someone will say that it is not appropriate for a legislative chamber to do that because the matter is sub judice. Let it be understood that that is nonsense. As the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) will be well aware, prosecution is a matter for the Executive. Prosecutions are laid by the Executive branch of government. Prosecutions can be withdrawn by the Executive branch of government. That is what we are talking about tonight. We are not talking about what the court should or should not do. We are talking about what the Executive should do in relation to the prosecutions.

There is no doubt in my mind that, given the manifest offensiveness of this law and the manifest injustice of women being prosecuted under the terms of this law, the prosecutions ought to be withdrawn. If they are not withdrawn the Senate should proceed to consider very seriously the question of the disallowance of this Ordinance. I am well aware that technically the disallowance of this Ordinance will not affect the viability of the prosecutions currently pending against these women. Of course that is true as a technical matter of law; but it is equally true, as a matter of real world reality, that if the Ordinance is disallowed by this Parliament before the prosecutions come to fruition those prosecutions will not be proceeded with and no court will feel realistically able to deal with them for this reason. How could a prosecution or any court in the land worth its salt confront the business of convicting and fining someone for an offence against an ordinance which has been determined by this Parliament to be offensive to civil liberties and, as such, demanding to be disallowed? Because of this there is an overwhelming reason in logic or at least in practice for the Ordinance to be disallowed even if the offences technically are not struck off by virtue of that happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will try in due course.

—That is the consideration that remains for the State. I make the point, in conclusion, that there is something manifestly offensive about every aspect of the way in which this unhappy exercise is being conducted. It is objectionable for the Ordinance to stay on foot and for these prosecutions to proceed. So long as an injustice of this kind is being perpetrated, the Senate should cry out against it and continue to express its voice, its pressure and its complaint to the Minister of the day, because it is absolutely intolerable that situations such as this should be allowed to continue in a democracy such as ours.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which of the following documents, which were included in An Inside Dopester's Index of One Hundred Examples of Secrecy, an appendix to the book Secrecy: Political Censorship in Australia by Jim Spigelman (Angus and Robertson, Sydney, 1972), have now been published: (a) No. 48-Register of restrictive trade practices and agreements; and (b) No. 49 Commissioner of Trade Practices complaints and investigations on examinable practices.
(2) Which of the above-mentioned documents have now otherwise been made available.
(3) Which of the documents so far not made available would the Government now be prepared to make available either unconditionally or on any, and if so what, conditions.
(4) Which of the documents does the Government continue to refuse to make available, and why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No register of restrictive trade practices and agreements was maintained by the Commissioner of Trade Practices. The Commissioner did maintain, however, a register of trade agreements. The register of trade agreements and the records of the Commissioner of Trade Practices concerning complaints and investigations on examinable practices were maintained from 1965 until 1974 and have never been published.
(2) and (3) Neither.

(4) Both. The information contained in the register of trade agreements and the Commissioner of Trade Practices' complaints and investigations on examinable practices was obtained on a confidential basis from industry. A guarantee that this information would be kept confidential was specifically provided for in the Restrictive Trade Practices Act 1971 and its predecessors.
Sections 148 and 149 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 also continues the confidentiality for documents acquired under the previous legislation.

As the information contained within the register of trade agreements, and the information in the Commissioner of Trade Practices records of complaints and investigations on examinable practices, was obtained under a specific legal provision that the information would remain confidential, it would not be appropriate for the Government to now make that information public.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications aware of a campaign by the Operation Woodpecker Committee directed against Soviet Union experiments with a long range military radar system.

(2) Are the Committee's claims correct that this system, known as Over Horizon Radar, is generating interference in the HF spectrum and could endanger human life should the interference block out a Mayday call; and if so have approaches been made to the Soviet Union through diplomatic or other channels to relieve this situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) My Department is aware of the radio interference caused by OHR systems. Fortunately, the interference is much less harmful in Australia than it is in other parts of the world. In fact, very little specific information is available that the transmissions are causing harmful interference to operating radio services in Australia.

The responsible authorities for safety communication in Australia have not observed any circumstances of significant interference on any of the internationally recognised radio distress channels. On the other hand, there has been some observation recently of OHR signals occurring on the Australian safety frequency 27.880 MHz, though the extent has not been serious. However, on the basis of these observations, my Department has initiated communication with the USSR seeking their co-operation in avoiding interference to the 27.880 MHz safety channel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1034) Senator MacGibbon asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a number of questions without notice concerning the Department of Transport's new logo.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has supplied me with the following additional information:
The new Department of Transport logo has not been overprinted on documents but is being introduced as new supplies of stationery and forms are required.
The redesigned logo contains the same elements as the previous logo, that is, the crossed arrows representing air, land and sea transport and the words Department of Transport, Australia.
No special funds have been allocated for the introduction of the redesigned logo. It will be implemented in the normal course of reprovisioning or renovation over a number of years.
